photos.desc:
Aduana or Customs House, also Intendencia or City Administration in Intramuros, 1899

(F. Tennyson Neely)

text:
Customs House. Location: Calle Aduana (renamed Andres Soriano Jr Ave in 1985), Intramuros, Manila. Built 1823-29, reconstructed 1874-77. Architect: Tomas Cortes; reconstruction plans by Luis Rom; modified by Luis Cespedes.

Manila’s first customs house or Aduana was the Alcaiceria de San Fernando, an octagonal two-story trading building of stone and wood that also housed Chinese traders. It was constructed from 1752 to 1758 on the northern banks of the Pasig, within range of the guns of Fort Santiago. In 1796 a set of instructions regarding the fortification of Manila specified that the Aduana be relocated to Intramuros. This would be an incentive for the merchants to remain within the walled city rather than outside it, as was becoming the trend.

The walls behind Santo Domingo church were demolished by the architect Ildefonso de Aragon to create a space for the new Aduana, which became the terminus for the street named after it. With plans by Tomas Cortes, who succeeded Aragon as chief engineer, construction lasted from 1823 to 1829. Notwithstanding objections that the building was inadequate for the burgeoning international port of Manila, mainly because it was too far from the port and offered too little space for warehousing, the building was considered a beautiful piece of classical architecture. Contemporary writers appreciated its good proportions and monumental appearance a la Europa. Its four corners and central facade were characterized by pabellones (pavilions), where the walls slightly jutted out from the rest of the building. The handsome building of cut stone had three principal entrances which led to two courtyards separated by two principal staircases. The roof was renovated by the firm of Manuel Perez in 1861, following the plans of Luciano Oliver. Despite this, the heavy tile roof seriously damaged the building during the earthquake of 1863. The abandoned ruin deteriorated rapidly, especially after the earthquakes of 1869 and 1872.

As early as 1866 two plans for the reconstruction were submitted to the consultative body of the Obras Publicas, one by Felix Roxas Sr and another by an anonymous architect, later identified as Juan Rom. The latter’s plans were followed as the Roxas plans were considerably deficient. Rom’s plan as further improved by Obras Publicas hewed closely to the older neoclassical lines. In 1871, galvanized iron sheets were proposed instead of tiles, and wooden facade details were replaced with brick ones. Luis Cespedes, who succeeded Rom, was supervising architect. Cespedes extended Cortes’s almohadillado (rustication) throughout the building’s exterior, which had been suppressed by Rom. He also expanded the entresuelo (mezzanine) for more office space. Implementation of the project was contracted to Luis Perez Yap-Sionjue who, working from 1874 to 1877, also obtained all discarded masonry.

The renovated building housed the central treasury (hacienda) and its archives, as well as the Bank of Isabel II. Hardly damaged by the 1880 earthquake, it provided temporary headquarters for the Intendencia, the tax office. The present historical marker thus inaccurately names the building the Intendencia, and Cespedes its builder. The functions of the Aduana had returned to the site of the old Alcaiceria since 1872.

As it housed the Treasury, the Aduana Building was destroyed by Japanese bombing in late Dec 1941. It was restored after World War II as the Central Bank of the Philippines; a reinforced cement vault was built in the atrium. After a fire in 1979, it was abandoned. In 1998 work began towards converting the Aduana into the Spanish section of the National Archives. With the walls dangerously stripped of their lime plaster, the project is still pending.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Galvan Guijo, Javier. 2004. “Arquitectura y Urbanismo de origen español en el Pacifico Occidental (1)”. PhD diss. Madrid: Universidad Politecnica Superior de Arquitectura.

Merino, Luis, OSA. 1987. Arquitectura y Urbanismo en el Siglo XIX. Manila: Centro Cultural de España and Intramuros Administration.

Torres, Jose Victor Z. 2005. Ciudad Murada. A Walk through Historic Intramuros. Manila: Intramuros Administration and Vibal Publishing House, Inc.

photos.desc:
Church of San Juan Nepomuceno in Anini-y, Antique, 2013

(Mello Villareal)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of San Juan Nepomuceno. Location: Anini-y, Antique. Built late 19th century to probably turn of the 20th century.

Situated on the southern tip of the island of Panay called Naso Point, the town of Anini-y became an independent parish in 1861. It was previously a visita (mission chapel) of the neighboring towns of Dao (now Tobias Fornier) and Hamtic. In 1840, Cagayancillo was annexed to Anini-y but eventually became a separate parish in 1895. Anini-y town got its name from the local word anini which means a place of small rivers. It was settled by people from a village of Hamtic called Asluman around 1600 to 1630 and immigrants from Cagayancillo who settled the town in the early 18th century. The residents supported themselves through fishing and farming. The town is also known for its sulphuric springs at a place called Sira-an.

Previously administered by secular priests, the town was taken over by the Augustinians in 1875 and administered as a parish by them probably until the late 1890s. The church and the convent were vacant when the Aglipayans seized both in 1902. In 1906, the Mill Hill Fathers from England arrived and were assigned to the province of Antique, including Anini-y. Fr John Sweere was named the first parish priest of the town in 1928. The Mill Hill Fathers still administer the parish up to the present.

 

The town’s first church was possibly built by Fr Hipolito Casiano around 1630 and 1638. It measured 33 m long by 13 m wide. The town’s second church was constructed near the old one in 1845. It was longer than the older church, measuring 44 m by 12.50 m. In 1879, the construction of the convento was completed by Fr Jeronimo Vaquerin. Fr Vaquerin replaced the second church with a new structure made of masonry. There is no exact date as to when the present coral stone church was started but by 1894 it was already roofed and in 1898 almost completed. This edifice measures 65 m long and 16 m wide. Parts of the town’s second church are still visible today.

The church survived the powerful Lady Caycay earthquake of 1948 but was damaged by a typhoon in 1973. The roof was blown off and the back wall collapsed. The church was subsequently restored by Fr William Erinkweld. The ruins of an old convento are found behind the church.

The church is in the classical revivalist style with baroque embellishments, popular during the 19th century. It has a rectangular facade capped by a triangular pediment with a niche at its center, flanked by two blind occuli. The two-story facade, unlike the baroque style of the 18th century, is demarcated by a line separating the first from the second story. Four shallow pilasters, terminating in composite capitals, run the height of the first story and divide it vertically into three parts. At the center is the arched entrance to the church, flanked at the sides by niches above which are occuli larger than those of the second story. The baroque touch of this otherwise classical facade are the rosettes and acanthus leaves embellishing the niches, the arched entrance, and the base of the pediment.

Attached to the facade is a three-story domed bell tower. The top two registers are octagonal and the base is a quadrilateral in plan.

The church has altars in the neoclassical style. The main altar, a new construction, is based on the baptistry’s niche and statue. The baptistry niche is decorated in the baroque manner, crowned by a semicircular pediment that can be interpreted as either a sunburst or an anahaw leaf. It has an image of the Baptism of Jesus. A stone baptismal font is in the baptistry located inside the first story of the bell tower as is customary.

Declared a historical site, the church was marked by the then National Historical Institute in 2004.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano, with notes from René B. Javellana

 

Sources

Anini-y Church. 2008. https://heritageconservation.wordpress.com/2008/01/13/anini-y-church/. Posted Jan 13.

Fernandez, Juan, OSA. 2006. Monografias de los Pueblos de la Isla de Pan-ay. Iloilo City: University of San Agustin Publishing House.

Galende, Pedro, OSA. (1987) 1996. Angels in Stone: Architecture of Augustinian Churches in the Philippines. Metro Manila: G.A. Formoso Publishing. 1996 hardcover ed. Manila: San Agustin Museum.

Simbahan ng Anini-y. 2004. National Historical Institute Marker, Antique. Issued 5 Aug.

photos.desc:
Prewar Antipolo Church and Convent

(Our New Possessions by Trumbull White, John E. Hoham & Co, 1898)

Post-World War II Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion in Antipolo, Rizal, 2015

(Don Directo)

text:
Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Inmaculada Concepcion. Location: Antipolo, Rizal. Built 1630-53, renovated after 1863. Architects: Fr Juan de Salazar, SJ and Luciano Oliver. Destroyed in 1945. Replaced by a modern church designed by Jose L. de Ocampo in 1954.

In 1578 the Franciscans established the Antipolo mission; then in 1591, while still a visita (mission chapel) of Taytay, Antipolo was ceded to the Jesuits. According to local tradition, the old town site of Antipolo was about one kilometer east from its present location. By 1596 the Antipolo parish had three barrios, each with its own chapel. In 1603, under the direction of the Fr Diego Garcia, SJ a wooden church was built in Antipolo at the cost of 1,500 pesos. In 1626 Gov-Gen Juan Niño de Tabora brought a dark image of the Inmaculada Concepcion from Acapulco to the Philippines and entrusted it to the Jesuits in 1632.

Meanwhile, from 1630 to 1653, Juan de Salazar built a stone church in Antipolo. Tabora was one of its principal donors. According to local tradition, the Virgin herself chose the church site, as the dark image enshrined in the earlier church had a habit of disappearing and being found at the top of the tipolo tree after which the town was named; hence Ang Tipolo, the popular name of the image of the Virgen de Antipolo. Not after the townspeople had carved a base from the tree for the image did the mysterious disappearances of the Virgin cease.

 

Before 1639, the image was solemnly enthroned in the church Salazar had built. In 1639 and 1640 Chinese rebels destroyed the church interior and desecrated the statue of the Virgin and a crucifix. To prevent its further destruction, the image was hidden by the townspeople in the forest of Guinapo. Later it was transferred to Cavite and designated patroness of the galleon for many decades. In 1645 an earthquake damaged the church fabric although not seriously enough to warrant its demolition. As a safety precaution three courses of stone were removed from the nave, the height of the church tower reduced, the pediment removed and a new one constructed. In 1684 the image was moved from a side altar to a renovated main altar. By this year six reliefs depicting the history of the Virgen de Antipolo had been completed. The church underwent another major renovation in 1726. Tuscan columns replaced Doric columns, and the convento was expanded. In 1824 an earthquake shook down a portion of the church roof and damaged its walls. The earthquake of 1863 brought down part of the bell tower. Repair was done on the church following the plans of government architect Luciano Oliver. In the late 19th century, the upper story of the convento was renovated and a decorative volada (gallery) added. From 1943 to the end of World War II, the image of the Virgin was kept in Quiapo for safekeeping; thus it was saved when both the church and convento of Antipolo were bombed by American Air Force planes in 1945.

 

The 17th-century Antipolo Church has been immortalized in photographs and paintings, notably those of Felipe Roxas and Fernando Amorsolo. These visual records depict a church built on top of a hill, buttressed by a fine stone wall. The church was cruciform, with a square “dome” over the transept. Old pictures of the facade portray it as it was after the 1726 renovations. Tuscan columns define the vertical sweep, and a triangular pediment crowns the squat structure. A bell tower flanks the church on the gospel side. On the other side, the convento is built parallel to the church facade. The interior is typical of colonial churches, where arcos torales (semicircular arches) divide the transept crossing from the apse. During the 19th century, the main altar housed the image of the Virgin in a shrine of chased silver. Bas-reliefs from the 17th-century side altar decorated the church walls.

After the war the parish priest Msgr Francisco Avendaño constructed a completely new circular church set a few meters away from the site of the 17th-century structure. The circular church presents a flat, not a curved, facade because a box-like structure is placed in front of it, which serves as main entrance and vestibule of the church. Because the church serves a large concourse of pilgrims, two entrances open at the sides for them. Behind the church a flight of stairs leads to the Camarin de la Virgen, which allows pilgrims to come close to the image of the Virgin to pray and touch the edge of her veil.

Very little remains of the old Antipolo church, aside from the image of the Virgin, which still bears the marks of the lances that desecrated it in 1639. Two of the high reliefs from the side altar of the Virgin, still bearing traces of gesso, gold leaf, and paint, are preserved in the San Agustin Museum. One is in a private collection. One of the San Agustin reliefs shows the Chinese rebels in Spanish garb burning the image in the uprising of 1639. Four molave images, about 2.25 m high, representing San Ignacio, San Francisco Xavier, Santa Catalina de Alexandria, and Santa Ana, are on display at the upper storey of a structure adjoining the rear portion of the church. These images used to decorate the facade. Another image of San Ignacio was in Xavier House, the Jesuit Provincial’s residence in Santa Ana, Manila, but was transferred to the Sacred Heart Novitiate at the closure of Xavier House. The statue was a gift to the Jesuits in 1931 from Msgr Gamero, then parish priest of Antipolo, who found the image in the Antipolo cemetery.

After Antipolo was created as the seat of a diocese independent of Manila, a number of projects to maintain and beautify the church were executed. A carillon bell was built near the convento. A baroque-inspired retablo was built for the sanctuary. The sanctuary was furnished with furniture and appurtenances in the same style as the retablo.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Araneta Coliseum in Cubao, Quezon City, ca 1960

(Way Kurat)

text:
Domed performance, events, and sports coliseum. Location: Cubao, Quezon City. Built 1957-59. Architect: Dominador Lacson Lugtu. Engineer: Leonardo Onjunco Lugtu.

In 1952, entrepreneur and sugar magnate from Negros J. Amado Araneta purchased a 35-hectare property from the Radio Corporation of America (RCA) in Cubao, Quezon City. Bounded by Aurora Blvd to the north, P. Tuazon to the south, Gen Romulo Ave to the east, and Epifanio de los Santos Ave (EDSA, formerly Highway 54) to the west, the property included the Araneta family home, called Bahay na Puti (White House), and a planned commercial area, presently called Araneta Center.

To anchor the development in this area, the Araneta Coliseum was begun in 1957 and completed in late 1959. Graduates of Mapua Institute of Technology, architect Dominador Lugtu and engineer Leonardo Lugtu, designed the coliseum. Its iconic dome was constructed by assembling prefabricated arches that were bound together by a ring at the top. The roof structure rested on a solid drum of reinforced concrete and strong pillars anchored to the adobe substrate of Cubao. The coliseum drew its inspiration from the classical Roman coliseum in that its plan was circular and rose many stories to enclose tiered sections for the audience, divided into lower box, upper box, and general admission. The audience surrounded a central performance space, which could be configured for various types of shows or events.

 

On 16 Mar 1960, the coliseum opened with a boxing match between Gabriel “Flash” Elorde and American Harold Gomes for the World Junior Lightweight title. It has since been the site of many athletic events like the “Thrilla in Manila” in 1975, the title match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier; the annual games of the Philippine Basketball Association (PBA); and the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP). It hosted the 1978 FIBA World Championship and the NBA champions Washington Bullet versus the PBA selection in 1979. The 1982 Asian Youth Basketball Championship was held at the coliseum.

Aside from sports, the Big Dome has been the site for the Binibining Pilipinas beauty pageant, the Christmas Holiday on Ice show, and numerous musical and stage events. It has also been used for religious events.

From 1960 to 1963, the Big Dome was recognized internationally as the largest covered coliseum in the world. But many structures have surpassed it since then. However, with a diameter of 108 m, and a land area of 4 ha and a floor area of 2.3 ha, it is still a formidable structure.

In Jul 1999, the coliseum underwent its first major renovation at the cost of PHP200 million and reopened on 20 Nov that same year. Changes were made on the seating arrangements, renumbering of seats, and the installation of a four-sided center scoreboard, upgraded in 2010 to a bigger LED screen. In its present configuration the coliseum has a total of 16,035 seats, of which 13,581 are permanent and 2,454 are portable.

In Jul 2011, it was announced that the coliseum had closed a five-year deal with Smart Communications and henceforth was to be known as Smart Araneta Coliseum. article.value: Domed performance, events, and sports coliseum. Location: Cubao, Quezon City. Built 1957-59. Architect: Dominador Lacson Lugtu. Engineer: Leonardo Onjunco Lugtu.

In 1952, entrepreneur and sugar magnate from Negros J. Amado Araneta purchased a 35-hectare property from the Radio Corporation of America (RCA) in Cubao, Quezon City. Bounded by Aurora Blvd to the north, P. Tuazon to the south, Gen Romulo Ave to the east, and Epifanio de los Santos Ave (EDSA, formerly Highway 54) to the west, the property included the Araneta family home, called Bahay na Puti (White House), and a planned commercial area, presently called Araneta Center.

To anchor the development in this area, the Araneta Coliseum was begun in 1957 and completed in late 1959. Graduates of Mapua Institute of Technology, architect Dominador Lugtu and engineer Leonardo Lugtu, designed the coliseum. Its iconic dome was constructed by assembling prefabricated arches that were bound together by a ring at the top. The roof structure rested on a solid drum of reinforced concrete and strong pillars anchored to the adobe substrate of Cubao. The coliseum drew its inspiration from the classical Roman coliseum in that its plan was circular and rose many stories to enclose tiered sections for the audience, divided into lower box, upper box, and general admission. The audience surrounded a central performance space, which could be configured for various types of shows or events.

Church of San Miguel in Argao, Cebu, 2009

(National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)

Main altar of Argao Church in Cebu, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Nuestra Señora de la Consolacion. Location: Argao, Cebu. Built ca 1788-1830.

The coastal town of Argao, 66 km south of Cebu City, was established in 1608. Having separated from Carcar, it became a parish church in 1734 with Fr Ignacio de Olalde as first parish priest. Argao’s first patron was San Miguel Arcangel. The parish also has a devotion to Santo Tomas de Villanueva.

The present church was started in 1788 and completed in the 1830s during the incumbency of Fr Mateo Perez, 1801–36. Fr Perez also built the present convento. Both church and convento were used as refuge in times of crisis. Classes of the Colegio Seminario de San Carlos were temporarily held in the convento after World War II.

 

The church was built using cut stone (corals), known as piedra de Visayas, bricks, and hardwood. The roof, formerly of locally made tiles, was later replaced with galvanized iron. The original rafters of hardwood and the walls of massive cut stones are preserved. The atrium and the northern side of the church are paved with bricks. The damaged portions have been recently restored.

A low wall of cut stone encloses the three sides of the quadrangular patio. The outer side of the wall is decorated with husk garlands, fruits, and festoons. Four corners of the patio have capillas posas (small outdoor oratories), a unique feature among Cebu’s colonial churches. This wall has abstract and symbolic depictions of the Way of the Cross.

 

The church is a simple rectangular building. Its cruciform plan is formed by a single nave from which extends a short transept. Its three-story belfry, designed by Bp Santos Gomez Marañon of Cebu, is attached to the main structure of the church by what was once a camarin de los campaneros (bell ringer’s quarters), now a baptistry housing a stone baptismal font. The bell tower has arched windows with balustrades and is crowned by a dome. Like the first organ of the church that still exists, five of the bell tower’s original eight bells are well preserved.

The facade has three levels formed from two lines of cornices and three segments formed from five sets of decorative Corinthian columns, four of which are paired. The third level, a large triangular pediment, is highlighted by the sculpture of San Miguel at the center. On the second or choir loft level are two semi-rounded windows at either side and a rectangular window at the center. On the first or ground level is the main door, arched and topped by a carved eagle. The facade walls are decorated with various reliefs including the Augustinian coat of arms, floral motifs, and angels. The nave and transept doors are similarly adorned, e.g., the wooden transept door, dated 1788, features a sculpted floral centerpiece.

The church interior is baroque blended with folk rococo. Well-appointed fenestrations include splayed doors and windows, and variations in interior space such as arches and tunnels of increasing height. An old choir loft, supported by a stone arch ornately designed with lattice railings and flame-like cartouche pinnacles, is flanked by twin tribunas (balconies). The wooden vaulted ceiling has colorful murals of biblical scenes from the entrance to the intersection of the nave and transept, with a 1930 painting of Canuto Avila portraying the temptation of Adam and Eve. Even the cornice and the beams are painted, leaving little bare space on the ceiling. The main two-story rococo retablo of San Miguel, a carved pulpit, and side altars covered with gold leaf further adorn the church.

The convento is made of stone and wood. The ground floor was built of mortar and lime or rubblework. Compact earth paved the ground floor of the bodega (warehouse). The upper level is of a variety of hardwood, such as apitong, molave, and ipil. Dividing walls are of tabique pampango (wattle and daub construction). The roof is also of galvanized iron.

The convento adjoins the church from the north side. An L-shaped two-story structure, facing west, it encloses the west orchard and the side doors of the church leading to the west gate. Its ground floor is an old bodega of disposed church properties. Upstairs are a spacious veranda, a sala, and large rooms. A passage from the veranda leads directly to the choir loft of the church. The entire tail end of the convento accommodates the dining and kitchen areas.

The remnants of a fortified perimeter, enclosing church, convento, and patio remain standing. The perimeter gate facing the sea stands directly in front of the church. It is in good condition because the arch entrance still stands, unlike the north and south gates where the posts alone have remained. A short piece of wall connects the seaward gate to a quadrilateral bastion, which at present is inside a privately owned compound and has been converted to an outdoor lounging area. Within the perimeter and beside the seaward gate is a small mortuary chapel marked by the figure of a skeleton. This once served as a clinic for Argao but has since been restored to its former use. Outside the perimeter wall is the town hall of Argao, built in the bahay na bato (stone house) idiom and said to date from the 17th century. This and the adjoining casa tribunal, presently the Hall of Justice, have been intelligently restored. The same cannot be said of the rococo retablo of the church, especially the main retablo, which was excessively gilded, including the statues of the saints. This heavy-handed intervention has masked the exquisite polychrome retablo, whose niches were decorated with peonies and other flowers in the Chinese style.

Behind the church and outside the perimeter stands the ruined Lucero residence. This bahay na bato, said to date to the 18th century, most likely served as temporary convento while the church and convento were being built between ca 1788 and 1830.  Written by Paul Labrado and Monica P. Consing, with notes from René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
American-period Army and Navy Club in Manila

(Leo Cloma Collection)

text:
Location: South Boulevard, corner Manila Bay, near the Quirino Grandstand, Luneta, Manila. Completed: 1909. Architect: William Parsons; built by the US Army Corps of Engineers.

The Army and Navy Club (ANC) was the first social club exclusively for the American military in the Philippines. It was established in Dec 1898 and first housed in Intramuros, Manila. On 12 Apr 1911, the club transferred to the recreational site fronting Manila Bay, following the Manila Master Plan of Daniel Burnham. It shared the lot with the Manila Elks Club, a social club for American civilians also built in 1911.

The ANC was designed by William Parsons as a three-story building along an H-plan; the Kahn system was adopted as a reinforcement medium for concrete. Typical of Parsons’s style are its impressive arched entrance, its maximization of ventilation and natural light through high ceilings and large windows spanning column to column, and airy loggias or verandas that surround the building and open onto courtyards. A flat roof used as an open deck allows views of Manila bay. Inside are the club proper, a dancing hall, and a separate area for the kitchen and servants’ quarters. Other facilities like tennis courts, a swimming pool, and service apartments were added later. The club thrived during the Philippine Commonwealth.

 

During World War II, ANC served as a bomb shelter and evacuation center. Both ANC and Elks Club were heavily damaged during the Liberation of Manila, and were eventually rebuilt. The ANC continued to operate until the 1980s and Filipinos were allowed to become members.

On 26 Apr 1991, the National Historical Institute declared both ANC and the Elks Club historical landmarks. The Elks Club was first converted into a rehearsal hall of the Manila Symphony Orchestra, then the Contemporary Art Museum Philippines (CAMP), and later into the Museo Pambata. The ANC was converted into the Museo ng Maynila in 2007 but the museum closed a few years later. It has now been converted into the Rizal Park Hotel.  Written by Clarissa L. Avendaño, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Prewar Ayuntamiento or City Hall in Intramuros

(Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)

text:
City Hall of Manila. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Built 1885-87. Architects: Eduardo Lopez Navarro, Felix Roxas Sr, Juan Hervas.

Although popularly known as Ayuntamiento (from Spanish “ayuntamiento”, meaning city corporation or ruling body), a more accurate name for this building is casa de ayuntamiento (house of the city corporation); or casas consistoriales (meeting house), roughly equivalent to city hall. The hall housed the cabildo or city chapter, composed of the offices of the alcalde and his regidores or the city mayor and councilors, the city jail, and other offices including that of the governor-general.

Thirty days after the official foundation of the City of Manila, Miguel Lopez de Legazpi mapped out the site for the future casas consistoriales, henceforth to be referred to as Ayuntamiento. However, for lack of funds, not even a structure of wood and nipa was raised, and thus for some years the city chapter meetings were held where convenient. The building of the Intramuros walls occasioned such a delay. Not until the incumbency of Gov-Gen Francisco Tello did work begin on a permanent home for the Ayuntamiento ca 1599. Morga, ca 1607, described this building as made of cut stones, monumental and pleasing to behold; its first floor housed the courts of first instance presided by the mayors and judges, and the municipal jail. The second story may have housed the meeting hall, the customary chapel, the administrative offices, and the archives. The building may have been just one wing, as later reports describe the old hall as unfinished. The effects of the earthquakes of 1645 and 1658 on the structure are inadequately documented, but a document of 1684 pleaded for funds to restore the structure ruined by so many quakes. The Ayuntamiento at this time held its sessions in a house rented from the Jesuit College of Manila.

 

On 31 Jan 1735, during the incumbency of Gov-Gen Fernando Valdes y Tamon, the cornerstone for the second Ayuntamiento was laid. The year given for its completion, 1738, is highly doubtful since the chronicles of the Franciscan Francisco de San Antonio state that as of this year the building was still being constructed. The building survived well into the 19th century when the earthquake of 3 Jun 1863 heavily damaged the structure so that it had to be rebuilt. The chief engineer of the islands Eduardo Lopez Navarro was commissioned to draw up plans for the reconstruction, since the city architect failed to deliver them after almost a decade since the quake. The construction of the new Ayuntamiento was scheduled to begin on 29 Apr 1879, but work had to stop a few months later because of an earthquake in 1880. The structural soundness of Navarro’s plans had to be studied and necessary revisions made, after which work continued on 4 Apr 1881. Another work stoppage occurred on 21 Mar 1885.

The completed building served at one time as the office of the American governor-general. In 1907 the first National Assembly of the Philippines held its sessions here. This third building of the Ayuntamiento was ruined during World War II.

As planned by Navarro, the Ayuntamiento was a quadrilateral structure built around an atrium. It had two floors made of cut stone. Presenting a facade in the neoclassical style, it was severe, well proportioned, and with quadrilateral windows and arched entrances arranged in a balanced manner. To relieve the simplicity of the quadrilateral plan, the main entrance at the center of the building and the corners of the building projected outwards, and its upper stories sported balconies, flushed to the walls, in contrast to the main halls, which had floor- to-ceiling windows. Gone were the bulbous wrought-iron balconies of the Ayuntamiento of 1735, as well as the arcaded walk and the clock tower, which gave the older building its characteristic facade.

The three arched doorways led to the interior, which Juan Hervas renovated at the turn of the 19th century. He was responsible for renovating the building’s vestibule, its imperial stairway, and the ballroom or “Marble Hall.” The vestibule had a harlequin floor of black and white marble and sculpted lions decorating the stairway that led to the second story. The stairway had a wrought-iron balustrade decorated by vine-like motifs. All the second-floor rooms opened to a corridor, which in turn opened into the atrium planted with a variety of tropical plants. Tall persiana or louver doors along the corridor could be closed so that the glare and heat from the atrium would not enter the upper story. The corridor was often used for receptions and meals. In this building was the mayor’s office—a room sparsely decorated with a desk and a high-back chair, some Vienna chairs, and paintings by Filipino masters and European artists. There were separate waiting rooms for men and for women who had business to transact with the city government. These were provided with furniture and bric-a-brac from Europe, giving them an overstuffed Victorian air. The session hall of the city chapter had a number of tall and large doors that led into it. Its ceiling was painted with allegorical scenes, and from it hung glass chandeliers from Europe. The “Marble Hall” was rectangular in shape with numerous doors leading into it. A coffered ceiling and chandeliers of brass and glass made this an elegant hall for soirees and social functions of the Manila elite. So popular was this room that the whole Ayuntamiento was also called the Marble Hall.

The Ayuntamiento stood majestic beside the Manila Cathedral and facing the Plaza Mayor until it was ruined during World War II. The interior was gutted, the roof was gone, and only the outer walls remained. A ruin for more than six decades, the gutted interior was once used as a parking lot. Plans to rebuild and restore were discussed but nothing substantial materialized until 2009.

The Bureau of Treasury, which holds office in the restored Ayuntamiento, entered into a contract with DDT Konstract Inc on 19 Oct 2009. In 2010, archaeological investigation, as mandated by a law on all heritage sites, was done under the supervision of the National Museum of the Philippines. Rebuilding and restoration was scheduled to be completed by 2011. By 31 Dec 2012, the Commission on Audit reported that the project of reconstruction had been delayed for one year, one month, and 23 days as of 31 Dec 2012 and the original budget of PHP1.181 billion had incurred an extra PHP195.5 million, in excess of the allowable 10 percent variation or PHP118.2 million because of change order and design modification during the course of construction. The rebuilt and reconstructed Ayuntamiento was finally inaugurated in 2013.

Restored according to the neoclassical plan of Navarro, the restored Ayuntamiento brings closer to completion the restoration of the area surrounding Casa Manila. The restoration is more sensitive to historic architecture and contrasts sharply with the overbuilt Palacio del Gobernador, which beyond its first two floors is a design fantasy with no basis in historic architecture.

The whitewashed exterior of the Ayuntamiento, its shuttered French windows leading to balconies evoke pictures of the building during the early 20th century. The interior is a pleasant surprise. The foyer shows knowledge of historic Philippine architecture. The black and white harlequin floor has been restored; the coffered ceiling and the Imperial staircase, flanked by lions at the base and a statue of Sebastian El Cano at the landing show care in being true to the original building being replaced. The grand hall has a ceiling painted with murals to capture the spirit of the 19th century building, which has been reconstructed.  Written by René B. Javellana

The chief engineer of the islands Eduardo Lopez Navarro was commissioned to draw up plans for the reconstruction, since the city architect failed to deliver them after almost a decade since the quake. The construction of the new Ayuntamiento was scheduled to begin on 29 Apr 1879, but work had to stop a few months later because of an earthquake in 1880. The structural soundness of Navarro’s plans had to be studied and necessary revisions made, after which work continued on 4 Apr 1881. Another work stoppage occurred on 21 Mar 1885.

The completed building served at one time as the office of the American governor-general. In 1907 the first National Assembly of the Philippines held its sessions here. This third building of the Ayuntamiento was ruined during World War II.

As planned by Navarro, the Ayuntamiento was a quadrilateral structure built around an atrium. It had two floors made of cut stone. Presenting a facade in the neoclassical style, it was severe, well proportioned, and with quadrilateral windows and arched entrances arranged in a balanced manner. To relieve the simplicity of the quadrilateral plan, the main entrance at the center of the building and the corners of the building projected outwards, and its upper stories sported balconies, flushed to the walls, in contrast to the main halls, which had floor- to-ceiling windows. Gone were the bulbous wrought-iron balconies of the Ayuntamiento of 1735, as well as the arcaded walk and the clock tower, which gave the older building its characteristic facade.

The three arched doorways led to the interior, which Juan Hervas renovated at the turn of the 19th century. He was responsible for renovating the building’s vestibule, its imperial stairway, and the ballroom or “Marble Hall.” The vestibule had a harlequin floor of black and white marble and sculpted lions decorating the stairway that led to the second story. The stairway had a wrought-iron balustrade decorated by vine-like motifs. All the second-floor rooms opened to a corridor, which in turn opened into the atrium planted with a variety of tropical plants. Tall persiana or louver doors along the corridor could be closed so that the glare and heat from the atrium would not enter the upper story. The corridor was often used for receptions and meals. In this building was the mayor’s office—a room sparsely decorated with a desk and a high-back chair, some Vienna chairs, and paintings by Filipino masters and European artists. There were separate waiting rooms for men and for women who had business to transact with the city government. These were provided with furniture and bric-a-brac from Europe, giving them an overstuffed Victorian air. The session hall of the city chapter had a number of tall and large doors that led into it. Its ceiling was painted with allegorical scenes, and from it hung glass chandeliers from Europe. The “Marble Hall” was rectangular in shape with numerous doors leading into it. A coffered ceiling and chandeliers of brass and glass made this an elegant hall for soirees and social functions of the Manila elite. So popular was this room that the whole Ayuntamiento was also called the Marble Hall.

The Ayuntamiento stood majestic beside the Manila Cathedral and facing the Plaza Mayor until it was ruined during World War II. The interior was gutted, the roof was gone, and only the outer walls remained. A ruin for more than six decades, the gutted interior was once used as a parking lot. Plans to rebuild and restore were discussed but nothing substantial materialized until 2009.

The Bureau of Treasury, which holds office in the restored Ayuntamiento, entered into a contract with DDT Konstract Inc on 19 Oct 2009. In 2010, archaeological investigation, as mandated by a law on all heritage sites, was done under the supervision of the National Museum of the Philippines. Rebuilding and restoration was scheduled to be completed by 2011. By 31 Dec 2012, the Commission on Audit reported that the project of reconstruction had been delayed for one year, one month, and 23 days as of 31 Dec 2012 and the original budget of PHP1.181 billion had incurred an extra PHP195.5 million, in excess of the allowable 10 percent variation or PHP118.2 million because of change order and design modification during the course of construction. The rebuilt and reconstructed Ayuntamiento was finally inaugurated in 2013.

Restored according to the neoclassical plan of Navarro, the restored Ayuntamiento brings closer to completion the restoration of the area surrounding Casa Manila. The restoration is more sensitive to historic architecture and contrasts sharply with the overbuilt Palacio del Gobernador, which beyond its first two floors is a design fantasy with no basis in historic architecture.

The whitewashed exterior of the Ayuntamiento, its shuttered French windows leading to balconies evoke pictures of the building during the early 20th century. The interior is a pleasant surprise. The foyer shows knowledge of historic Philippine architecture. The black and white harlequin floor has been restored; the coffered ceiling and the Imperial staircase, flanked by lions at the base and a statue of Sebastian El Cano at the landing show care in being true to the original building being replaced. The grand hall has a ceiling painted with murals to capture the spirit of the 19th century building, which has been reconstructed.  Written by René B. Javellana

Prewar Bacarra Church and bell tower

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Andres Apostol. Location: Bacarra, Ilocos Norte. Brick church first built early 1700s; damaged and rebuilt several times, especially in the 1830s and 1870s. Bell tower built between 1828 and 1848, under Fr Pedro Berger, OSA.

The area occupied by Bacarra today was known in earlier times as Dumaquaque. It was still known by that name when the first Spaniards arrived in 1572. Its present name is said to derive from bacar, a large local basket for harvested rice, or bacbacarra, a fish common along the coast. The Augustinians founded the mission of Bacarra around 1590. It was nestled between two rivers that linked it with the sea and the mountains. From here Christian centers were established in Vintar, Pasuquin, Banguisan (now Bangui), Bambang (now Taguipuro, a barrio of Bangui), Bangbanglo (the earlier site of Burgos), Adang (Adams), and Vera (location unknown). Thus, Bacarra is the mother parish of the northern half of today’s Ilocos Norte. The town was not exempt from slave raids, as evidenced by a watchtower in barrio Natba.

Atypically, the administrative seat was not in the center of the town’s elongated grid plan. The church was the first building encountered from the river. In this it resembled Vintar, Badoc, Laoag, and indeed Vigan Cathedral. An early church may have been destroyed during the Almazan Revolt of 1661. A single-naved brick church was raised from 1700 to 1706, but most of its walls except the apse cracked in the 1707 earthquake. A new brick church and convento built in the 1830s were renovated in 1868. Both buildings were damaged again by an earthquake in 1880, entailing a new floor and tile roof for the church, and more buttresses for the convento in 1889. These were further repaired in the 1890s. Further earthquakes in 1931, 1944, 1981, and especially 1983 resulted in the drastic alteration of the church complex.

The pre-1981 earthquake facade consisted of two levels and a pediment. The ground level was a massive wall, its single entrance flanked by imposing pairs of twin columns. The squat second level and pediment do not continue the majestic proportions of the first level, and may have replaced their damaged counterparts. A step buttress supports the left church wall. Rare bas-reliefs of Augustinian symbols in stone crown the side entrances. The pre-1981 central retablo was also of brick with a smooth plaster finish, neoclassical in its columns but with echoes of baroque vines running down the sides. The expansive L-shaped convento is brick in both levels, with a sweeping azotea and matching stairway at the back. Several steps lead down to a brick-lined well in the courtyard.

The iconic, massive bell tower stands some distance from the church. A 50-meter tall masterpiece in brick, it was built under the direction of Fr Pedro Berger, parish priest in 1828-48. Its unique cupola shaped like a pilon or sugar loaf came crashing down along with major sections of the walls in the 1980s earthquakes. The Bacarra church was declared a National Cultural Treasure on 1 Aug 1973 by the virtue of Presidential Decree No 260.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Galende, Pedro, OSA. 2007. Philippine Church Facades. Manila: San Agustin Museum.

Ilocos Norte: A Travel Guidebook. 2004. Laoag: Gameng Foundation, Inc.

Jose, Regalado Trota. 2001a. A Chronology of Ilocos Norte History 1572-1999. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion in Baclayon, Bohol, 2012

(Wikimedia Commons)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion. Location: Baclayon, Bohol. Built before 1727.

In 1596, when the Jesuits Juan de Torres and Gabriel Sanchez arrived in Baclayon, the town already had its own church, built at the instigation of the encomendero. This must have been of wood for the first recorded stone church did not appear until much later in 1727, 10 years after Baclayon was raised to the status of parish. Mostly intact, this church was one of the best-preserved Jesuit churches in the country. Records of repair and renovation are scanty.

In 1768, Baclayon was ceded to the Recollects, who regilded the church altars in the late 1700s. Around 1777 the lower part of the bell tower in front of the church was completed, as attested to by the inscription on the bell tower. In 1779 silver frontales (silver-decorated panels for the altar) and ornaments were purchased, some of which still remain. A new convento wing was built in 1872. The church transepts are all of finely cut coral stone. The crossing has a squarish cupola made of tabique (wattle and daub construction). Although the Jesuits had a residence within the fort, they preferred to live in the baluarte (fort), which was a separate structure located about a hundred meters from the church and very near the sea. The structure was torn down in 1984. The residence within the walls appears to have been three rooms built above the sacristy, which was an extension of the epistle transept. This extension, all of coral stone, is not immediately visible because the 1872 renovation has hidden part of the wall behind a wooden volada (gallery).

The fortification walls extend from the end of the 1872 wing to a corner bulwark, where it turns north, then west and south, meeting the church near the end of the gospel transept. With the fortification are ruins identified by tradition as a well, kitchen, and stables. Within the fortification are other structures apparently built by the Recollects: an octagonal baptistery and a visita (small chapel). A low perimeter wall protected the flanks of the nave. That wall has been removed in parts and greatly reduced in others.

There are two church facades. The Jesuit-built facade follows the classic San Ignacio-type design (i.e., a triangular pediment surmounts a bipartite lower structure). The Recollect-built facade is an arcade of Roman arches with the upper story and pediment chastely adorned by windows. The Baclayon retablos, arguably the most outstanding in the Visayas, have merged the occidental in its arrangement of statues, and the oriental in its opulent decorations.

Baclayon church’s site poses problems for the structural soundness of the building because of its close proximity to the sea. When on 15 Oct 2013 at 8:15 am, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake hit Bohol and the neighboring islands, especially Cebu, the Recollect-built tower collapsed. About half of it was left standing. So did the Recollect facade and a portion of the Jesuit one. The rest of the church, including its opulent retablos suffered minor damage.  Written by René B. Javellana

Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion in Balayan, Batangas, 2011

(Fung Yu, www.pamana.ph)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion. Location: Plaza Mabini, Balayan, Batangas. Built 1795 by secular clergy.

Although Balayan traces its beginnings to the friars, the present church is among the handful that is the work of the secular or diocesan clergy. In 1575, the Augustinians opened Balayan as a visita (mission chapel) of Bonbon, the ancient name of Taal. Balayan’s boundaries were quite extensive, including in its territory the towns of Nasugbu, Lian, Calatagan, Tuy, and Calaca. It was effectively the visita and later the parish of the southern coast of Batangas. When they arrived in 1578, the Franciscans were given charge of Balayan by the Augustinians. Fr Francisco de Santa Maria, OFM built a provisional church in 1579. The Franciscans ministered at Balayan for more than a decade, when in 1591, the Franciscans, represented by Fr Juan de Oliver, OFM, a noted expert in Tagalog and preacher, turned over Balayan to the Jesuits under Pedro Chirino. This is recorded in Chirino’s Relacion de las islas Filipinas (Accounts on the Philippine Islands). Chirino who was chronicler of the Jesuit missions in the Philippines and trusted assistant of Fr Antonio Sedeño, the mission superior, built a church in Balayan. The Jesuits left Balayan, most likely after 1600, when Fr Diego Garcia, SJ, invoking his authority as visitor, told the Jesuits to consolidate their missions into a few strategic ones since their manpower was overstretched, especially with the opening of the Visayan missions in 1595.

A stone church was reportedly built in 1749. It is unclear by whom because the seculars did not take charge of Balayan until 1753.

Balayan was under the seculars until 1876, when it was turned over to the Recollects. Because Balayan was a coastal town, with an opening to Balayan Bay, and vulnerable to sea-faring raiders, its parish priests built a fortification or stone kuta or fort, after a raid in 1754. They also built a watchtower on a nearby hill. The fortification surrounded the church and convento but the fortification was torn down most likely in the 1840s, when similar fortifications in Bauan and Batangas were taken down. A low row of stones, serving as a perimeter wall, is all that remains of the Balayan fortification.

The church, attributed to the initiative and effort of the seculars, was completed and blessed in 1795 and dedicated to the patroness, Inmaculada Concepcion. It is uncertain if the previous churches of Balayan, until that of 1749, were made of stone or were provisional churches of wood, bamboo and thatch. Most likely Chirino’s 1591 church was provisional as was the church of 1579.

In 1857, a new convent was completed. The old convent, which was located across the patio was demolished but its tiles were used for an ermita or chapel being built for the cemetery. Additions to the church complex did not cease. In 1870, the second and third levels of the bell tower were added. Repair work had to be done on the convento and church, which had been damaged by earthquake. The second floor of the convento had to be taken down and rebuilt and a temporary chapel raised while repair on the church was being made. It was most likely the earthquake of 1863 that damaged the church and convento. The sanctuary of Balayan was refurbished in the 1870s.

In 1875, the archbishop of Manila, under whom all of Batangas fell, authorized the purchase of a retablo mayor, pulpit and other appurtenances for the church. To pave the floor, narra planks were used for the nave and azulejos (tiles) for the sanctuary. An additional bay was added behind the sanctuary as an antesacristia (anteroom) for the sacristy, in 1878. Decorative grilles were installed around the atrium in 1887 and the bell tower was repaired in 1892 using bricks rather than stone. Two intense earthquakes hit Luzon in 1880 and in 1884 in the vicinity of Quezon, then known as Tayabas. It seems that the Balayan bell tower, which was reported as built of stone in 1870, survived the 1880 earthquake but not the one four years later, whose epicenter was closer to Batangas.

In 1857, the construction of the cemetery using material from the demolished convento began. Work on the cemetery continued and rows of niches were built in 1887. In 1896, the work had to be stabilized because of erosion on the hillside. By this time the Recollects were already administering Balayan and the seculars were demoted to assistants.

Although Batangas was not originally Recollect territory, it was given to the Recollects, along with other parishes in Cavite and Batangas to compensate for their loss of parishes in Mindanao, which had been given to the returning Jesuits. Expelled from the Philippines in 1768 and returning in 1859, the Jesuits were assigned to all of Mindanao. The stipulation of their assignment indicated that as soon as a Recollect parish in Mindanao was vacant due to the death, illness or resignation of the parish priest, the Jesuits would take over administration.

The Recollects were replaced by Filipino seculars after the Revolution of 1896. Seculars who had occupied Balayan were driven out by American soldiers, who commandeered the church complex in 1900 to serve as quarters. They remained in the complex for about a year. In 1908, Balayan was given to the seculars of the Archdiocese of Manila. When the Diocese of Lipa was established in 1910, Balayan was placed under it. In 1972, Lipa would be raised to an archdiocese with the suffragan dioceses of Lucena, Gumaca, and Boac.

Exteriorly Balayan church is typical of colonial churches, using a facade plan composed of two stories, crowned by a triangular pediment. The horizontals are defined by projecting rows of stones and the verticals by pilasters and engaged columns at the first floor. The whole facade is flanked by thick pillars capped with a vase finial. Arched openings define the windows and the main entrance found at the center. This is flanked by niches for statues, separated from the main door by flanking engaged columns. Above the niches are arched windows and between them another niche.

The bell tower is also typical. It begins with a quadrilateral base on which three octagonal stories of diminishing sizes are raised. Unlike the church, which is made of stone, this tower is built of bricks. Its uppermost floor was destroyed and for a long time, it was covered with a floor and dome of white metal sheets. That temporary structure, still up until 2003, has been taken down and the upper story of the bell tower restored using bricks. The plaster layer of the church, visible in early 20th century photographs, has not been restored.

The addition of a stone portico in front of the historic building mars the line of the original design.

The church interior has remained largely unchanged except for the refurbishing of the altar in gold leaf and brown wood stain. The pulpit has likewise been refurbished. The nave and sanctuary walls are not embellished so that the stone used for construction are visible. The nave’s ceiling, a flat vault that curves to the side to meet pairs of zapata or corbel along the wall, is painted with a geometric pattern of chamfered boxes. The section where there are zapatas is defined by a brown ladderlike structure that runs from one pair of zapata to those at the opposite wall. This ceiling design is repeated in the transept.

At the transept crossing is a shallow dome supported by pendentives in which the images of the four evangelists are painted as customary. The dome is divided into triangular segments by lines and by clouds that form a frame. The Trinity is depicted in the segment nearest the apse, with the Father on the throne of heaven, holding up the crucified Christ while the Spirit hovers above. Biblical scenes fill the other segments, like the visit of the three angels to Abraham, the Baptism of Jesus, the Commissioning of St Peter.

The adjoining convento, painted in white and blue, is Immaculate Conception College. The college building was involved in a heritage row in 2013. Word leaked that the Archdiocese of Lipa was exploring an arrangement to lease land to a supermarket chain, despite the church’s declaration as a heritage site. Upon pressure by heritage groups, the archdiocesan financial administrator admitted to exploring plans to lease land, but this meant demolishing the heritage building adjoining the church, which served as the casa real and tribunal until 1752, when it was designated as the convento. People’s action saved Balayan from defacement.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

 

Source

Villegas, Ramon. 2002. “Lumang Simbahan: Ancestral Churches of Batangas.” Batangas: Forged in Fire. Makati: Ayala Foundation.

The horizontals are defined by projecting rows of stones and the verticals by pilasters and engaged columns at the first floor. The whole facade is flanked by thick pillars capped with a vase finial. Arched openings define the windows and the main entrance found at the center. This is flanked by niches for statues, separated from the main door by flanking engaged columns. Above the niches are arched windows and between them another niche.

The bell tower is also typical. It begins with a quadrilateral base on which three octagonal stories of diminishing sizes are raised. Unlike the church, which is made of stone, this tower is built of bricks. Its uppermost floor was destroyed and for a long time, it was covered with a floor and dome of white metal sheets. That temporary structure, still up until 2003, has been taken down and the upper story of the bell tower restored using bricks. The plaster layer of the church, visible in early 20th century photographs, has not been restored.
The addition of a stone portico in front of the historic building mars the line of the original design.

The church interior has remained largely unchanged except for the refurbishing of the altar in gold leaf and brown wood stain. The pulpit has likewise been refurbished. The nave and sanctuary walls are not embellished so that the stone used for construction are visible. The nave’s ceiling, a flat vault that curves to the side to meet pairs of zapata or corbel along the wall, is painted with a geometric pattern of chamfered boxes. The section where there are zapatas is defined by a brown ladderlike structure that runs from one pair of zapata to those at the opposite wall. This ceiling design is repeated in the transept.

At the transept crossing is a shallow dome supported by pendentives in which the images of the four evangelists are painted as customary. The dome is divided into triangular segments by lines and by clouds that form a frame. The Trinity is depicted in the segment nearest the apse, with the Father on the throne of heaven, holding up the crucified Christ while the Spirit hovers above. Biblical scenes fill the other segments, like the visit of the three angels to Abraham, the Baptism of Jesus, the Commissioning of St Peter.

The adjoining convento, painted in white and blue, is Immaculate Conception College. The college building was involved in a heritage row in 2013. Word leaked that the Archdiocese of Lipa was exploring an arrangement to lease land to a supermarket chain, despite the church’s declaration as a heritage site. Upon pressure by heritage groups, the archdiocesan financial administrator admitted to exploring plans to lease land, but this meant demolishing the heritage building adjoining the church, which served as the casa real and tribunal until 1752, when it was designated as the convento. People’s action saved Balayan from defacement.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Interior of the Church of Santiago Apostol in Betis, Pampanga, 2016

(Cereneo Mistal)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santiago Apostol. Location: Betis, Pampanga. Built 1660-1770.

Like many of the country’s older towns, Betis grew as a religious unit under the Augustinians before it evolved as a political district. It was a visita (mission chapel) of Tondo and then of Bacolor as early as the late 16th century, but municipally remained part of Lubao till the start of the 17th century.

Fr Fernando Pinto, probably a visiting priest from Lubao, ca 1596-1604, erected the first buildings. Fr Jose de la Cruz began the construction of a stronger church and convento which took from 1660 to 1770 to complete because of the lack of voluntary labor. Repairs were undertaken in 1789 and in 1885. During his 30-year service, 1868-98, Fr Manuel Camañes restored both buildings and added a cemetery. He also dug an artesian well at the center of the plaza fronting the church, a unique feature said to be a precedent in Philippine architectural history.

The church illustrates rococo at its height. A recent addition, the intricate portico, is itself an art piece but distracts from the facade’s other attractions (i.e., the lattice and stained glass windows), the decorative rather than functional columns, and even the hanger-shaped pediment. Much charm is achieved by the combination of various shapes, like the alternating semirounded and rectangular windows of the belfry.

The convento is entered through sculptured wooden doors bearing the Augustinian emblem. A similar wooden door, with carved angels, leads to the richly adorned interior of the church. Simple wooden floors look up to a painted ceiling, the main mural portraying Christ the King. The walls have trompe l’oeil windows, medallions, and other decorations. The small windows have bright-colored glass panes arranged in checkerboard patterns. The rococo retablo is one of the best of its kind in the country. It has two stories with five niches and two relieves on the first story, three niches and two relieves on the second story, and one niche on the pediment. Salomonica columns on the first level and Corinthian columns on the second level separate the niches and reliefs of Augustinian saints. A bust of God the Father peers down from the top center of the retablo’s pediment.  Written by Monica P. Consing

photos.desc:
Church of the Inmaculada Concepcionin Boac, Marinduque, 2009

(National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion. Location: Boac, Marinduque.

The Franciscans were the first to evangelize Marinduque Island, formerly Malindig. The first permanent Franciscan missionary to Boac, Fr Esteban Ortiz, OFM, arrived in 1579. The following year, he founded the town of Boac and named it Montserrat de Marinduque. Fr Alonso Bañol, OFM became the first resident parish priest in 1584. In 1609, Santa Cruz de Napo and Gasan were separated from Boac and the first parish priests were Fr Juan Rosendo, OFM and Fr Pedro de Talavera, OFM respectively.

In 1613, for lack of personnel, the Franciscans returned Marinduque to the Archbishop of Manila. The archbishop appointed a cathedral canon as the proprietary priest of Boac. When the canon died, the archbishop requested the Jesuits to take charge of the island. The Jesuits initially sent men on an extended tour from their Silang residence. They then assigned a resident missionary between 1621 and 1622. They also reestablished the abandoned parishes.

Lying south of Batangas and west of the Bicol Peninsula and Mindoro, the island of Marinduque was strategically important for the defense of Manila. The island was along the pathway of both the galleons and southern raiders. In inclement weather the galleons would take shelter in its harbor at Balanacan as they would in neighboring Puerto Galera in Mindoro Island. Because of its importance, Marinduque’s coasts were lined with fortresses and watchtowers, usually built on hills or promontories.

The fortress church of Boac has a two-story facade with a triangular pediment and heavy buttresses for its single nave, a style common to churches in less war-prone areas. It is strategically located on top of a hill and surrounded by a wall. In case of an attack the church would become the second line of defense. Boac’s defensive walls were probably built sometime in the latter part of the 18th century when raids were frequent. The walls, then as high as 3 m although degraded now, crown the top of the hill, now called Mataas na Bayan (higher town). There are six sides to the walls, each side of unequal length. At every corner are bulwarks with openings for artillery. A sixth bulwark doubles as a sacristy. Two gates pierce the wall; one at the northern side facing the river, and the other at the southern side facing the hills. By 1939, a third breach was cut into the walls, by demolishing the eastern bulwark, building an archway, and laying a road for cars.

The convento behind the church opens to a vista of the Boac River and distant Laylay, where at a river mouth delta stands the ruins of an old watchtower. This unusual placement of the convento and its multiple passages may have been designed for defense; thus one can go from church to convento without being exposed. The convento itself is defensive. Instead of the regular plan using a wooden second floor, both floors are of stone and brick. A veranda surrounds the convento on two sides, perhaps as a passageway for lookouts. Below the convento is an empty hall identified by tradition as a cuadra or stable.

In 1953, Saint Mary’s Academy opened in Boac. The Religious of the Virgin Mary, RVM, who run the school, were given use of the convento. Meanwhile a new convento was built within the fortification in front and to the right of the church, near the north gate and the shrine to the Inmaculada known as “Biglang Awa,” because of her defense of the people from slave raiders. On 2 Apr 1977, the diocese of Boac was created and on 10 May 1978 canonically erected. The church was elevated to a cathedral and the new convento used as the bishop’s residence. In the 1990s, the RVM school, now a college, constructed new buildings in the outlying areas of Boac and abandoned the convento for the new buildings. The old convento was repaired and refurbished.

The fortification’s interior has been landscaped; trees and palms planted, a gazebo built. In the fortification is a memorial to Diego de Saura, erected in memory of a Jesuit priest and native of Menorca who served Boac in the 1630s. In 1979, a delegation of 120 pilgrims from Menorca, headed by Spanish king Juan Carlos, visited Boac. The memorial to Fr de Saura was built for this occasion.

In the 1980s, Boac church was renovated under the sponsorship of Carmencita O. Reyes, who was governor until 2007 of Marinduque Province and also congressional representative. Interventions on the building fabric include removing the lime palitada (primer) that covered the church and exposed the stone and brick structural members. The windows, which formerly were found only at the upper register of the nave with the lower half of the nave a solid wall, were lengthened to allow more light into the church. This meant breaching the lower half of the nave wall, thereby changing the defensive character of the fabric. The interior plaster was clad with a veneer of brick tiles. New wrought iron chandeliers were added and the ceiling remodeled. The two side retablos were moved to the sanctuary from their former site along the nave. A new altar and other sanctuary furniture were added. The main door of the church, which was plain and unadorned, was replaced by a door carved with reliefs of the four evangelists. It was made in Paete, Laguna in 1984.

Boac was declared a National Historical Landmark by the National Historical Commission in 1972.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Source

Javellana, René B. 1991. Wood and Stone for God’s Greater Glory: Jesuit Art and Architecture in the Philippines. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

photos.desc:
Church of Nuestra Señora del Patrocinio de Maria in Boljoon, Cebu, 2009

(National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Nuestra Señora del Patrocinio. Location: Boljoon, Cebu. Begun 1783.

Formerly a visita (mission chapel) of Carcar, the parish was said to have been founded simultaneously with the town after Boljoon was made capital of the second vicariate south of Cebu in 1692. Fr Nicolas de la Cuarda, OSA was Boljoon’s first prior. For lack of priests, the parish was turned over to the Jesuits in 1737; it was returned to the Augustinians in 1747. The first buildings were probably ruined during the frequent Muslim raids in the 18th century, particularly in 1782. The present church was begun by Fr Ambrosio Otero and finished by Fr Julian Bermejo, who enclosed the complex within stone walls. Inscribed dates, like 1789 above the south wing door; 1801, above the main entrance door; and 1829, above the side door near the belfry may indicate several suspensions of work, renovation, and expansion. Both church and convento were restored by Fr Leandro Moran, OSA, Boljoon’s last Augustinian prior, 1920-48.

 

The stone church measures 65 m long, 12 m wide, and 12 m high. The classical facade is accentuated with floral and geometric rococo motifs on the panels and pilasters. It consists of three levels, including a large triangular pediment. Its only openings are the arched main door on the ground level and the two arched windows on the second level. These windows are on either side of a niche housing the statue of Nuestra Señora de Patrocinio.

To the right of the church is a two-level belfry attached by a gable-roofed baptistry to the main structure. The other bell tower, holding more bells of various sizes and now facing the municipal hall building, was once used as a watchtower or blockhouse. Massive and rectangular, this used to be connected to a large house at its north wall; the house deteriorated, leaving only few stone remnants.

The church interior has a single nave and transept. Wooden tracery adorns its pulpit and choir loft. The hexagonal pulpit, five panels of which are missing, has an elaborately designed crown. Still in the choir loft is the old organ installed in 1880. Other highlights include an outstanding gilded main retablo which has five niches on the first level, three on the second, and one on the third; two minor gilded altars at the transept similarly decorated with gold leaf; and the vaulted ceiling painted with biblical scenes.

To the right of the church is the L-shaped convento. The church can be entered through the convento’s ground floor; a door opens to the church at the south wall. A grand old staircase from the basement leads upstairs to the spacious main sala overlooking the sea. The sala is only half of the horizontal section of the convento. The other half consists of larger rooms. A volada (gallery) linking the sala to the dirty kitchen protects the storage rooms and chambers of the parish priest and his assistant from sun and rain. In addition to the kitchen and bathroom, these rooms occupy the vertical section of the convento.

In the 1990s, the ground floor was turned into a garage, bodegas, and pens for domesticated animals. The ground floor windows are narrow and protected by semicircular wooden balustrades. There are two doors of hardwood and wrought iron, with metal locks; a semicircular door faces east, and a flat and wider door faces south. Persiana or louver shutters encircle the entire second floor. Rather than ventanillas or sliding shutters beneath the window and translucent transoms as in a typical bahay na bato (stone house), static and plain wooden panels are used. The convento’s steep roof is made of tiles,

On the Epistle side of the church is a cemetery, entered through a lintel and post gate with a relief of death as a skeleton holding a scythe and hourglass. Beside the convento is the two-story Escuela Catolica built in 1940 and designed by Fr Leonardo Moran. Similar to the bahay na bato, the lower story is cement and the upper story is of wood. The school has a pitched roof of galvanized iron. A double flight of cement stairs, believed to be a way to separate girls and boys, leads to the second story. The stairs end in a landing with wood filigree cutout in the style of Victorian houses.

Boljoon church was designated a National Historical Landmark by the National Historical Institute (NHI) on 25 Jun 2000.

Because of this declaration restoration of the complex and cleaning of the area was done. The once dirty ground floor has been cleaned and part of the zaguan converted to the parish museum of Boljoon. The museum displays church artifacts and precolonial and early colonial gold artifacts, metal tools, pottery and tradeware unearthed during a 2007 archaeological survey of the church plaza.

The church and bell tower underwent consolidation and a new layer of palitada or plastering was applied in 2007 under the supervision of NHI. These recent interventions may have saved Boljoon from damage during the 15 Oct 2013 earthquake. The structure suffered surface cracks but remained structurally sound.  Written by Paul Labrado and Monica P. Consing, with notes from René B. Javellana and Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Bersales, Jose Eleazar R., ed. 2010. Balaanong Bahandi: Sacred Treasures of the Archdiocese of Cebu. Cebu: The Cathedral Museum of Cebu and University of San Carlos Press.

Greschwiler, Paul. 2009. Bolhoon: A Cultural Sketch. Cebu: Boljoon Heritage Foundation Inc.

Redondo, Felipe Sendino. 1886. Breve Reseña de lo que fue y lo que es la Diocesis de Cebu en las Islas Filipinas. Manila: Establecimieto Tipografico del Colegio de Sto. Tomás.

photos.desc:
American-period Bradford Memorial Church in Cebu City

(Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos)

Bradford Memorial Church, ca 1913-24, Cebu City

(Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos)

text:
Protestant Church, formerly Presbyterian; presently United Church of Christ. Location: Jones Ave (now Osmeña Blvd), Cebu City. Built 1913.

 

Protestantism arrived in Cebu in 1900 at the heels of the occupying American troops that accepted the surrender of the Cebuano Katipunero on 23 Feb 1899. A pioneer missionary, G.C. Bartter of the Foreign Bible Society, came to Cebu in 1900 to sell Spanish Bibles and tracts of Mark’s Gospel in the vernacular. But when Dr and Mrs Graham acquired a piece of land belonging to the Banilad Estate, formerly owned by the Augustinians, the Presbyterians settled permanently in Cebu and symbolized this by building a church, Fuente Osmeña Evangelical Church, forerunner of Bradford. After the establishment of the Cebu Presbytery in 1908, churches in Opon, Compostela, Dumanjug, and three other municipalities were established.

In 1912, with donations from generous benefactors, three structures were built in Cebu City: a boys’s and girls’s dormitory, Sneed and Emerson respectively, and a third structure, the Bradford Memorial Church. This last was named after Matilda L. Bradford, the mother of Dorothy H. Day, its donor. Although it had been used since Apr 1913 after its completion, the church was not formally dedicated until 26 Oct of that year.

By 1971 a growing congregation had outstripped the capacity of the 1913 church and a new church was constructed. The old church was used as a schoolroom. Plans to demolish the old church were halted when, through the initiative of members of the church council, old Bradford was declared a National Historical Landmark by the National Historical Institute in 1984, being the oldest Protestant church in Cebu. article.value: Protestantism arrived in Cebu in 1900 at the heels of the occupying American troops that accepted the surrender of the Cebuano Katipunero on 23 Feb 1899. A pioneer missionary, G.C. Bartter of the Foreign Bible Society, came to Cebu in 1900 to sell Spanish Bibles and tracts of Mark’s Gospel in the vernacular. But when Dr and Mrs Graham acquired a piece of land belonging to the Banilad Estate, formerly owned by the Augustinians, the Presbyterians settled permanently in Cebu and symbolized this by building a church, Fuente Osmeña Evangelical Church, forerunner of Bradford. After the establishment of the Cebu Presbytery in 1908, churches in Opon, Compostela, Dumanjug, and three other municipalities were established.

In 1912, with donations from generous benefactors, three structures were built in Cebu City: a boys’s and girls’s dormitory, Sneed and Emerson respectively, and a third structure, the Bradford Memorial Church. This last was named after Matilda L. Bradford, the mother of Dorothy H. Day, its donor.
