text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Vicente Ferrer. Location: Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. Built 1774-1782; tower, 1775-1788; convento, 1778, with major additions in 1846. Repaired in 1990 and after.

Dupax was organized in 1727 as a visita or mission chapel of Bujay, under the patronage of Nuestra Señora del Socorro (Our Lady of Succor). Bujay was the center of a mission territory called Ituy, roughly the southern part of what is now the province of Nueva Vizcaya. Ituy had been evangelized by the Augustinians since 1717, although earlier attempts had been made by the Franciscans and Dominicans in the early 1600s. The dwellers of Ituy were known by various names. Their Gaddang and Ifugao neighbors in Paniqui (northern Nueva Vizcaya, not the town in Tarlac) called them Malaat. The Pampango further south knew them as Isinay. But they called themselves Immeas or Inmeas. A shy people, they remember stories by their ancestors of how they were pushed from lands further north by more aggressive communities. The name Dupax is said to have been taken from the word dopaj, with the archaic Spanish “x” corresponding to the “h” of the local language, which meant “lying down in rest, with face up and legs extended.”

 

The region was turned over in 1740 to the Dominicans, who accepted the four missions of Bujay (now Aritao), Dupax, Bambang, and Bayombong. The first three quasi-towns comprised the Ituy Mission; the last constituted the center of the Paniqui Mission. By this time the people of Dupax were living in 150 nipa houses, surrounded by fruit trees and irrigated rice fields. The chapel of wood and light materials was repaired and improved with hardwood posts and boards. The Dominican saint Vicente Ferrer was made the new patron of Dupax.

This wooden chapel burned down in 1755 and again in 1766. The extant Book of Baptisms thus begins in 1767. The town was briefly linked to the national destiny as a result of the British Invasion of Manila in 1762. To prevent the silver subsidy from Acapulco from falling into enemy hands, the precious cargo was smuggled from its landing in Batangas to the mountains of Tayabas and then to Dupax before it finally reached the headquarters of the government-in-exile of Simon de Anda in Bacolor, Pampanga. Despite the two fires, the surreptitious relay of treasure, and an epidemic besides, Fr Cristobal Rodriguez OP, 1753-69, the parish priest during these stressful times, also introduced the cultivation of cacao. This brought so much income to the town that the Isinay could now pay taxes in silver where before they would offer an animal. In fact, the earnings from cacao helped raise the church and decorate it.

Masons and workers from Tuguegarao, whose grand church was raised in 1766, began the construction of the present church in 1774. It certainly helped that Tuguegarao’s builder, Fr Antonio Lobato, OP, had ministered in Bujay in his younger years, 1755-59, and thus was sympathetic to the project. Brick and lime were produced locally. Work proceeded so smoothly that the church could be used in two years’ time. A brick inset over the central doorway is marked “1776.” Work on the church building was completed in 1782. Brick insets on the four levels of the bell tower trace its construction: 1775, 1776, 1786, and 1788.

The first masonry church in the entire Ituy-Paniqui region was followed by similar ones in Aritao (begun 1780); Bambang (begun 1782, with the tower finished 1791); and Bayombong (church built ca 1773-92, with the tower completed around 1800). With Dupax, these three churches bear the obvious influence of Tuguegarao in the gracefully catenated silhouette of the pediment and in the brick insets adorning the walls, doors, and windows. A Dominican in the 1780s noted that this “construction boom” also inspired the building of churches in the Franciscan towns of Carranglan and Pantabangan in adjoining Nueva Ecija province.

The church is decorated with a number of unique artworks. A baked clay statuette of San Vicente Ferrer used to grace a niche on the bell tower’s ground level. Its head bore a strong affinity with the neolithic “portrait” jars found in Maitum, Saranggani Province in Mindanao. Sadly, this unique piece was stolen in 2006. Upon entering the church, one is confronted with a massive pair of carved sandstone pillars supporting the choir loft. Each pillar has a height of 13.3 ft, and a circumference of 10 ft. The carved decoration consists of clams, leaves, and vines, interspersed with tilted waffle-like medallions common in late 18th century Philippine art. To the left is the baptistry, wondrously filled with similar carving squeezed into a room measuring only 3.60 x 4.20 m. Instead of the standard retablo scene featuring St. John baptizing Christ, there is a curious figure of Christ seemingly waving a welcome to the baptismal party. The vaulted ceiling represents the Holy Spirit surrounded by rays of light, stars, and flowers.

The central and two side retablos seem to have been refashioned from surviving pieces with baroque elements. Other movable art pieces are safeguarded in the convento. Among these is an indigo blanket said to be of the type traded with the Ifugao for use as funeral shrouds.

The convento is said to have been finished in 1778. A tambobo or rice granary of stone was added to the convento in the first decades of the 19th century, while a reception hall protruding from the front of the convento went up in 1846. The tribunal (ancestor to today’s municipal building), cemetery, and two schools of brick and stone were also built by the Dominican missionaries. Fr. Antolin provided the populace with two orchards known as comunes, and is said to have introduced the cultivation of mongo, as evidenced by a patch which was called “Antolin.”

The buildings were damaged by the earthquake of 1990, but were repaired under the administration of Fr Paul Bollen, CICM (1976-97). The oldest masonry church in Nueva Vizcaya, Dupax is also the most intact, with its bell tower, convento, churchyard, and incomparable Immeas stone carvings remarkably well preserved after more than two hundred years. It was declared a National Cultural Treasure by the National Museum on 31 Jul 2001.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

text:
El Hogar Filipino also known as Edificio El Hogar. Location: 117 Juan Luna corner Muelle de la Industria, Escolta Zone, Binondo, Manila. Begun 1911. Architects: Ramon Irureta-Goyena and Francisco Perez Muñoz. Inaugurated on 14 Sep 1914.

El Hogar Building was designed and constructed by the engineers Irureta-Goyena and Perez Muñoz. It is in the Beaux-Arts style, combining neoclassical and Neo-Renaissance elements. One of the oldest American-era buildings, El Hogar is flanked by First National City Bank on the right and the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank behind it. It was given as a wedding gift by the Zobel family to Margarita Zobel de Ayala, who had married a Peruvian, Antonio Melian Pavia. Margarita was the sister of the Ayala patriarch, Don Enrique. Melian established the Filipinas Compañia de Seguros with brothers-in-law, Enrique and Fernando, which had its office in this building until it moved out when it acquired its own building at Plaza Moraga. The building also housed the Sociedad El Hogar Filipino, founded by Melian. El Hogar also housed the offices of Melian’s business empire, which included Tondo de Beneficiencia, Casa de España, and Casa de Pensiones. Other tenants were Ayala y Compañía, and Smith, Bell and Company, and Warner Barnes and Co, proprietor of Filipinas Cable Co.

 

The building was located on the northwest corner of Juan Luna St and Muelle de la Industria. Its northern front faced the Pacific Commercial Company, built in 1922. Its western front overlooked the Pasig River. The El Hogar was basically a three-floor structure, but it had a fourth floor on its northwest corner corresponding with the four bays on both the north and west front. The facade of the 1914 building had neoclassical features. Flat pilasters rising from plinths and reaching up to the second floor ended up in arches. The pilasters, flanked by geometricized colonnettes, articulated the bays. On top of the colonnettes were geometricized capitals from which rose the arches. Over the arches was the entablature topped by a cornice and crowned by the third story balustrade. The third story repeated the ornaments of the second floor. The windows on both the second and third stories were fitted with fanlights.

With the downturn of Escolta as Manila’s business district, El Hogar had less and less tenants and was but partially occupied. While awaiting restoration, the building transferred ownership. Remaining tenants of El Hogar were told to vacate the premises in early 2015 and a blue galvanized iron fence was built around its perimeter. Heritage conservation groups are concerned that El Hogar would be demolished to make way for a new building.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from René B. Javellana

Fort of Balangingi on Samal Island

(J. Espejo, 1848, Library of Congress Geography and Map Division)

text:
Balangingi Kuta Complex. Location: Samales Island Group, Sulu. Built late 18th or early 19th century.

A vital enclave of the Sama was the island of Balangingi, east of Jolo, after which the group was named. In the 18th century, the Sama were among the countless peoples slowly drawn into the complex economic web brought about by the British taste for Chinese tea. Very simply stated, slaves were needed for the rambling tea plantations in China, as well as for gathering seaweed and sea cucumber that could be traded with the Chinese. British merchants procured such slaves and goods through business agreements with the Sultan of Sulu, who in turn relied on his allies the Sama to supply him with these commodities. Slave raiding was more an economic than a religious activity, as clarified by Warren (2001, 24). The British even armed the slave raiders who attacked not only the Visayas, Mindanao, and other parts of the Philippines butmuch of insular Southeast Asia as well.

Spanish reconnaissance reports in 1845 describe the kuta complex in Balangingi. There were four forts: Balangingi in the northern part of the island, and Sipac, Sungap, and Bucotingol in the south. All were well protected by impassable mangrove swamps and water too shallow for anything but canoes and vintas. Only insiders knew when to take advantage of the tides in navigating through the narrow canals, escaping from danger, or luring the enemy into a sudden water-swell.

 

The fort at Sipac, the largest, was typical. Two to three lines of tree trunks 1½ to 2 ft in diameter were tightly lashed together to constitute meter-thick walls that in turn formed a roughly quadrangular palisaded fort. The spaces between the walls were filled with boulders, earth, and sand. The walls averaged 5 m in height. There were two levels for artillery. On the lower level, cannons peered out from truncated quadrangular pyramidal casemates, the smaller end facing the enemy. Emplaced on open-air batteries on the higher level were lighter arms such as lantaka (a type of culverin). Access to the kuta was impeded by small pozos de lobo (foxholes) and rows of finely sharpened bamboo sticks (Herbella 259-60). Inside the fort, women and children took shelter in trenches covered with mats.

On 13-25 Feb 1848 Gov-Gen Narciso Claveria himself led Spanish and Filipino forces in ending Balangingi slave-raiding. The four forts were burned to the ground, along with 8,000 coconut trees. Also, of the Balangingi, 450 were killed; 150 women and children were taken captive by the Spaniards; and 200 captive slaves from Indonesia and the Philippines were released. Hundreds of pieces of artillery were taken; among these, three fine lantaka and a flag from Sipac are now in the Army Museum in Toledo, Spain.

Most of the Balangingi captives were eventually shipped to forge new lives in tobacco plantations in faraway Isabela, Cagayan Valley. Many even assisted the local Yogad people in building the church in Camarag (now Echague). Stragglers in Balangingi reestablished themselves in Taluksangay, Zamboanga City, by the early 1900s. Unfortunately, their refuge was once more destroyed during a siege begun by separatists on 9 Sep 2013.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

Inner plaza of Fort Pilar, Zamboanga City, 2009

(Eldon Tenorio)

Shrine of Nuestra Señora del Pilar at Fort Pilar, 2009

(National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)

text:
Fuerza de Nuestra Señora del Pilar de Zaragoza. Location: Zamboanga City. Built 1635, rebuilt 1719. Architects: Melchor de Vera, SJ, Juan de Ciscara.

Fort Pilar was the southernmost fort built by the Spaniards in the Philippines. The Jesuits, who had been actively evangelizing the Zamboanga coast from their residence in Dapitan, were convinced that the only way to stop marauding bands of slave raiders was to establish a military garrison on Mindanao’s southern tip. So they prevailed upon acting Gov-Gen Juan Cerezo de Salamanca to create a presidio (garrison) of about 300 men composed of Spaniards and Pampango. In 1635 the Jesuit Melchor de Vera built a fort dedicated to San Jose. From this fortress the Jesuits went out to evangelize the Lutao (Badjao), a seafaring tribe who were vassals of the Jolo sultanate. In 1663, when Spanish troops were recalled to Manila to prepare for an impending attack by the Chinese corsair Koxinga, the Spaniards abandoned Zamboanga and the Jesuits left with them. The fort was ordered demolished to prevent it from falling into enemy hands. The Christianized Lutao were placed under the care of the Jesuits in Dapitan who came to visit them occasionally, while others left with the Jesuits and settled elsewhere in the Visayas.

 

In 1666 the Jesuit Provincial Luis Pimentel began to appeal to the government to reopen the fort; it was not until 1715 that the Jesuits prevailed upon the government to reopen the Zamboanga garrison, against all the objections in Manila. From 1718 to 1768, the Jesuits returned and worked in Zamboanga. The fort was rebuilt in 1719 by Juan de Ciscara, probably hewing close to de Vera’s plans. The fort was renamed in honor of Nuestra Señora del Pilar de Zaragosa and its four bulwarks were named San Felipe, San Fernando, San Luis, and San Francisco Javier. In 1720 the rebuilt fort withstood Dulasi’s attack. In 1794 Gov Juan de la Torre had a new gate built for the fort, and the image of the Virgen del Pilar was placed above the main entrance. Fort Pilar was renovated and improved during the late 19th century. New barracks, a kitchen, and a gunpowder room were added to the structure. The American General J. C. Bates, who was sent to Zamboanga, occupied the fort in 1899. It was seized by the Japanese during World War II in 1942.

 

The fort underwent restoration by the National Museum. A restored building now houses a Marine Museum, opened in Oct 1987. The main gate over which is the image of the Virgin has been converted to a shrine for devotees of this reputedly miraculous image.

It is unknown if anything remains from de Vera’s fort although de la Costa (1961) asserts that the wall containing the venerated image of Nuestra Señora del Pilar goes back to the 17th century. The famous Philippine map of Murillo Velarde, 1734, shows, among its marginal vignettes, the location and shape of the 1719 fort—a quadrilateral structure with three quadrilateral bulwarks and a fourth one facing the sea in the shape of an ace of spades. Six of seven cannons are mounted on the bulwarks. Inside the fort are barracks, a warehouse, a well, and a chapel. Outside the fort—in another fortified area protected by a wall, palisade, and moat—are the Jesuit church and college, the residence of the governor, a hospital, and a number of houses. These structures appear to be covered with nipa. Outside the fort is the community of the Lutao. Nothing now remains of the structures outside Fort Pilar. Presumably these were perishable structures for the report of 1779 says that the church in Zamboanga was made of wood. Before World War II, this site outside was occupied by the Pettit Barracks, a camp for American soldiers. The area is known as Santa Barbara, the saint after whom a bastion at this site was named.

The Shrine to Nuestra Señora del Pilar, consisting of the fort’s former main gate and the area immediately outside the northeast walls and bastions of the fort, defined by Lustre and N.S. Valderosa Sts, was renovated recently to become more Catholic. Enclosed with a fence, statues of saints and Stations of the Cross were added. An elevated platform with cement altar was raised. In the past, the Shrine attracted Catholics, Chinese, and Muslims of various ethnicities. It was an opportunity for interreligious dialogue, which was lost with the new additions of Catholic saints. With the resurgence of Islam in southern Mindanao and the rise of Muslim groups that are more rigid, the presence of statuary (forbidden by the Bible’s Old Testament and the Quran) is a deterrent to the Muslim visitors who used to come to this shrine of Mary, considered as saint and a religious figure in Islam.

For many years the south and southwest flanks of the fort were derelict—a garbage dump. But with the construction of Paseo del Mar, a well-lighted and spacious public park, an unnamed perimeter road was built around the fort linking it to Lustre and N. S. Valderosa Sts. The grounds outside the wall have been cleaned and cleared of vegetation; the fort walls scrubbed clean and lighted monumentally. In the evenings, the walls of Fort Pilar have become a visual attraction best viewed from the Paseo del Mar.

Fort Pilar was recognized as a National Cultural Treasure through Presidential Decree No 260 of 1 Aug 1976.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Sources

 

De la Costa, Horacio. 1961. The Jesuits in the Philippines: 1581-1768. Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press.

photos.desc:
Castillo de San Vicente Ferrer in Maribojoc, Bohol, 2016

(Photo by Claire Jabines, Bohol Provincial Tourism Office)

text:
Castillo de San Vicente Ferrer. Location: Punta Cruz, Maribojoc, Bohol. Fortin or small fort. Built 1796 by Recollects.

Oral tradition claims that Punta Cruz in Maribojoc, Bohol was the landfall of the two Jesuit pioneers sent to Bohol, Juan de Torres and Gabriel Sanchez, in Nov 1596. To mark this event, a wooden cross was raised by the Jesuits at the shore facing the sea, as was customary. A cement cross has been raised at the spot where it is claimed the Jesuits planted the wooden cross.

An inscription above the arched entrance to the fortin reads: “Castillo De S Vicente Ferrer en esta Punta de la Cruz q hor[ti]culo y Arbol de la Santa Cruz desde de la Conquista de los Espaoles Hasta Hoy y se Venera en su Pueblo de Maribohoc con Devocion del Santo Via Crucis Ao 1796.” The inscription asserts three things: the name of the structure, the date of construction and the facts about the site Punta Cruz, which the inscription says poetically is the source and beginning of the devotion to the Sacred Cross.

 

Although Punta Cruz was the first landing of the Jesuits, de Torres and Sanchez evangelized Baclayon and Loboc first. Baclayon, then Loboc, became the center or residencia of the Jesuit mission to Bohol. Maribojoc, where Punta Cruz is located, was under Baclayon remaining its visita (mission chapel) until 1767, when it was made an independent parish but by mid-1768, the Jesuits were expelled from the Philippines and the Recollects took charge of Bohol.

The Castillo de San Vicente Ferrer was built by the Recollects to stand guard along the seashore. With other towers and defense structure like fortified churches, it protected the southwestern perimeter of Bohol and area facing the Cebu Strait and the Bohol Sea. This system of defense complemented the one built by the Augustinians in southeastern Cebu.

Southwestern Bohol’s complement of fortifications consisted of the following: fortified churches—Loon, Maribojoc, Cortes, Tagbilaran, Dauis, Baclayon, and Loboc; watchtowers: Cabalian Island, Punta Cruz, Dauis, Panglao, Villalimpia at Loay, and Pamilacan.

The castillo’s triangular fort, has a roofed second story designed as a hexagon. The apex of the isosceles triangular first floor faces seaward, while the base inland. The entrance to the fortin is through an arched doorway of stone facing inland. The first floor raised about 1.5 m from the ground is approached through stone steps. Small windows flank the main entrance. Larger windows are placed on the sides of the triangle and niches are built into the corners. One corner opens to a stone staircase leading to the upper story.

This hexagonal second story has larger openings: three are lookouts, and three corresponding to the apex of the lower triangle, lead to a parapet. The windows above and below open to the Bohol Sea, and on a clear day Siquijor island and southeast Cebu are visible. The fortin’s door and windows may have been shuttered with hardwood panels but has since been destroyed and removed.

The fortin was in relatively good condition but consolidation of the upper floor was necessary because the molave timber supporting the lime floor was rotting and the roof needed repair.

On 15 Oct 2013, at 8:15 am, Bohol was hit by a 7.2 earthquake on the Richter scale, emanating from the North Bohol Fault, a hitherto unknown fault near Inabanga. A branch of the fault reached Maribojoc where it caused an uplift that added some 500 m of shoreline along the beach. During this earthquake the upper story of the fortin collapsed. Its roof fell into the structure and the walls crumbled. The inscription above the main door was damaged. The fortin is restored. It was given a historical marker in 2008.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Sources

Diaz-Trechuelo, Lourdes. 1959. Arquitectura Española en Filipinas (1565-1800). Sevilla: Escuela de Estudios Hispano-Americanos de Sevilla.

Javellana, René B., and Jose Ma. Lorenzo Tan. 1997. Fortress of Empire: Spanish Colonial Fortifications of the Philippines 1565-1898. Makati City: Bookmark, Inc.

Tamon, Fernando Valdes. (1738) 1995. “Relacion” translated as Report in Which, By Order of His Catholic Majesty … the Strongholds, Castles, Forts and Garrisons of the Provinces Under His Royal Protection in the Philippine Islands Are Listed. 1995 ed. Spain: Santander Investment.

photos.desc:
Fort San Andres and Santiago in Romblon, 2004

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Fuerza de San Andres and Fuerza de Santiago. Location: Romblon, Romblon. Construction: 1640-50. Architect: Agustin de San Pedro, OAR, aka “El Padre Capitán.”

The Recollects, the last of the five religious orders to arrive in the Philippines during the first era of evangelization (late 16th to early 17th centuries), were intrepid builders of fortifications in some of the remotest and inaccessible islands of the Philippines. The location of these forts was due in part to the late arrival of the Recollects. By then the archipelago had been divided among the four orders that had come earlier, and the Recollects had to content themselves with areas neglected or on the fringe of the bigger provinces.

In 1635, Romblon was turned over to the Recollects. The first missionary sent was Pedro de San Jose. That year, a church was built. After a Moro raid, Fray Pedro sought assistance of “El Padre Capitán” who was reported to have built two forts in Romblon. A legendary figure of this time, Fray Agustin was known for his military exploits, particularly in Mindanao where with the assistance of an army of Manobo warriors he kept the expansionist Maguindanao Sultanates at bay. He also built a fort in the hinterlands of Agusan, naming it San Jose.

 

From 1640 to 1650, El Padre Capitán built forts San Andres and Santiago using coral, stone, and rubble. These forts were located on hills opposite each other flanking the poblacion. Their strategic location gave sentinels a panoramic view of the poblacion, laid out between the two hills and the bay between the hills, the only approach to Romblon.

By 1738, the poblacion was fortified. Effectively it had three forts, which included the town’s defensive wall, which had three bastions: the central which served as entrance and a pair of collateral bastions built against the base of the hills.

Fortifying the islands of Romblon was important, as the island proved to be a strategic point for guarding the Tablas Strait, then and even today, a passage from the south to Manila. This was a route the galleon would take when it traveled from the coast of Samar north toward Manila Bay. It was also used by slave raiders sailing north. So the defense of Romblon town and the strait was crucial for commerce and for the safety of the coastal area.

Fort San Andres is a quadrilateral fort with rounded bastions at the corners. Loopholes along the wall allow for the use of armament. For a long time it was in poor condition, the northern portion had collapsed and the walls were greatly degraded. Although some of the vegetation outside the curtain wall has been cleared, the structure in general is badly preserved.

The provincial government has initiated clearing the site and removing vegetation that covers the fort from view. It is possible that Santiago is not a fully developed fort but a gun emplacement and a lookout to complement Fort San Andres. From the ruins is a clear view of the church bell tower below, which suggests that the fort served as a warning system in conjunction with the tower.

article.value: Fuerza de San Andres and Fuerza de Santiago. Location: Romblon, Romblon. Construction: 1640-50. Architect: Agustin de San Pedro, OAR, aka “El Padre Capitán.”

The Recollects, the last of the five religious orders to arrive in the Philippines during the first era of evangelization (late 16th to early 17th centuries), were intrepid builders of fortifications in some of the remotest and inaccessible islands of the Philippines. The location of these forts was due in part to the late arrival of the Recollects. By then the archipelago had been divided among the four orders that had come earlier, and the Recollects had to content themselves with areas neglected or on the fringe of the bigger provinces.

In 1635, Romblon was turned over to the Recollects. The first missionary sent was Pedro de San Jose. That year, a church was built. After a Moro raid, Fray Pedro sought assistance of “El Padre Capitán” who was reported to have built two forts in Romblon. A legendary figure of this time, Fray Agustin was known for his military exploits, particularly in Mindanao where with the assistance of an army of Manobo warriors he kept the expansionist Maguindanao Sultanates at bay. He also built a fort in the hinterlands of Agusan, naming it San Jose.

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

article.value: From 1640 to 1650, El Padre Capitán built forts San Andres and Santiago using coral, stone, and rubble. These forts were located on hills opposite each other flanking the poblacion. Their strategic location gave sentinels a panoramic view of the poblacion, laid out between the two hills and the bay between the hills, the only approach to Romblon.

By 1738, the poblacion was fortified. Effectively it had three forts, which included the town’s defensive wall, which had three bastions: the central which served as entrance and a pair of collateral bastions built against the base of the hills.

This was a route the galleon would take when it traveled from the coast of Samar north toward Manila Bay. It was also used by slave raiders sailing north. So the defense of Romblon town and the strait was crucial for commerce and for the safety of the coastal area.

Fort San Antonio Abad in Manila, captured by US troops, 1898

(San Diego Air and Space Museum, John Tewell Collection)

Gate and walls of Fort San Antonio Abad in Manila, 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
Fuerza de San Antonio Abad also known as Polverin. Location: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Complex, Malate, Manila. Built 1764.

The fort has it origins in 1584, when a structure was built to guard the route between Cavite and Manila, and as a rear guard for the city. The fort was used as gunpowder storage or polverin when it was deemed that the polverin near the Bastion de San Diego in Intramuros posed danger should its content be inadvertently ignited. The British occupied the fort in 1762 and used it in the assault against Manila.

After the British occupation, 1762-64, this polverin outside Manila and south of Intramuros was renovated and renamed San Antonio Abad, after a saintly hermit of ancient times who started the monastic movement in the church.

 

As an outer defense of the walled city of Intramuros, the fort proved useless under American attack and it was on its walls that the Stars and Stripes were first hoisted on 13 Aug 1898. Photographs from this era show that the fort had been damaged by bombardment during the Battle of Manila Bay.

During World War II the Japanese built a cement bunker to the eastern side of the fort and mounted a canon on it. The fort and the land surrounding it were given to the navy until it was turned over to the Central Bank for its headquarters.

This triangular fort with two bastions was restored, with the construction in the 1970s of a new Central Bank Complex along Roxas Blvd. A third bastion was not rebuilt nor the quarters for the gatekeeper and guards immediately after the main gate, which faces north. An earthquake damaged this building in 1863. Photographs from the 1890s do not show any evidence of a building, which may have been pulled down and never rebuilt. Above the only gate to the fort is Spain’s coat of arms.

 

The fort, located between the Central Bank building and the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, serves as a venue for receptions sponsored by the Central Bank or the museum. A wooden image of the fort’s patron San Antonio is found in a niche along the rear wall.  Written by René B. Javellana

(CCP Collection)

text:
Location: Cavite City. Fuerza de San Felipe, 1609, expanded 1628, rebuilding and remodeling 1636, 1650, 18th century. Builder: Military.

As early as 1591, Gov Gómez Pérez Dasmariñas recognized the strategic importance of Cavite as the entrance to the city and moved toward its fortification. It was, in fact, at this isthmus, two decades earlier, that Miguel Lopez de Legazpi hid his ships prior to the attack on Manila. The king ordered the construction of a fort but, for lack of funds and personnel, it was planned on a small scale. Work began in 1609 and continued to the following year. Storerooms for artillery and fittings of the galleons were kept in the fort. In 1628, news of the impending attack by the Dutch compelled Gov-Gen Juan Niño de Tabora to call a council of war that decided to build a bigger fort with four cavaliers and embankments, enough for a contingent of 200. The fort was constructed of stone near the beach so that one side jutted out to the docks.On the opposite side, a redoubt was built, and connected to the fort by a palisade and a covered walkway to defend the landward side of the fort. Beside the redoubt, Gov-Gen de Tavora built an earth esplanade facing the entrance of the port and equipped it with cannons.

 

Then followed decades when improvements on Cavite’s fortifications drained the royal coffers, as there was no one competent in military architecture. For instance, a bastion was built in 1636 but had to be reinforced in 1650 because it was badly made. Gov-Gen Diego Fajardo had to order the construction of a palisade surrounding the fort as it was in a bad state, but he could not commit funds for construction. In 1659, a royal decree ordered a full report on the fortification of Manila and Gov-Gen Sabiniano Manrique de Lara complied in a report of 19 Jun. This is the first documentary report, which gives a full description of the fortification. The report states that San Felipe was built between 1609-16, under Gov-Gen Juan de Silva. It was quadrilateral in form, with four corner bastions, and had a perimeter of 220 ft. It was built to face the Cavite port and Manila. Furthermore, a cube or platform named Santa Catalina Martyr, large enough for 10 cannons, was nearby. At the most narrow part of this isthmus was an 80-foot wide moat separating the burgeoning town of Cavite. Protecting the moat were two 30-foot round platforms with a diameter of 80 ft, connected by a curtain wall 30 ft high and 8 ft thick. Between the wall and the moat was a barbican 30 ft wide.The northern platform was named Nuestra Señora de la Concepción and the opposite Nuestra Señora del Rosario. From the Concepción ran a span of wall 247 ft long and one fathom tall and reached the church of the Jesuits. In between the Concepción and the church was another platform. Facing San Felipe were the ruins of the Casa Real which had another low platform for eight cannons. However, it was in a bad state and had to be repaired. The wall continued for a total of 4,230 ft, enclosing the town and the churches and convents of San Francisco, Santo Domingo, the Jesuit church of Loreto, and the Recollect church of San Nicolas.

Manrique de Lara’s report was forwarded to Spain where the opinion of the Dutchman Ricardo Carr was sought. Although he was Spain’s prisoner and incarcerated in Madrid, he was knowledgeable about Cavite. Carr’s plans were scrutinized by others, namely, Juan de Somovilla, Fuentes Cortes, and Juan de Pereña. Neither the plans of Carr nor of Somovilla were fully implemented; rather, elements from the plans were realized as resources allowed. Manrique de Lara reported in Aug 1663 that a cavalier with a capacity of 10 canons was built above the gate of San Felipe. The platform of Santa Catalina was completed. Ninety-one feet from the Concepcion platform, another platform 40 ft in diameter, named San Sabiniano, had been constructed and between this and the Santa Catalina a wooden platform was raised completing the fortification of the northern flank. At the shore and 222 ft from San Felipe, another stone platform was completed, and still another one but of wood, named San Jose. The area was enclosed by a palisade, revellins, and covered walkways. A moat completed the defenses of Cavite Puerto and San Felipe. But all these works needed the demolition of four churches.

Manrique de Lara’s successor, Gabriel de Curuzelaegui, ordered an inspection of the fortifications and noted what needed to be repaired, in particular the ruined living quarters of San Felipe. Furthermore, the sea was advancing and flooding the port, making it necessary to build a breakwater of wooden trunks. The sea would always remain a problem for the next century to come. Cavite Puerto was built on a low sandbar, whose unstable substrate was subject to the action of wind and wave. Military engineers would have to contend with this environment.

On 5 Oct 1687, an earthquake destroyed the royal warehouse, the docks, and the living quarters of San Felipe. When Gov-Gen Fausto Cruzat y Góngora assumed office, he ordered the gathering of material for the necessary works in Cavite and further ordered in 1695 a report on the status of Cavite.The report emphasized the destructive nature of the sea and sought to contain it. In Cruzat y Góngora’s time, a granary called tambobo de arroz had been raised in San Felipe, as well as a vaulted chamber for gunpowder. At the Nuestra Señora del Rosario, a new tower of stone and brick was built. Other works were done, but the governor-general emphasized the importance of finding more permanent and less costly solutions to contain the advance of the sea.

The encroaching sea remained a major problem.This was the period when the government could avail of the expertise of military engineers and architects who had come from Europe, namely Juan de Ciscara, Miguel Antonio Gomez, Tómas de Castro y Andrade, and the Theatine priest Juan de Uguccioni, who had rebuilt the Manila cathedral in 1711. This was a period of rapid and effective construction. Ciscara completed his work in Cavite in 1710. During the interim in 1745 when, Francisco de la Arechederra, bishop of Vigan, assumed governorship, the threat of attack by the British was in the air, so the covered walkway between Puerta Vaga and the Baluarte de San Juan were repaired. The bishop also added another baluarte (fort).

The British’s successful possession of Manila from 1762 to 1764 called for better fortifications in Cavite. The sea continued its erosion of the sandbar. Castro was called to offer his expertise and, in 1765, made a report regarding the ruinous state of the northern flank of the port, and the poor condition of the antiquated fortification San Felipe. Under Gov-Gen Jose Razon, the engineer Feliciano Marquez made another set of recommendations and plans submitted in 1766. The Marquez plan involved the total demolition of San Felipe and the construction of an irregular-shaped bastioned fort at the tip of the peninsula separated from Puerto by a moat. The plan was never executed.

When Gov-Gen Jose Basco y Vargas assumed office, he had plans made by the engineer Tomás Sanz, who submitted a report dated 16 Dec 1778. The report stated the danger posed by rising groundwater because of the close proximity of structures to the sea, as had been the problem for decades. It continued to show the most rapid deterioration of structures. Like previous plans, Sanz’s recommendations, although thorough, were not fully implemented. To make matters worse, a typhoon hit Cavite, destroying practically all the wall surrounding the northern part of the fortification. All told, as the century dragged to a close, work on Cavite’s fortifications was dismal. Lack of decision, lack of funds, compromise, and plain bureaucratic dillydallying resulted in an enormous waste of time making recommendations and proposing projects that, by and large, were not implemented.

By the 19th century, Cavite lost its prominence with the demise of the galleon trade in 1815 and the cutting of economic ties with Mexico in 1819 when the last of the situado (silver subsidy) arrived from Mexico. In the 19th century, Spain built other ports of call, like San Esteban in the Ilocos, Sual in Pangasinan, Iloilo and Cebu in the Visayas, and Zamboanga in Mindanao. With the opening of trade to other nations in 1848, Spain set the Philippines on a new course of commerce. Trading houses opened in the Chinese enclave of Binondo. Here British and Americans established trading houses. Improvement in transportation also meant shorter travel time and heavier traffic in sea going vessels. The banks of the Pasig along Binondo developed as a docking area.

In 1872, the workers in the naval base of Cavite rose up in revolt. The revolt was quickly quelled but blame was put on local leaders and the priests Jose Burgos, Mariano Gomez, and Jacinto Zamora as the instigators of the uprising. Among those arrested, some were executed at Bagumbayan, while others who were judged to be less culpable were exiled. But the execution of the 13 martyrs of Cavite and of the three priests collectively known as Gomburza, who were perceived as innocent and whom the archbishop of Manila refused to defrock amidst all the pressure put on him, planted the seed of revolt which was to flower in the 1896 Revolution against Spain. Cavite province played a key role in the revolution because it was in Kawit, across the bay from Cavite Puerto, that Gen Emilio Aguinaldo declared Philippine independence on 12 Jun 1898.

The revolution against Spain was quickly aborted. Using the Spanish-American War as an excuse, the United States sent a flotilla of warships to Manila to besiege it. The defeat of the Spanish navy in Manila Bay proved to be the beginning of a new era of colonization. The United States laid claim on the Philippines by virtue of the Treaty of Paris (10 Dec 1898). Spain ceded the Philippines to the United States. But the Filipinos fought for their independence from 1899 to 1907. Assuming sovereignty over the Philippine Islands, the US military took over Fort San Felipe and the neighboring fortified town of Cavite Puerto.

The fort was planned as an irregular quadrilateral and has four bastions with orillons at each corner. Various maps (e.g., 1639, 1738) represent the fort’s bastions as having orillons; however, remaining physical evidence indicates that the fort’s bastions were of the more advanced, straight-wall type rather than the more traditional ace-of-spades layout.

Today, only the facade and main entrance with flanking curtain walls and two bastions remain. The rest of the fort was demolished by the Americans during the early 20th century to make way for a naval station.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Source

Diaz-Trechuelo, Lourdes. 1959. Arquitectura Española en Filipinas (1565-1800). Sevilla: Escuela de Estudios Hispano-Americanos de Sevilla.

Among those arrested, some were executed at Bagumbayan, while others who were judged to be less culpable were exiled. But the execution of the 13 martyrs of Cavite and of the three priests collectively known as Gomburza, who were perceived as innocent and whom the archbishop of Manila refused to defrock amidst all the pressure put on him, planted the seed of revolt which was to flower in the 1896 Revolution against Spain. Cavite province played a key role in the revolution because it was in Kawit, across the bay from Cavite Puerto, that Gen Emilio Aguinaldo declared Philippine independence on 12 Jun 1898.

The revolution against Spain was quickly aborted. Using the Spanish-American War as an excuse, the United States sent a flotilla of warships to Manila to besiege it. The defeat of the Spanish navy in Manila Bay proved to be the beginning of a new era of colonization. The United States laid claim on the Philippines by virtue of the Treaty of Paris (10 Dec 1898). Spain ceded the Philippines to the United States. But the Filipinos fought for their independence from 1899 to 1907. Assuming sovereignty over the Philippine Islands, the US military took over Fort San Felipe and the neighboring fortified town of Cavite Puerto.

The fort was planned as an irregular quadrilateral and has four bastions with orillons at each corner. Various maps (e.g., 1639, 1738) represent the fort’s bastions as having orillons; however, remaining physical evidence indicates that the fort’s bastions were of the more advanced, straight-wall type rather than the more traditional ace-of-spades layout.

Today, only the facade and main entrance with flanking curtain walls and two bastions remain. The rest of the fort was demolished by the Americans during the early 20th century to make way for a naval station.  Written by René B. Javellana

(Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos)

text:
Fuerza de San Pedro also known as Kuta ni San Pedro. Location: Plaza Independencia, Cebu City.

Located at the edge of Plaza Independencia near the port of Cebu, the fort protected the first European settlement in the Philippines known as Villa de San Miguel which was established on 8 May 1565, the feast of St Michael the Archangel. The Villa was just a small defensible area which had a church and some quarters. Like every other solid structure built by the Spaniards, the fort was originally just made of local materials such as wood, bamboo, and nipa strengthened by earthworks. Triangular in shape, its three corners were laid down by Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, Mateo del Saz, Miguel de Goiti, and Juan de la Isla. When Legazpi moved to Panay and then to Manila, Cebu was left with the skeleton of a Spanish outpost. Legazpi would later reestablish the settlement upon his return on 1 Jan 1571 as Ciudad del Santisimo Nombre de Jesus, owing to the rediscovery of the image of the Child Jesus thought to have been given to the Queen of Cebu by Magellan in 1521.

 

In 1588, there were 30 Spanish citizens, among whom 20 were soldiers who lived in the area. By the 1620s, the fort had become among a handful of structures that were made of masonry. The present stone fort was completed only in 1738. It was later given the name Fuerza de San Pedro to honor Legazpi’s flagship in the 1565 expedition.

The fort has three bastions and was once protected by an outer work of square wooden stakes. It has a parameter of 380.39 m. Its curtain walls are of unequal length. Its entrance facade is emblazoned with the Spanish royal seal.

 

Miraculously preserved from destruction during World War II and a planned demolition, the fort has a checkered history. It served as a refuge for the Spaniards during the brief Tres de Abril revolt in 1898. It saw the surrender of the Spaniards in December of the same year and the American occupation of Cebu in 1899. In 1937, it housed the University of the Philippines Cebu, then known as the Cebu Junior College, and was later turned into a Japanese camp in World War II. During the postwar period, it hosted an emergency hospital, the Philippine Army Camp in 1946-50, and government agencies such as the Bureau of Health, and the Cebu City Public Works Department; and the city zoo. It was restored in 1968 under Arch Leonardo Concepcion and finished in 1977 under the Cebu Tourism Council. It is now a park and a venue for public and private affairs. It used to host the Cebu branch of the National Museum of the Philippines.  Written by Resil B. Mojares, with notes from Trizer Dale D. Mansueto

 

Source

Javellana, René B., and Jose Ma. Lorenzo Tan. 1997. Fortress of Empire: Spanish Colonial Fortifications of the Philippines 1565-1898. Makati City: Bookmark, Inc.

text:
Also known as Fuerza de Santa Isabel de la Paragua. Location: Taytay, Palawan. Construction said to have begun in 1626, under Fray Agustin de San Pedro; reinforced ca 1717-19 by Fernando Vélez de Arce and ca 1738.

 

 

 

The Augustinian Recollects established a mission in Taytay, an enclave along the coast of northern Palawan, in 1623. A fort was first built here three years after, in 1626, by Fray Agustin de San Pedro, OAR. However, the friar’s fortification was apparently a palisade, and it is uncertain whether a more permanent structure was built. Whatever the case, by the first quarter of the 18th century Fray Agustin’s fort was in a bad state and had been abandoned. Taytay’s close proximity to Borneo, being in the track of both merchant ships under other Europeans and the vessels of seafaring pirates, prompted Gov-Gen Fernando Manuel de Bustillos to rebuild the fort. Around the years 1713 to 1719, Fernando Vélez de Arce was appointed as the castle chief because of his expertise in building fortifications gained at the public academy of Barcelona.

In 1725, the Marques de Torrecampo, the successor of Bustillos, reported that Taytay was fortified by a palisade and recommended that a stone structure be built in response to the request of the alcalde mayor (provincial governor) of Calamianes (ancestor of today’s Palawan province) who had called together a council of war. In Oct 1726, work had progressed to the point that the wall facing the town was completed. The castle master Juan Antonio de la Torre suggested the demolition of the redoubt called “La Retirada” and suggested the building of a garita (guard house) at the shore as a guide and protection for ships.

Five years later, the new alcalde mayor Benito Llanes y Cienfuegos reported that the fortification was on a rock but was indefensible as it was of poor quality material. He suggested that the fortification be built elsewhere rather than waste resources on repairs, and that the demolished redoubt La Retirada be rebuilt. The central government sent the engineer Tomás de Castro to survey the area and submit his recommendations. De Castro wrote that building a new fort of a much better and more adequate design was the preferred option. However, he was instructed to do some repairs on the fort before such an undertaking (Diaz-Trechuelo 1959, 375-78).

Thus, in the fort’s plan included in the 1738 Valdes y Tamon report, sections were indicated as already being made of stone, others of timber, while still others were being planned. It seems that de Castro’s recommendation to build a completely new structure was not followed or rather that he was ordered to continue the reconstruction because a memorial stone on the inner side of the curtain wall indicates that de Castro was responsible for rebuilding the Taytay fort.

Described as a fuerza, Santa Isabel is built on a rocky islet a few hundred meters from the shore beside the sea. Planned as an irregular quadrilateral, whose perimeter followed the contour of the rock on which it is built, the fort has a seaward side curtain wall that is curved rather than straight. Bastions are found at each corner of the irregular plan, named, Santo Torribio, San Miguel, San Juan, and Santa Isabel. Garitas are strategically located.A ruined chapel is in the center of the plan. Some structures below ground are visible but their functions are uncertain. They may be the structures described in the 1738 report as storehouses.

Despite being well built, the fort was vulnerable to an attack from a hill on the shore which afforded an unobstructed view of it, and it was indeed attacked from this direction in 1734. The hill was subsequently ordered to be leveled.

The fort’s 1738 plan indicates barracks for the soldiers, a storehouse for supplies, a storehouse for gunpowder and weapons, and a common kitchen, but does not indicate where the church and convento were located. The last two were probably in the poblacion on the shore across the fort. A 650-foot causeway linked the mainland and the fortified rock. At high tide, this path was submerged and the fort was isolated.

Landor (1904, 111-12) describes Taytay and identifies the underground structures as “dungeons,” although he may have been mistaken. Landor writes:

“The fort, which could accommodate six or seven hundred soldiers, was constructed on a high rock projecting into the sea and connected with the land by an artificial causeway. There was a passage with steps, and an incline by which the summit of the church could be reached some 35 or 40 ft above the sea level. By the side of this incline were two dungeons, now roofless. In former times these dungeons had only one small aperture to give light and air to both chambers. On the opposite (east) side of the entrance-gate was a large cistern with a fountain at the lower portion. The fort was one of the finest on Palawan Island, and had four bastions, those overlooking the sea to the north being semicircular, whereas the other two were angular. For its day it possessed some powerful iron artillery, such as one long five-inch piece dated 1812, and two four-inch (1823) cannons. A great number of one-pound bullets were used as mitraille in the big guns; possibly smaller guns were in those times mounted upon the wall; or maybe it was ammunition fired at the fort by the Moro lantacas (brass cannon) in some attacks. The inside of the fort was at a slope, the north part being filled up to within five feet of the top of the wall. The two east turrets were reached by an incline, and a path was built all around the top of the castellated wall. The actual stone outer wall was no more than thirty inches wide, but it was filled with earth and thus made of great strength. The only building inside, which was formerly a chapel with two bamboo annexes, is now used as barracks for the constabulary force of seventeen men. The fort measures some forty paces square, and its walls was were about forty-two feet high and vertical, except corner bastions at a slant, with a cornichon twenty feet above the ground all round.”

The fort was partially restored by the local government, its environs landscaped, and then used as a park. The chapel in the middle of the fort was cleaned and consolidated and roofed with a temporary structure of metal and PVC roofing. As of 2016, the Taytay fort is being considered for declaration by the National Museum as an Important Cultural Property and has been placed under the supervision of the National Museum.  Written by René B. Javellana

Fort Santiago in Manila, ca 1920

(Leo Cloma Collection)

text:
Fuerza de Santiago. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Begun 1591.

Built on the site of Raja Sulayman’s old palisade, the earliest fort built here in 1571 by Miguel Lopez de Legazpi was one of wood. For many years thereafter, this fort and one of stone, called Nuestra Señora de Guia, built to its south between 1585 and 1587, constituted the two strongholds of the City of Manila. Gov-Gen Gomez Perez Dasmariñas, who began constructing the walls of Manila, ordered the demolition of the wooden fort and the construction of one in stone. Work began in 1591.

The fort was improved during the incumbency of Gov-Gen Sabiniano Manrique de Lara, as part of the preparations for the expected attack of the Chinese pirate Koxinga. The flanks of the bulwarks were strengthened with new masonry, platforms and earthwork tiled, the fort’s walls repaired, and parapets added. A platform, the San Miguel, on which cannons were mounted, was constructed at the fort’s apex facing the sea and commanding the river mouth. The platform was protected by a wall. A passage through the platform afforded a view of the sea and served as a good place for target practice.

 

In 1685, Gov-Gen Gabriel de Curuzelaegui ordered the reconstruction of two bulwarks: San Juan Crisostomo, which commanded the river, and San Gregorio, which commanded the sea. Both had been ordered demolished by Gov-Gen Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera, 1635-44. He also ordered the construction of a moat to separate the fort from the rest of the city, and a drawbridge with a protecting ravelin. During his term as interim governor, Alonso de Abella Fuentes secured permission to transfer the Royal storehouse elsewhere. Under Gov-Gen Fausto Cruzat y Gongora, new barracks were constructed, as the quarters built by his predecessors were inadequate. He also had the bulwarks and curtain walls tiled and improved the moat, which was inundated when the tides were high but was otherwise dry.

During the first quarter of the 18th century, the barracks constructed by Abella Fuentes were in disrepair. Plans for a new barracks, with a flat roof to serve as platforms for soldiers, were proposed in 1713; nothing was done until 1716. Quarters for the commander of the fort and the chaplain were also constructed. A sketch done in 1714 by Juan de Ciscara illustrates the fort during this time. A semicircular platform (now renamed San Jose) was the same one constructed by Manrique de Lara. Behind it were the bulwark of Santa Barbara and its ramps, the storehouse for munitions, a small garden, the house of the fort commander’s house, and barracks. The moat separating the fort from the city stands before the bulwarks of San Miguel (formerly San Gregorio) and San Francisco (formerly San Juan Crisostomo).

Throughout the Spanish period, the fort achieved notoriety as a place of imprisonment and torture for “enemies of the state.” Most prominent of the Filipinos imprisoned in Fort Santiago was Jose Rizal, who upon his arrest in 1896 was shipped back to Manila and imprisoned in one of the cells of the Fort. It was here where he wrote his “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell) and from here that he walked to his execution in nearby Bagumbayan (now Luneta) in the early morning of 30 Dec 1896. During the Pacific War, the Japanese used the Fort as their jail and torture chambers. Hundreds of Filipinos, including Josefa Llanes Escoda and her husband Antonio Escoda, are believed to have been executed in the Fort. Bombed and partly destroyed by Americans in 1945, the Fort was restored in stages, first the walls and dungeons, then offices and barracks. The gate destroyed during the war was restored, the bas-relief of Santiago on a horse was recreated by Paete artists. In the course of archaeological excavations in the area and in Plaza Moriones, once used for military drills, an old bridge located slightly to the west of the entrance was discovered. It was then decided to revive the moat that once separated Fort Santiago from the rest of the city.

In time for the centennial of Jose Rizal’s birth, a building beside the western wall was restored and made into a shrine-museum to honor Rizal. Here Rizal memorabilia, paintings, and a life-size diorama were assembled. This building was chosen for restoration because it was the least damaged from the war. Visitors often misidentified this building as the site of Rizal’s incarceration. He was jailed in the building across the shrine, near the Pasig. That building was left partially ruined. Another building adjoining Rizal’s place of incarceration was made an open-air theater named Dulaang Raha Sulayman. It became the home for almost four decades of the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), founded in 1967 by Cecile Guidote-Alvarez. Its unique T-shaped stage influenced the aesthetics of PETA. To this theater many fans and followers went to watch performances of PETA until 2006 when it moved to a new home, the PETA Theater Center in Quezon City.

Plaza Moriones, the area immediately south of Fort Santiago, has often been mistakenly associated by visitors with the fort because an antique wrought iron gate, originally from the Madrigal residence, was set up as a perimeter along Santa Lucia St, together with a ticketed entrance booth for tourists. In colonial times, the plaza had an auxiliary building for the fort. Here the Artilleria de Maestranza, the fort’s foundry and successor of the Fundición, an earlier foundry beside Bastion San Diego, was built to one side of the plaza. The area was an open archaeological site until it was converted into a bamboo garden. Adjoining this site was where the Royal Chapel of the Incarnation used to stand; its space is now occupied by offices and toilets. The ruined building of the Reales Almacenes, the warehouse for goods to be shipped to Acapulco, beside the Pasig, was converted into a venue for cultural and social events and exhibitions. The Intramuros Visitors’ Center was built in the section of the wall beside the Baluartillo de San Francisco Javier. Immediately outside the Baluartillo was the Reducto de San Francisco, now converted to a shrine to Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, patroness of Mexico and the Philippines.

Work on maintaining, repairing, and restoring the Fort Santiago and its environs continues. Recently, the building on the Falsabraga de Santa Barbara was restored by Escuela Taller.  Written by René B. Javellana

It was here where he wrote his “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell) and from here that he walked to his execution in nearby Bagumbayan (now Luneta) in the early morning of 30 Dec 1896. During the Pacific War, the Japanese used the Fort as their jail and torture chambers. Hundreds of Filipinos, including Josefa Llanes Escoda and her husband Antonio Escoda, are believed to have been executed in the Fort. Bombed and partly destroyed by Americans in 1945, the Fort was restored in stages, first the walls and dungeons, then offices and barracks. The gate destroyed during the war was restored, the bas-relief of Santiago on a horse was recreated by Paete artists. In the course of archaeological excavations in the area and in Plaza Moriones, once used for military drills, an old bridge located slightly to the west of the entrance was discovered. It was then decided to revive the moat that once separated Fort Santiago from the rest of the city.

In time for the centennial of Jose Rizal’s birth, a building beside the western wall was restored and made into a shrine-museum to honor Rizal. Here Rizal memorabilia, paintings, and a life-size diorama were assembled. This building was chosen for restoration because it was the least damaged from the war. Visitors often misidentified this building as the site of Rizal’s incarceration. He was jailed in the building across the shrine, near the Pasig. That building was left partially ruined. Another building adjoining Rizal’s place of incarceration was made an open-air theater named Dulaang Raha Sulayman. It became the home for almost four decades of the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), founded in 1967 by Cecile Guidote-Alvarez. Its unique T-shaped stage influenced the aesthetics of PETA. To this theater many fans and followers went to watch performances of PETA until 2006 when it moved to a new home, the PETA Theater Center in Quezon City.

Plaza Moriones, the area immediately south of Fort Santiago, has often been mistakenly associated by visitors with the fort because an antique wrought iron gate, originally from the Madrigal residence, was set up as a perimeter along Santa Lucia St, together with a ticketed entrance booth for tourists. In colonial times, the plaza had an auxiliary building for the fort. Here the Artilleria de Maestranza, the fort’s foundry and successor of the Fundición, an earlier foundry beside Bastion San Diego, was built to one side of the plaza. The area was an open archaeological site until it was converted into a bamboo garden. Adjoining this site was where the Royal Chapel of the Incarnation used to stand; its space is now occupied by offices and toilets. The ruined building of the Reales Almacenes, the warehouse for goods to be shipped to Acapulco, beside the Pasig, was converted into a venue for cultural and social events and exhibitions. The Intramuros Visitors’ Center was built in the section of the wall beside the Baluartillo de San Francisco Javier. Immediately outside the Baluartillo was the Reducto de San Francisco, now converted to a shrine to Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, patroness of Mexico and the Philippines.

Work on maintaining, repairing, and restoring the Fort Santiago and its environs continues. Recently, the building on the Falsabraga de Santa Barbara was restored by Escuela Taller.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
Ang Maharlika. Location: San Miguel, Manila. Built in the late 19th century, restored 1966. Architect: Leandro Locsin (renovation).

The text of the Philippines Historical Committee (PHC) marker reads: “Built by the Eugster Family from whom it was acquired by the Oidor de la Audiencia, Jose Moreno Localle; successively occupied by Admiral Patricio Montojo of the Spanish Navy, 1897-1898, later by the Spanish Royal Navy Club, 1898. Became the offices of the Philippine Preliminary Exposition to the International Exposition, St Louis, Mo., USA, 1903-1904. Housed the Philippine School of Commerce, 1908. The First Philippine Senate held its sessions here, 16 Oct 1916. Bought and occupied by Michael Goldenberg, 1950.”

Michael Goldenberg was a French-Jewish businessman who at the age of six came to Manila in 1895 with his father Leon Goldenberg, a doctor who had served in the French Army. As a chemist of the Botica Inglesa along Escolta, Dr Goldenberg made the acquaintance of such Filipino patriots as the Luna brothers. Michael Goldenberg was a renowned Filipiniana collector.

 

The two-story house, located on Gen Solano St, Manila, is a unique example of 19th-century Filipino architecture. The facade has 10 bays, each consisting of an arch on the ground floor, and a window set between wooden panels on the second floor. The wooden second floor extends beyond the stone walls of the first floor to form a U-shaped porch on the first floor. The projecting second floor is supported by slender steel columns with cusped arches, which form the boundary of the porch. A cusped arch has curved or leaf-like ornaments at regular intervals on its inner side, making it appear like a multi-foil arch.

The two central bays of both the second floor and the first floor porch project slightly beyond the facade to form a sheltered entrance. The gable and a flat overhang over this section resemble a pediment. Behind this focal point of the facade is a small third-story tower, providing vertical emphasis. The windows, each with a ventanilla or window shutters, are separated from each other by wooden panels. The front wall of the ground floor has three doors evenly spaced. The steel columns and arches were made in Belgium. The ground floor porch and interior have a floor of black and white tiles in chessboard pattern.

 

The cusped arches of the porch are repeated in wood in the interior, in the ground floor and second floor hallways, and in the volada (gallery) of the sala on the second floor. A wide corridor connects the entrance to a grand stairway set deep in the interior. The stairway is of the imperial type—a wide single flight rising to a landing, then splitting into two flights that make a 180-degree turn at the landing as they continue to the second floor.

The long sala with its volada along the front and side windows, and the staircase, with its surrounding arcade, are elegant examples of space surrounded by space. The marker installed by the PHC in 1957 called the house the Goldenberg Mansion. After it was acquired by the Marcos Foundation in 1966 and subsequently restored and improved, it was renamed Ang Maharlika. Both restoration and improvement followed studies and plans made by architect Leandro Locsin. Ang Maharlika was used as a guesthouse during the Marcos regime.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
Location: Loyola St, Sampaloc, Manila. Completed 1917. Architects: Arcadio Arellano and Juan Arellano.

Gota de Leche (Drop of Milk) building is a project of La Proteccion de la Infancia Inc (LPI), a charity organization founded in 1907 by Asociacion Feminista Filipina, together with other philantrophists. Concerned with alarmingly high mortality rate, malnutrition, and diseases of the infants and children from poor families, LPI provided free medical care and created a nutritional program by giving free weekly rations of milk. The first foundation was in San Pedro (now Evangelista) St, Quiapo, Manila.

The design for the present building was a collaborative work of Arcadio Arellano, considered to be one of the founding fathers of Philippine Architecture, and his brother Juan Arellano, a newly arrived architecture graduate from the United States. Construction began in 1914 or 1915 on the land donated by the philanthrophist Teodoro R. Yangco in Sampaloc, and was finished in 1917. Gota de Leche was modeled on the first Renaissance building in Europe, the Ospedale degli Innocenti (Hospital of the Innocents), an orphanage in Florence, Italy designed by the renowned Italian architect Filippo Brunelleschi in 1419-27.

 

The brick building is rectangular in plan. The two-story main facade has a triangular pediment whose apex is adorned with a statue of the Madonna and Childat its apex. A tall arched portal serves as the main entrance with decorative relief carvings and the Latin words Salus Populi Suprema Lex (“the welfare of the people is the supreme law”) familiar Latin words from Cicero’s De Legibus.

Adjacent to the right is a five-bay, cross-vaulted arcaded loggia (shaded verandah) with semicircular arches on columns. In the spandrels or spaces between the arches are the terra-cotta tondi (roundels) that frame reliefs of babies in swaddling clothes, referring to the advocacy of the institution. All these features relate to Brunelleschi’s masterpiece. Mother and child, angels, and robust infants were the main decorative motifs used in the reliefs. Large wooden-framed capiz shell windows that protect the verandah from sun and rain provide a local touch.

In 2002, Gota de Leche and its garden were restored to their original 1917 condition and appearance by a team spearheaded by architect Augusto Villalon and landscape architect Ani Katrina de Leon. Villalon’s grandfather Dr. Jose Fabella was once a president of Gota de Leche. The restoration project received an honorable mention in the 2003 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Asia-Pacific Heritage Awards for Cultural Heritage Preservation. It was declared a historical landmark in 1977 and 2003 by the National Historical Institute (NHI), later known as National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP).

A successful adaptation of Italian Renaissance architectural style in a tropical setting, Gota de Leche continues to serve its original purpose with other parts of the building rented and leased for exhibitions, student and community functions, and office space.  Written by Clarissa L. Avendaño

Pilapil, Impy. 2004. “Reminiscences of Gota de Leche.” The Philippine Star. Updated 1 Mar. http://www.philstar.com/arts-and-culture/240917/reminiscences-gota-de-leche

Church of Nuestra Señora de Gracia in Makati City, 2016

(Kiko del Rosario)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe. Location: Makati, Metro Manila. Completed 1630, rebuilt 1970.

The Monastery of Guadalupe was the 32nd Augustinian house founded in the Philippines. Initially a house for priests in 1601, it officially became a monastery in 1605. Grateful travelers of the Manila-Acapulco galleons popularized the devotion to the patroness Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, formerly Nuestra Señora de Gracia. Chinese traders were the first advocates of a secondary patron, San Nicolas de Tolentino, who supposedly saved them at sea, for which he has since been honored with a fluvial parade. Perched on a hillock, Guadalupe was a seasonal refuge of priests away from their city parishes. It was also a sanctuary of high officials, and even housed an office for Gov-Gen Rafael Izquierdo. The British converted the monastery into their operational headquarters in 1762, during which only the image of the patroness was saved from defilement by an Irish Catholic soldier. It was a grammar school in 1853, an orphanage from 1882 to 1885, and the Escuela de Artes y Oficios in 1885. It was occupied by Emilio Aguinaldo’s troops from 1898 to 1899, and later by the Americans in the Philippine-American War and the Japanese during World War II. Erecting the church and convento to replace the first makeshift building was costly and laborious.

 

Using cash donations from Cebu’s bishopric, Fr Eustaquio Ortiz finally saw its completion in 1630. The structures underwent repair in 1662, following the earthquake of 1885, and again in 1706. However, not even the image of the patron survived the devastating earthquake of 1880. Fr Jose Corugedo’s two terms were thus devoted to reconstruction, accomplished in 1885. It was destroyed by bombs during the Battle of Manila in 1945. After World War II, the archdiocese tore down the convento to use its stones in constructing the Manila Cathedral in Intramuros. The church was rebuilt only when the house was restored to the Augustinians in 1970. Some aspects of the present church are derived from the Romanesque, as best exemplified by the interior stuccoed vaults, formerly of stone. Adorning the facade are baroque touches, like the leaf carvings above the recessed semi-rounded arches of the entrance, windows, and niches. A large round window at the center, the facade’s focal point, breaks the vertical lines of Doric columns supporting the cornice and the triangular pediment. The church is flanked by huge buttresses. An apparent structural imbalance results from the absence of the old convento, once an integral part of the complex.  Written by Monica P. Consing

photos.desc:
Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion in Guiuan, Eastern Samar, 2016

(Kinna G. Kwan)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of Inmaculada Concepcion. Location: Guiuan, Eastern Samar. Built most likely 1718, repaired and renovated 1844, also 1935. Ruined 7 Nov 2013 by Typhoon Yolanda (Haiyan).

The Augustinians may have visited Guiuan and preached Christianity in 1585, 10 years before the Jesuits took charge of Samar, following the decree of 1595 demarcating mission areas and designating specific religious orders to each. The arrival of the Jesuits is also mentioned in Huerta’s catalogue of Franciscan parishes in the 19th century.

In Samar, the Jesuits made their first landfall in Tinagon, present-day Barangay Dap-dap in Taragnan and from there spread throughout the island. Guiuan, on Samar’s southern coast, however, was easier to reach through Leyte so at one time it fell under Leyte, although by 1768 it was administratively under the Palapag residence.

 

Guiuan was developed as an important way point in the galleon’s route; it was an emergency docking area and a provisioning point before the galleon set across the Pacific or as a rest area after the long crossing from Mexico. By the mid–1600s, the church was fortified. The Jesuit Jose Delgado (1697-1755) describes the fortification walls as quadrilateral with bastions at the corners and considered the fort the second best south of Manila.

By the 1700s, Guiuan had a considerable Chinese community, proof of its active engagement in trade. It may have had a stone church by then or at least a church of wood and tiles. In 1718, Murillo Velarde says, a more permanent structure was built. But that church burned down later. However, in 1740, Delgado describes the church as single-naved and reports that it was in good condition, indicating the church must have been repaired after the fire mentioned above.

 

In 1768, Guiuan and other southern Samar missions were turned over to the Augustinians who were given spiritual charge of Leyte. In 1795, unable to meet the demands for personnel, the Augustinians ceded Guiuan to the Franciscans. But, for nine years, the Franciscans could not supply any resident pastor. Then, in 1804, the first Franciscan missionary Fray Miguel Pérez arrived.

In 1844 and following, the church was renovated, and the roof covered with tiles at the initiative of Frays Manuel Valverde and Pedro Monasterio. Fray Monasterio, parish priest in 1844-45 and 1853-59, added the transepts to the church transforming it to a cruciform. Huerta describes the parochial house as made of stone.

As it was no longer functional for defense, the fortification’s southern bastion became the site of a bell tower in 1854. The Jesuits had not built a bell tower but rather kept the bell within the fortification where it served liturgical functions and doubled as a warning device to warn of sea-borne attacks. The Jesuits had a modest convento, built behind the church sanctuary, an extension of the sacristy. In 1872, Franciscan Fray Arsenio Figueroa built another convento for which he demolished part of the western curtain wall. After 1886, Fray Fernando Esteban (parish priest 1888-97) replaced the church’s tile roof with zinc sheets. He also built two schools. In 1935, Guiuan church was refurbished while Msgr Donato Guimbaolibot was pastor. Guimbaolibot was parish priest of Balangiga when the American soldiers were attacked by Katipunero. Although the monsignor was not involved in the plot, he was arrested and severely tortured. In 1903, he was assigned to Guiuan, his hometown, and remained parish priest there until he died in 1949.

In 1987, the church sanctuary was renovated. On 7 Nov 2014, Guiuan suffered major destruction when super typhoon Yolanda blew off its roof, toppled half of its facade, and damaged the main retablo of the church. The restoration of the church was completed in 2019.

The Guiuan fort is partially preserved. The southeastern bulwark, where the Franciscans built a bell tower in 1854, the southwestern bulwark, and parts of the southern and western curtain wall still stand.

The Franciscans apparently added a transept and a baptistry. This is the sense of Huerta’s “reedificada.” Architectural evidence bears this out. Guiuan owns numerous altars—a virtual history of the parish. Aside from the baroque main altar, two side altars stand along the nave. One bears mixed parentage, a retablo from Franciscan times and a rococo frontal with the Augustinian emblem. Each transept end has an altar. One, which houses a templet, has florid baroque motifs, probably remnants of the side altar from Jesuit times. The altar table itself is cuplike, typical of Franciscan rococo, similar to the altars in the Franciscan church of Baras.

An outstanding Franciscan addition is the baptistry located near the church entrance. It is decorated like grottoes, that is, with shells of at least eight kinds and coral; probably the only example of its kind in the Philippines. The types of shells used were identified by the National Museum of the Philippines in 2008.

The Guiuan facade damaged by Yolanda is divided into verticals and horizontals by engaged columns and horizontal lines. But its ornamented pediment, surface decoration and niches with sculpture, and carved hardwood door make it akin to the retablo facade. The Guiuan Church has been declared a National Cultural Treasure by the National Museum.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Sources

Alzina, Francisco Ignacio, SJ. ca 1960. The Muñoz Text of Alzina’s History of the Bisayan Islands (1668). Part 1. Preliminary translation by Paul S. Lietz. Chicago: Philippine Studies Program, Department of Anthropology, University of Chicago.

De Huerta, Felix. (1855) 1865. Estado Geografico, Topografico, Estadistico, Historico-Religioso de la Santa y Apostolica Provincia de S. Gregorio Magno. Manila: Imprenta de los Amigos del Pais. Reprint, Binondo: Imprenta de M. Sánchez y Cª.

Delgado, Jose. 1892. Historia General Sacro-profana, Politica y Natural de las Islas de Poniente Llamadas Filipinas. Manila: Imprenta de el Eco de Filipinas de Don Juan Atayde, 1892.

Murillo Velarde, Pedro. 1749. Historia de la provincia de Philippinas de Compania de Jesus. Part II.
