text:
Location: Luneta, Manila. Inaugurated 1912, renovated 1975. Architects: William Parsons, 1912; Leandro Locsin, 1975.

The Manila Hotel was the first big hotel built during the American regime, and was the largest in the country for more than half a century. Daniel H. Burnham’s plan for Manila allocated a lot, 152.40 m x 182.88 m along Manila Bay at the north end of the Luneta, as the site for a hotel that would serve the needs of Americans in the Philippines, particularly tourists. The building was officially inaugurated on 4 Jul 1912, although it had actually been in operation some time before that. Some rooms later served as residences for American government officials, among them Justice George Malcolm and Maj Dwight Eisenhower, the latter then in the staff of Gen Douglas MacArthur.

The five-story building was H-shaped and originally had 149 guest rooms on the second up to the fifth floors. For purposes of ventilation, the rooms were on one side of a corridor and were provided with large windows. Some rooms opened out to balconies.

Because of the hotel’s popularity, an annex with 80 rooms was subsequently built on the bay side.

 

The lobby was a hall about 8 m deep and 45 m wide, with an inner arcade composed of semicircular arches resting on coupled columns in the Tuscan or Roman Doric style. At the west end of the lobby was the dining room, surrounded by a veranda. Along the lobby towards the dining room were the ladies’ parlor and rest rooms. At the east end were the reading room, billiard room, bar, cigar counter, barbershop, and men’s rest rooms. On the mezzanine were the music room, guests’ parlor, and children’s dining room. One of the hotel’s attractions was its roof garden. The Manila Hotel was the first hotel in Asia equipped with electric elevators.

Following Burnham’s recommendations, the building was of reinforced concrete, with flat unadorned exterior walls. While modern in appearance, it evoked the style of the Spanish colonial period, with prominent hip roofs, wide overhangs, rectangular windows on the upper floors, and semicircular arches on the ground floor. Sliding window shutters with capiz panes gave the structure a distinctly Filipino character. The building then cost 1.4 million pesos or $700,000.

In 1934, a vast ballroom, the Fiesta Pavilion, was built on the bay side, extending from the dining room. It soon became the center of Manila’s social life and also the venue of political gatherings. Heavily damaged during World War II, the hotel underwent repairs and resumed operations in late 1945. The repairs took two years to complete. In 1950 the hotel inaugurated the Winter Garden, an air-conditioned ballroom located at the rear and along the bay. Further improvements were made in 1954. The Fiesta Pavilion housed the 1971 Constitutional Convention. The dining room was later converted into a foyer for the pavilion, and was adorned with murals by Carlos “Botong” Francisco.

In 1975, the hotel was renovated following plans prepared by Leandro Locsin. Since the original building could not house additional rooms, an 18-story tower was built behind the central section of the building. The hotel has at present 600 rooms and suites. The lobby was expanded and the original dining room was restored and refurbished. The old Fiesta Pavilion was demolished and a new pavilion built at the rear on the Intramuros side, provided with its own entrance.

New function rooms were added. The firm of Dale Keller and Associates was engaged for the interior design. The exterior retained the original white-and-green color scheme of Parsons. A wrought-iron porte cochere was erected at the main entrance. In its refurbished form, the Manila Hotel became a felicitous combination of Parsons’s austere proto-modern style and Locsin’s elegant, romantic style.

Around 1995, the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) placed the property for sale. Under new ownership, Manila Hotel underwent renovation in 1997. Beginning in 2008, the hotel underwent even more renovations in preparation for its centennial in 2012. Room windows were enlarged, interiors were refurbished and equipped with new amenities. A health club was opened next to the hotel spa. On 17 Jan 2008, adjacent to the main building, was built Tent City, a performance and concert hall that can hold 2,500 guests.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Manila Observatory on Padre Faura Street in Manila

(Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)

text:
Observatorio Meteorológico del Ateneo de Manila, El Observatorio de Manila. A meteorological and astronomical observatory founded by the Jesuits. Location: Originally in the Jesuits’ Casa Mision in Intramuros, moved to Padre Faura St, Ermita, Manila. Established 1865; building on Padre Faura inaugurated in 1886; astronomy building in 1894.

The Manila Observatory had its beginnings as a serious hobby of the Jesuit scholastics Jaime Nonell and Francisco Colina who kept track of typhoons on a dovecot at the roof of the Jesuits’ Casa Mision in Intramuros. This was augmented in Sep 1865 by the purchase of a Secchi universal meteograph and in 1869 by the arrival of its first director Federico Faura, SJ.

Invented by Angelo Secchi, the director of the Vatican Observatory, the universal meteograph was a thermometer, hydrometer, and barometer, which cost the business community of Manila 500 duros to purchase and turn over to Faura. With the meteograph, the systematic observation of the weather began.

 

In 1879, the Manila Observatory began routinely serving typhoon warnings and the following year began earthquake studies. In 1884, the Manila Observatory, was recognized by the Spanish government, which issued a royal decree formally making it the official Philippine institution for weather forecasting.

In 1885, the Observatory began its time service that would greatly benefit merchant shipping. A seismology section was established in 1887. In 1899, the Observatory ventured into astronomical studies. By this time the Observatory had outgrown its quarters and moved to Ermita beside the Escuela Normal de San Francisco Xavier, established as a teacher training institute. The Observatory’s new building was inaugurated in 1886. The astronomical building was built in 1894. The road where the Observatory stood would be named Padre Faura, in honor of its first director during the American colonial era. On its original site is now Robinsons Place Ermita.

The American colonial government recognized the importance of the Observatory’s work, and, in 1901, established it as the Philippine Weather Bureau under the Department of Interior. In 1917, it was placed under the Department of Agriculture and Natural Resources. For about 45 years, the Observatory remained active and well known in international expositions and scientific expeditions. The Institution continued to give accurate typhoon forecasts, and its scientific works in the field of meteorology, geo-magnetism, and astronomy was notable.

World War II gravely set back the institution. In Feb 1945, during the liberation of Manila, the Observatory with its scientific instruments and documents was completely destroyed. It was in harm’s way, located between the walled city of Intramuros and Rizal Stadium, where Japanese troops made their last stand. After the war, the Observatory ceased to function when the government set up the Weather Bureau as a distinct government agency.

In 1951, the Observatory re-opened on Mirador Hill in Baguio, resuming its research in seismology earthquakes and continuing its study of the ionosphere. In 1963, the Manila Observatory transferred to the Loyola Heights campus of the Ateneo de Manila University, where it continued seismic studies, geomagnetic and radio physics research, while expanding into solar physics as well.

Now more fully integrated with the Ateneo de Manila’s academic program, the Manila Observatory has entered the area of environmental and climate studies.

Manila Observatory’s building along Padre Faura St had two parts: a longitudinal building of two stories at the center but whose opposite ends rose to three. An open deck atop these towers was reserved for scientific instruments. Joined to it by an open bridge was the astronomy building, designed with two towers 10 m in diameter and 14 m high. On one of these, a rotating dome was installed for the equatorially mounted refracting telescope. In 1901, it had a Merz object glass with an aperture of 18 Paris inches.

Like its neighbor, the Escuela Normal, the Manila Observatory building at Padre Faura was designed in the neoclassical style with its clean and straight lines, simple rectangular windows, and arched entrances.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Sources

De la Costa, Horacio. 1997 (1941). Light Cavalry. Manila: National Office of Mass Media.

text:
Location: Ermita, Manila. Completed 1930. Architect: Juan Arellano.

In conformity with the Burnham plan for Manila, the Post Office was situated at the end of a boulevard and along the Pasig River to make it accessible by both land and water transport. Its front dominates Liwasang Bonifacio (formerly Plaza Lawton) and the country’s widest boulevard, Burgos Drive. Its rear lords over the south bank of the Pasig. It is flanked by two bridges, Jones and MacArthur (formerly Santa Cruz). In its early decades, its setting was far more impressive than that of Arellano’s previous masterpiece, the Legislative Building. Presently that setting has been marred by flyovers, and the building itself has become a base for unsightly antennae.

The neoclassic reinforced-concrete building is a monumental composition consisting basically of a rectangular block buttressed at each end by semicylindrical volumes. A majestic portico with 14 fluted Ionic columns runs along the front, its repeated vertical lines dramatizing the strongly horizontal character of the structure. The portico, piercing the massive block, as it were, serves as the disclosure of a large inner space. The building is fittingly elevated on a podium consisting of steps.

 

The principal interior space is a long, two-story high hall where counters are located. In the original building, pilasters rose along the walls and led the eye to a richly decorated ceiling. On each end of the hall are spaces where more counters are located. These semicircular halls are in the semicylindrical blocks.

Destroyed in 1945 during the liberation of Manila, the building was restored in accordance with the original plans, although some of its rich interior details were simplified.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion in Maragondon, Cavite, 1994

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion. Location: Maragondon, Cavite. Begun around 1687, completed 1714 under the Jesuits; renovations under secular clergy, first half of 19th century, and under the Augustinian Recollects, 1880s.

The Franciscans were the first evangelizers in the area around Maragondon, the most important community then in northwest Cavite. By 1611 Maragondon was under the Jesuits, separated as a town in this year from Silang by the Jesuit Angelo Armano. In 1630, a second church with more elaborate furnishings was completed. In 1633, a new and bigger church was built to replace the older and smaller one. The church was apparently of stone, for sometime between 1646 and 1649 the government ordered its demolition for fear that the Dutch, who were at war with Spain, would use it and other churches near Manila for fortification. The orders were apparently implemented because, on 16 May 1650, a license was given to the Jesuits to build a house and church of wood in Maragondon to replace the one that had been demolished. Repairs were made on the convento between 1666 and 1672. In 1687, another church was begun although the construction was interrupted; only in 1714 was it completed. Most of the church, the entire bell tower, and the lower portion of the convento are all of chipped rubblework; the inside and outside walls are covered with palitada (stucco).

 

The church was repaired a number of times but data on the renovations are sketchy. At the expulsion of the Jesuits from the Philippines in 1768, Maragondon was turned over to the secular clergy. The secular priest Anastacio de los Reyes provided the church with new roof beams, emblazoning them with praises to the Virgin Mary and topping it off by having his name carved along with the date the work was inaugurated. This would correspond with the raising of the facade with cut stone, as revealed in a recent restoration. The Archbishop of Manila had to admonish Fr de los Reyes from spending too much on his church. A year after their return to the Philippines in 1859, the Jesuits were assigned the Recollect missions in Mindanao. To compensate the Recollects, they in turn were given the secular-administered churches around Manila. Maragondon was the last in Cavite to be relinquished, which in the 1880s had been more than a century under the seculars. After 1886 the Recollects added windows with colored glass panes, and set these in a wooden frame decorated with a partridge on a plate, the attribute of San Nicolas de Tolentino.

The facade is chastely ornamented with tapering buttresses supporting it. In contrast is the door, divided into squares featuring carved floral designs of different shapes, ships, and castles, all probably references to the patroness of the church. To the facade’s left is a tall bell tower which uniquely has no clear divisions between the stories. It is a single shaft tapering upwards, ending in finials at the corners, and surmounted by a rounded roof. The elevation of the facade is emphasized in the interior by the use of pilasters that taper upwards. This produces a dizzying effect, as the pillars appear to soar up and sway. The door leading from sanctuary to sacristy is also carved with flowers in squares. This design motif can also be found in the doors of the churches in Indang, Cavite and Baclayon, Bohol. Probably the doors came from the same atelier. The church has three retablos, all brightly polychromed. The main retablo has an image of the Virgin’s assumption in the main niche. An image of a balding and somewhat rotund San Ignacio flanks it, and so does an image of San Luis Gonzaga. The whole retablo is decorated with salomonica or twisted columns, foliage, and angels with large bellies. The side retablos have lost their original statuary, and new ones have replaced what have been lost. The gospel-side retablo that used to house the Santo Niño de Ternate might belong to the late 17th or early 18th century. An octagonal pulpit at the right side of the nave is polychromed in red, blue, gold, and green. Monograms of the names of Jesus and Mary decorate the pulpit panels. Salomonica columns flank the borders of each panel. The bottom of the pulpit is decorated with swirling foliage that end in an inverted pineapple. A crucifix dated 1712 is found near the church’s main entrance. The lower part of the convento is older than the rest of the building, being made of rubble like the church and tower; the newer part is of cut stone and brick. The sacristy is a 19th century addition. There are remains of an old defensive wall and a blockhouse that surrounds the quadrangle formed by the church and convento. A rare vaulted cistern or bodega at one end of the convento still standing in the 1980s has since been demolished.

The church has been renovated since 1991. Among the welcome changes when repainting the retablo was the decision to remove the embroidered dress imposed over the fully carved image in the round. On 31 Jul 2001, the National Museum of the Philippines awarded Maragondon the title National Cultural Treasure. In 2012, the church’s historic look was restored with the protective plastering of the walls.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Church of Santa Cruz in Maribojoc, Bohol, 2003

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of [Triunfo de la] Santa Cruz (Triumph of the True Cross), San Vicente Ferrer (secondary patron). Location: Maribojoc, Bohol.

Maribojoc (other names: Malabohoc, Dungguan) was named after agoho (in Visayan maribojoc or malabohoc, an endemic evergreen tree, Casaurina equisetifolia, often mistaken for a pine) in one of its barangays, Punta Cruz. Oral tradition claims that first Jesuits, Juan de Torres and Gabriel Sanchez, sent to Bohol in response to the request for priests by the family of the encomendero of the island, set foot in this barangay in late Nov 1596.

 

The fort built by the Recollects in 1796 at Punta Cruz shows that Bohol’s coast was vulnerable to slave raiders, thus, Maribojoc’s town center was put on a plateau facing the sea. Placed inland, like a number of Bohol coastal towns, Maribojoc has a lower town (ubos) and an upper town (ibabao).

The cruciform church and the convento adjoined to its rear are located in ibabao. From the convento one sees a clear view of the lower town and the sea. Unlike most colonial towns, the church does not face a flat, open plaza but a ravine linked by a causeway. Jose observes: “Maribojoc must be the only one [church] in the country with a ravine in front of its entrance, instead of a plaza. There must be a defensive purpose for this kind of location. There is a plaza on either side of the church—one grassy, the other now a basketball court—but neither is bounded by municipal buildings, as is the case with other towns. According to oral tradition, the grassy field flanking the gospel side of the church was once a graveyard. Parts of the walls bordering this space are still standing” (Jose 2001b, 82). But could these walls have been part of an older fortification?

Further on Jose writes: “The bell tower has a separate entrance on the ground floor level. Could this have served the same purposes as similar entrances for the bell towers of Jagna and Dimiao, that is, to facilitate watchmen changing shifts during the pirate season?” (Jose 2001b, 84). Taking these details of the built structures and the natural location, one gets an impression that in fact Maribojoc was a well-fortified site. But who chose the site and when was its defensive position recognized?

By the 17th century, the Jesuits were already ministering in Maribojoc. Murillo Velarde, 1751-54, reports that the Austrian Jesuit, Jose Sanchez, 1616-92, had built part of the church and retablo of Maribojoc. Maribojoc for many decades was a visita (mission chapel) under Baclayon. But which church is Murillo Velarde referring to?

The foundation date of the parish is uncertain, although the years 1767 and 1768 are cited. Redondo’s 1886 report states that the oldest extant parish books were dated 2 Jan 1788, during the Recollect era. Maribojoc is an important parish because from it the parishes of Cortes, 1793, and Antequera, 1880, were established.

The Recollect era records two churches one built from 1798 to 1816 and the other later. The present church, however, was begun in 1852 and completed in 1872 under the incumbency as parish priest of Manuel Plaza, OAR, 1843-59, and Fernando Rubio, OAR, 1861-75 and 1877-84. This church built of cut coral is simple in design: a two-story structure crowned with a triangular pediment. The facade is divided into three vertical sections by paired engaged columns. Rosettes define the boundary between the first and second story. To the right of the facade, separated by a connecting corridor stands the bell tower.

On 15 Oct 1860, Maribojoc was raised to status of a municipality. In 1864, an elegant flight of steps from church to wharf was completed. The stairs are still there. The church was still being furnished and decorated in the early 20th century. The striking neo-Gothic altar of Maribojoc was initiated by Padre Quiteriano Sarigumba, whose initials PQS are found in the retablo. The retablo was completed in 1934.

On 15 Oct 2013, at 8:15 am, an earthquake of magnitude scale 7.2, equivalent to the power of 32 Hiroshima atomic bombs, hit Bohol. Traced to the activity of a recently discovered fault named the North Bohol Fault running east-northeast by west-southwest and running parallel to the shoreline from the town of Inabanga, north of Maribojoc to about 100 kilometers south, the quake caused the earth to rise some 500 m at the shore of Loon. Since Maribojoc stood on the fault line, the church was completely damaged. Reconstruction at the same site is being studied because the presence of the fault line does not recommend building on the same site.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Sources

Jose, Regalado Trota. 2001b. Visita Iglesia Bohol: A Guide to Historic Churches. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Murillo Velarde, Pedro. 1749. Historia de la provincia de Philippinas de Compania de Jesus. Part II.

Putong, Cecilio. 1965. Bohol and its People. Manila: Cecilio Putong.

Redondo, Felipe Sendino. 1886. Breve Reseña de lo que fue y lo que es la Diocesis de Cebu en las Islas Filipinas. Manila: Establecimieto Tipografico del Colegio de Sto. Tomás.

photos.desc:
Church of San Andres in Masinloc, Zambales, 2008

(Oliver Bautista)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Andres. Location: Masinloc, Zambales. Rebuilding of the church, 1837-53. The bell tower was built in 1882-83.

The name Masinloc is said to be derived from the name of a type of grass, hinloc. A barangay called Kasinlocan is located some two kilometers from the town center. During the Spanish colonial period, Zambales formed the western part of Pangasinan and had not yet been divided into the provinces of Bataan and Zambales. The area was inhabited by the Zambal or Sambal, known for being warlike and distrustful of intruders. In 1606, the Augustinian Recollects (OAR) were invited by the encomendero Hernando de Avalos to evangelize the area. The first friar sent to evangelize Bagac, Fr Miguel de la Madre de Dios, OAR, was martyred by stoning while he was preaching to the hostile Zambal. The future of the Recollect mission was uncertain. But, in 1607, Fr Rodrigo de San Miguel, OAR, who had successfully established a vicariate at Mariveles, sent Fr Andres de Espiritu Santo to Masinloc, now Zambales Province.

The expansion of the Recollect missions in Bataan and Zambales was turbulent. Because of native opposition, some missions were founded, then abandoned and refounded after a while. But the Recollects, by dint of single-minded hard work, were eventually able to establish a network of missions from Subic to Mariveles and throughout Zambales. The network reached as far north as Bolinao.

 

In 1607, Fr Andres directed the building of the first church of light materials at a site now identified as Barangay Bani and Tugui, south of the present town center. But this mission did not last long due to the hostility of neighboring groups. In Playa Honda (near today’s Iba), a fort was built to discourage enemy raids. A more permanent church and convento were built at the present site in 1616,using stones left over from the fortification. In 1679, when the Recollects were sent to evangelize Mindoro, Masinloc was turned over to the Dominicans; but, in 1713, Masinloc was returned to the Recollects. Around 1745, work by the Recollects on the church is reported, with repairs in 1754, 1756, and 1798, the year it was supposedly destroyed by an earthquake.

From 1814 to 1836, the whole of Zambales was ceded to the secular clergy due to lack of personnel. But in 1836, the Recollects returned to Masinloc, in the person of Fr Jose Aranguren, OAR, who arrived as the new parish priest on 13 Apr. This tireless priest was largely responsible for rebuilding the church. Fr Aranguren left in 1843. Two years later, he was made Archbishop of Manila.

The work on Masinloc church was continued by Fr Modesto Sesma, OAR, who arrived in Jul 1844. He had the sacristy enclosed, and provided the niches at the facade with locally made images of San Agustin, San Andres, and San Nicolas de Tolentino.The following year, he raised the walls and installed the ceiling of batikulin wood. In 1851-52, the roof was covered with tiles. The platform of the church including the main retablo was finished in 1853.Fr Agustin Perez, OAR (parish priest ca 1877-91) is credited with having completed the church: the roof tiles were replaced with zinc sheets, the marble baptismal font was bought, and the main altar was repaired. The epistle and gospel-side altars were donated by Don Jose Gloria and Don Agustin Medina respectively; the tabernacle of white marble was donated by Doña Manuela Segovia. The bell tower was partially built in 1882-83.

The Columbans replaced the Recollects after 1898. Fr Dennis Egan built the present convent in 1955. Masinloc was ceded to the diocesan clergy in 1988.

Much of the original interior of the church, including a noteworthy carved wooden statue of San Andres Apostol, has been lost through time. However, the portal that used to connect the choir loft with the old convent has retained its polychrome and is the most interesting and unique feature of the church.

The parish church of San Andres was declared a National Cultural Treasure by the National Museum of the Philippines on 31 Jul 2001. Damaged by the earthquake of 12 Dec 1999, rescue restoration was completed in 2007. The polychromed portal was restored in 2012-13.  Written by Mary Rajelyn J. Busmente, with notes from René B. Javellana and Regalado Trota Jose

The first friar sent to evangelize Bagac, Fr Miguel de la Madre de Dios, OAR, was martyred by stoning while he was preaching to the hostile Zambal. The future of the Recollect mission was uncertain. But, in 1607, Fr Rodrigo de San Miguel, OAR, who had successfully established a vicariate at Mariveles, sent Fr Andres de Espiritu Santo to Masinloc, now Zambales Province.

The expansion of the Recollect missions in Bataan and Zambales was turbulent. Because of native opposition, some missions were founded, then abandoned and refounded after a while. But the Recollects, by dint of single-minded hard work, were eventually able to establish a network of missions from Subic to Mariveles and throughout Zambales. The network reached as far north as Bolinao.

value.desc:
Church of San Andres in Masinloc, Zambales, 2008

(Oliver Bautista)

article.value: In 1607, Fr Andres directed the building of the first church of light materials at a site now identified as Barangay Bani and Tugui, south of the present town center. But this mission did not last long due to the hostility of neighboring groups. In Playa Honda (near today’s Iba), a fort was built to discourage enemy raids. A more permanent church and convento were built at the present site in 1616,using stones left over from the fortification. In 1679, when the Recollects were sent to evangelize Mindoro, Masinloc was turned over to the Dominicans; but, in 1713, Masinloc was returned to the Recollects. Around 1745, work by the Recollects on the church is reported, with repairs in 1754, 1756, and 1798, the year it was supposedly destroyed by an earthquake.

From 1814 to 1836, the whole of Zambales was ceded to the secular clergy due to lack of personnel. But in 1836, the Recollects returned to Masinloc, in the person of Fr Jose Aranguren, OAR, who arrived as the new parish priest on 13 Apr. This tireless priest was largely responsible for rebuilding the church. Fr Aranguren left in 1843. Two years later, he was made Archbishop of Manila.

The work on Masinloc church was continued by Fr Modesto Sesma, OAR, who arrived in Jul 1844. He had the sacristy enclosed, and provided the niches at the facade with locally made images of San Agustin, San Andres, and San Nicolas de Tolentino.The following year, he raised the walls and installed the ceiling of batikulin wood. In 1851-52, the roof was covered with tiles. The platform of the church including the main retablo was finished in 1853.Fr Agustin Perez, OAR (parish priest ca 1877-91) is credited with having completed the church: the roof tiles were replaced with zinc sheets, the marble baptismal font was bought, and the main altar was repaired. The epistle and gospel-side altars were donated by Don Jose Gloria and Don Agustin Medina respectively; the tabernacle of white marble was donated by Doña Manuela Segovia. The bell tower was partially built in 1882-83.
The Columbans replaced the Recollects after 1898. Fr Dennis Egan built the present convent in 1955. Masinloc was ceded to the diocesan clergy in 1988.

Much of the original interior of the church, including a noteworthy carved wooden statue of San Andres Apostol, has been lost through time. However, the portal that used to connect the choir loft with the old convent has retained its polychrome and is the most interesting and unique feature of the church.

The parish church of San Andres was declared a National Cultural Treasure by the National Museum of the Philippines on 31 Jul 2001. Damaged by the earthquake of 12 Dec 1999, rescue restoration was completed in 2007. The polychromed portal was restored in 2012-13.  Written by Mary Rajelyn J. Busmente, with notes from René B. Javellana and Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Prewar Manila Metropolitan Theater facade

(Leo Cloma Collection)

text:
Also known as Manila Metropolitan Theater. Location: Ermita, Manila. Inaugurated 1931, reinaugurated 1978. Architect: Juan Arellano, 1931; Otilio Arellano, 1978.

“On Wings of Song” was the phrase that inspired Juan Arellano when he designed the Metropolitan Theater. When the building was inaugurated on 10 Dec 1931, with a program that included music, drama, and film, it was hailed as another monumental masterpiece by the gifted architect. Arellano had designed the Legislative Building and the Post Office Building, both in the neoclassic style. The Metropolitan Theater was stunningly different. A. V. H. Hartendorp, editor of Philippine Magazine, described it as “modern expressionistic.” It was in fact one of Arellano’s romantic works, and was influenced by art deco, then in its heyday. While the nearby Legislative and Post Office Buildings were stately and monochromatic, the Metropolitan Theater was festive and colorful.

 

The site was an 8,393.58-square-meter lot in the Mehan Gardens, between Burgos Ave and Arroceros St, which had been leased by the City of Manila to the Metropolitan Theater Company. The one million pesos needed for the project was raised by public subscription. Arellano was sent to the United States to study with Thomas W. Lamb, an American expert in theater design.

The front of the theater was crowned by a wall gently curved at the top, against which rise a series of pinnacles. The entrance resembled a theater proscenium. On the lower half were doors with iron grills depicting stylized birds of paradise, and on the upper half was a large window of colored glass. This exterior proscenium was set against undulating walls decorated with brilliantly colored batik patterns.

The two-story lobby, with wide stairways at each end and a balcony overlooking the entrance, was the elegant setting for Fernando Amorsolo’s murals The Dance and History of Music, and the Italian sculptor Francesco Monti’s modern statues. The theater proper was flanked by garden courts around which were two-story buildings housing the ballroom, restaurant, offices, and shops.

The original capacity of the auditorium was 1,670: 846 in the orchestra, 708 in the balcony, and 116 in the loge. Enshrined above the proscenium were figures depicting Music, Tragedy, Comedy, and Poetry, set amid an array of jewel-like plaques. Adorning the plain walls were lamps, tall tapering tubes of translucent glass in the form of bamboo stalks. On the ceiling was a luxuriant array of tropical fruits and foliage. Hartendorp described the acoustics as “faultless” and the lighting as “excellent.”

The auditorium was destroyed in the last days of World War II, and its subsidiary buildings were used by various establishments. The building was restored under the supervision of Otilio Arellano, a nephew of Juan Arellano, and was inaugurated on 4 Feb 1978. The Metropolitan functioned up to the end of the Marcos era in 1986. It ran into financial problems but continued operation until it closed in the 1980s. Abandoned for a number of years, the Metropolitan was taken over by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2015.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Side view of Miag-ao Church, ca 1970

(Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Facade details of Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva in Miag-ao, Iloilo, 2013

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda,Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva. Location: Miag-ao, Iloilo. Built 1786-97.

The mission station of Miag-ao was declared an independent parish in 1731, at the same time that a simple church and convent were constructed. The town possibly got its name from the plant called miagos or mayagos which used to be abundant in the place. Its residents supported themselves through fishing, agriculture, salt-making, cattle raising, copra-making, and especially weaving.

The town located on a plateau by the sea was burned along with its church by pirates in 1741. A second church was burned during another such raid, probably in 1754. These events led the authorities and the Augustinian parish priest to transfer the town site to the edge of a hill, named Tacas, overlooking the sea and the Miag-ao River. The church was planned as a fortress in which the populace could take refuge during succeeding raids. Construction of the present building began in 1786. The foreman of the construction, a native from the nearby town of Igbaras, is remembered only as Matias. Later recalled to his hometown to build a church there, Matias was replaced by a certain Aquino, a resident of Alimodian, another nearby town. A yellow-orange sandstone was the primary building material. The splendid church was completed in 1797 and has since then withstood all the earthquakes and typhoons that have ravaged Panay, including the calamitous earthquake of 1948 which ruined many of the island’s finest churches. The interior was burned twice: in 1898 during the Philippine Revolution against Spain and again a few years later, during the Philippine-American War. A third story was added to the right tower in 1830, which still did not raise it to the level of the four-story left tower. There is logic in the left tower being taller since it commands a magnificent view of the sea.

 

The squatness of the church, the massive pair of bell towers flanking the facade and doubling as lookout posts, and the angled buttresses, all identify the structure as a redoubtable fortress. With its sumptuously worked facade, carved tassel decorations on the cornices of the bell towers, and rocaille-festooned window frames, Miag-ao is the best example of a type of church known as “fortress baroque.” Moreover, its facade sums up the Filipino’s transformation of Western decorative ideas. The pediment features San Cristobal clad like a farmer with rolled-up trousers, carrying the Santo Niño on his back and holding on to a lush coconut tree for support. They are flanked by guava and papaya trees, and ornamental urns adopted from viñetas, decorative cliches in engraved books. The cornice separating the pediment and the lower facade is interrupted by two windows and the central niche containing the patron saint. This niche, framed by fern-like C-scrolls, also bisects the Doric frieze which surprisingly appears in this rococo-like arrangement—Doric motifs were rarely used in Philippine colonial churches. The frieze supports a blind balustrade, but the frieze is not supported by a logical system of pilasters. Moreover, it does not extend along the entire width of the pediment. Swaying secondary cornices over the two tower niches give the illusion that the facade projects in an undulating manner. Rocaille decorations flank the central portion of the facade and are intimated on other details.

 

Restoration work was undertaken in 1959 and in the late 1970s. However, the crenellations above the traceries marking the tiers of the towers were overlooked in these restorations. Some windows were also converted into side entrances to facilitate passage in and out the church. In recent years, a new and quasi-baroque retablo was installed. The Marillac Academy to the right of the church has taken up some of what was originally part of the church plaza.

A marker was installed in 1963 by the then Philippine Historical Committee and the church declared a National Historical Landmark in 1973. In 1993, the UNESCO inscribed Miag-ao Church in the World Heritage List together with three other Philippine baroque churches. Following a detailed engineering study in 2003, the church underwent cleaning and repair in 2010.

Aside from the church, Miag-ao has two other notable Spanish-era structures—the bridge called Taytay Boni and the cemetery.

Taytay Boni was constructed in 1854. Located about a kilometer east of the poblacion, it was named after its construction foreman. The bridge, of stone similar to that of the church, has newel-posts topped by cone-shaped finials. With no more river running below it, the bridge has been converted into a promenade.

The cemetery was transferred to its present site in Cota Baybay in 1857. Commissioned by Fr Maximo Gonzales, its octagonal chapel and perimeter walls are of bricks and coral stone.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose, with notes from Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

 

Sources

Fernandez, Juan, OSA. 2006. Monografias de los Pueblos de la Isla de Pan-ay. Iloilo City: University of San Agustin Publishing House.

Jamerlan, Eugene. 2011. “Miagao Church.” BluPrint Magazine. Article posted at www.g1d.me/miagao-church, Mar 2013.

photos.desc:
Church of Santa Monica in Minalin, Pampanga, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santa Monica. Location: Minalin, Pampanga. Built ca 1834, reconstructed 1854.

Until 1614, Minalin was a visita (mission chapel) of Macabebe. In 1618, the Augustinian Miguel de Saldana was sent to minister to the town.

The Minalin Church stands on the bank of a creek. It is not known exactly how long the church has stood there nor which Augustinian friar built it. However, the church was most likely built in 1834. It was repaired and redecorated by Isidro Bernardo in 1877. There are records of minor repairs done by Gala de la Fuente in 1855 and Vicente Ruiz in 1895. The old brickwork was restored in the 1990s.

 

The facade resembles a retablo accentuated by Corinthian columns and flanked by twin hexagonal belfries. Floral carvings arching over the main door and the window above it add baroque detail. The two-level pediment is shaped like a truncated triangle, with clear divisions between the levels. Balustrades adorn the pediment sides. What used to hold a templete (an urn at the apex of the pediment), which once lighted the path of fisherfolk, is now a lantern-like bell tower. Capillas posas (small oratories) of stone, now rare in the whole country, are found in the church patio. Inside the church is an ornate wooden tabernacle and a retablo of San Agustin and Santa Monica.  Written by Monica P. Consing

photos.desc:
Church of Santa Ana in Molo, Iloilo, 2013

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santa Ana. Location: Molo, Iloilo. Built 1831.

Molo was a parian (Chinese community), one of several established by the Spaniards in certain large towns to restrict the movements of Chinese businessmen involved in the lucrative textile industry of the late 18th and early 19th centuries. The introduction of sugar as a commercial export crop during the mid-19th century further consolidated the hold of the Chinese on Iloilo’s retail trade. The parish of Molo, run by the secular clergy, was established in 1795 for the Christianized Chinese. During the 19th century a large church was built, probably to replace an earlier one built around the time of the parish’s foundation.

 

Molo Church is the best known of the secular clergy’s architectural works. It was built in 1831 during the incumbency of Pablo Montano and completed under Agapito Buenaflor. Jose Manuel Locsin, a local builder, supervised construction. The church combines neo-Gothic and neoclassic motifs. The facade is tall and narrow, flanked by bell towers on either side which terminate in high-pitched roofs with Gothic finials. However, instead of a lancet arch for an entrance, a Roman arch leads to the church’s vestibule and its arcaded nave. True to the mixture of styles, the arcade’s columns terminate in Corinthian capitals. These columns were originally made of carved hardwood, but around 1987 these were changed to cement replicas. The columns are decorated with statues of female saints, earning Molo the reputation of being the church of women saints in consonance with its patron, Santa Ana, mother of the Virgin Mary. The colonnade divides the church into three—a central nave and two aisles. The colonnade terminates in retablos in the neo-Gothic style, built ca 1930 by an unknown carver from Cebu. The central retablo houses the image of the patroness Santa Ana. The varnished retablos show the natural colors of wood and contrast sharply with other neo-Gothic altars, like those in the church of Maribojoc, Bohol and the San Sebastian Church, which are polychromed and gilded. The semicircular dome covering the sanctuary is painted with biblical scenes.

At the transept crossing, a pair of pulpits in the neo-Gothic style have been built facing each other. The precise liturgical use for this arrangement remains obscure but it has been suggested that this was for the dramatic reading of the Passion of the Lord during Holy Week. The church is well maintained, the gilding and varnishing of its altars have been refurbished but there has been no noticeable or major change in the church’s structure.

Molo church was designated a National Historical Landmark by the National Historical Institute in 1992.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Church and convento of San Geronimo in Morong, Rizal, 2014

(Mariano Sayno)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of San Geronimo Church complex. Location: Morong, Rizal. Built ca 1615, renovated, 1850-53 and 1966. Builder: Bartolome Palatino.

Morong parish traces its origins to the pioneers Fr Juan de Plasencia and Fr Diego de Oropesa, OFM, who erected a cross on the northeastern shore of Laguna in 1578. For lack of Franciscan missionaries, Morong did not have a resident priest until 1586 when Fr Blas de la Madre de Dios was assigned to Morong. He gathered people together in a reduccion (controlled settlement) and formally established Morong. Morong would play a central role in the towns along the eastern coast of Laguna so that on 23 Feb 1853 it was constituted capital of a district with the same name. That district was renamed Rizal in the American period.

 

The present church was built ca 1615 by Chinese masons who laid its foundations on a rock, some 10 m in height from the level of the town and the river that divides it. An earlier church, located on the opposite side of the river, was burned in 1612 with the rest of the town. The church fabric seems to have lasted for more than two centuries because there are no reports of it being destroyed or repaired until the 19th century when Bartolome Palatino from Paete worked with Fr Maximo Rico, OFM, to create a new facade. Paired columns mark the central portion, and single columns mark the sides. Above the main entrance, shaped as a Roman arch, is the window of the choir loft. Above that is a window corresponding to the third story. Both windows are flanked by pilasters and crowned by ornamented lintels. To either side of the main entrance and the choir loft are ornamented blind windows. A frieze of dentils defines the division between stories. The octagonal bell tower is pierced by windows on all sides and crowned by a dome, on top of which is a cross. Twin columns decorate the sides of the octagon. The bell tower and the lower two stories are linked by a decorative balustrade. This facade, decorated with the symbol and image of San Geronimo touching the head of a Chinese lion has been called an excellent expression of Philippine baroque.

A pair of granite Chinese lions also flank the beginning of the road ascending to the church. Some of the stone statuary from the facade that had been damaged have been removed and are found in a garden along the gospel side of the apse. In front of the church is an elevated patio with a low adobe fence from colonial times, decorated at set points with pyramidal finials topped by spheres. On the side of the fence across from the facade is inscribed “Año de 1696”.

The church is shaped like a cross. Although greatly renovated after 1965, the interior has retained some of its original ornamentation and design. Noteworthy are the corbels shaped as crocodile heads supporting the choir loft. Also to be noted are the painted Stations of the Cross, the paintings of the evangelists at the pendentives supporting the cupola, and the bas-relief of Christ’s baptism in the baptistry. It is uncertain when the adjoining convento on the nave’s gospel side was built but details of construction suggest that it or part of it may be as old as the church. The nave is pierced by openings, some serving as tribunas or balconies that are accessible through the convento. One narrow opening previously functioned as the way to the pulpit, which is now missing. Such an arrangement is found in another Franciscan church, Pakil. The pulpit was accessed through the convento, rather than through the body of the church because in colonial times it was common to have a preacher other than the priest presiding at Mass. Usually, the preacher was someone well versed in the local vernacular. A room at the bottom floor of the convento has been remodeled as a Blessed Sacrament Room.

article.value: Roman Catholic Parish of San Geronimo Church complex. Location: Morong, Rizal. Built ca 1615, renovated, 1850-53 and 1966. Builder: Bartolome Palatino.

Morong parish traces its origins to the pioneers Fr Juan de Plasencia and Fr Diego de Oropesa, OFM, who erected a cross on the northeastern shore of Laguna in 1578. For lack of Franciscan missionaries, Morong did not have a resident priest until 1586 when Fr Blas de la Madre de Dios was assigned to Morong. He gathered people together in a reduccion (controlled settlement) and formally established Morong. Morong would play a central role in the towns along the eastern coast of Laguna so that on 23 Feb 1853 it was constituted capital of a district with the same name. That district was renamed Rizal in the American period.

photos.desc:
Church of San Francisco de Asis in Naga, Cebu, 2013

(Michael Ocaña)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Francisco de Asis. Location: Naga, Cebu. Built 1839.

Naga was originally a visita (mission chapel) of San Nicolas. In 1829, it was raised to a parish and placed under the patronage of San Francisco de Asis. The church was built in 1839 by Fr Simon Aguirre. The church is cruciform in plan, with a nave 75 m long and 16 m wide, and a transept 32 m long. The bell tower, 18 m high, stands apart from the church. The present bell tower was built in 1974 to replace the original bell tower destroyed in 1942. The walls of the church are of blocks of coral stone. The facade is plastered. Buttresses of almost vertical slant support the sidewalls. Pilasters in the interior correspond to the buttresses. The windows are semicircular arches. Above each window is a small round window 60 cm in diameter. The buttresses just behind the facade and at the ends of the transept rise above the height of the walls, becoming turrets with four-sided curved tops that evoke onion-shaped roofs.

 

A pre-World War II photograph shows a facade with a triangular pediment. The ends of the present pediment that slope up to half its height appear to be portions of the earlier structure. The upper half of the portion of the pediment is a rectangular wall that rises slightly in the middle to form a not-too-prominent peak. The facade is divided into two horizontal sections: the lower, with few adornments; and the upper, profusely decorated. The portal, which has a shallow triangular arch, dominates the lower half of the facade. Its spandrels are adorned with floral designs. On each side of the portal is a pair of pilasters, and near each end of the wall is a pilaster. The narrow strip above the portal, which is on the level of the capitals of the pilasters, is crowded with carved ornaments. The upper half of the facade has two horizontal sections: the lower portion, which is pierced by square windows at each end; and the upper portion, which forms the pediment. The lower portion has a shallow niche in the middle with coupled columns on each side. In the niche is a circle on which stands a cross with rays. The columns rest on grotesque-looking human heads. The windows are flanked by single columns resting on heads. The sections of the wall between the windows and the niche and the sections extending beyond the windows are divided into four horizontal bands of varying height. The uppermost has floral and tendril forms. The band directly below it has vertical grooves set between rosettes. On the frieze under this are angels with musical instruments. On the lowest band are floral decorations within frames.

The pediment has three horizontal sections, narrowest below and becoming wider towards the top. The two lower sections are divided by six columns, three on each side of the niche which is located in the center on the same vertical line with the portal and the emblem above it. In the niche is an image. In the lower section, the space between columns is occupied by images of angels. In the section above, eight-pointed stars are attached to the middle of the columns. In the uppermost portion, namely, the rectangular section of the pediment, the eight-pointed stars are afloat. Adorning the raking cornice are leaf-like forms.

While various sources describe features of Naga Church as Muslim, Aztec, and Mexican, the basis for such descriptions is vague. This church is unique and its uniqueness exemplifies the Filipino predilection for ornament, particularly the eclectic. Which part belongs to the original 19th-century structure and which part is the product of 20th-century renovation is yet to be determined through serious study. The church was slightly damaged by the earthquake in Oct 2013 but was subsequently repaired.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Mortuary chapel of the 19th-century Nagcarlan Cemetery, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

Church of San Bartolome Apostol in Nagcarlan, Laguna, 1993

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Outer walls of the 19th-century Nagcarlan Cemetery, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
Catholic Parish Church of San Bartolome Apostol. Location: Nagcarlan, Laguna. Church built in 1752, renovated 1845; cemetery in 1845 built by Fr Vicente Belloc, OFM.

In 1571, Juan de Salcedo was sent to pacify the inhabitants of Nagcarlan aka Nagcarlang. After a brief resistance, the inhabitants, together with those of nearby Majayjay, capitulated to Spanish rule. In 1578, evangelization commenced with Frs Juan de Plasencia and Diego de Oropesa, OFM. In 1583, Fr Tomas de Miranda organized the town and introduced the cultivation of wheat at the same time. As was customary, a church of perishable material may have been constructed then. A stone church, the present one, was constructed in 1752 under the direction of Fr Cristobal Torres, OFM; this was damaged by fire in 1781. Fr Atanasio de Agrobrejo, OFM, repaired it immediately, but it was his successor, Fr Fernando de la Puebla, OFM, who completed it and also built a four-story bell tower.

 

In 1845, Fr Vicente Belloc, OFM, renovated the church’s woodwork, painted it, and added ornaments to it. He then renovated the choir loft by raising three strong arches of cut stone upon which the choir rested. He covered the central aisle and decorated the main nave, presbytery, and baptistry with azulejos (glazed tile).

The church facade appears to trace back to 1752 as Belloc’s renovation was less than total. It is a good example of a Philippine interpretation of baroque. Pealing stucco reveals that the facade and the nave are built of alternating layers of adobe and brick. Thus, a pleasing striped pattern has emerged. Flanking the facade is the octagonal bell tower—this is unusual for being of equal dimension throughout, while the more common type is of diminishing dimensions. The side entrance is flanked by Corinthian columns, while a conch decorates the arch’s capstone. Above the doorway is an ovoid niche, surrounded by foliage and surmounted by a cherub’s face. In one niche is an image of San Juan Bautista. The church retablo has a solid silver image of San Diego de Alcala, a rarity in Philippine iconography, and bas-reliefs, one of them depicting the power of Mary’s intercession which she lavishes on devotees in a relief showing heaven and purgatory.

 

The contrast of styles is most apparent in the cemetery built by Belloc at the outskirts of the town. A quadrilateral fence of wrought iron set in a brick structure allows a vista of the mortuary chapel within. The chapel, made of bricks and stone, has a neoclassical facade and an underground crypt. Because of this crypt, the cemetery is popularly known as an “underground cemetery” when in fact most burials are aboveground in the niches built into the cemetery’s perimeter wall. The crypt niches are reserved for VIPs.

 

The whole interior was previously painted in the style that was in vogue in the later half of the 19th century.

Nagcarlan Church has been designated as House of Worship Level-II with marker by the National Historical Institute (NHI) since 1937. The cemetery was declared a National Historical Landmark through Presidential Decree No 260, on 1 Aug 1973, as amended by Law No 1505, on 11 Jun 1978, and was soon after restored by NHI.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Negros Occidental Capitol in Bacolod City, 2013

(www.juan-ted.com)

text:
Provincial Capitol of Negros Occidental. Location: Lacson St, Bacolod City. Built 1924-25. Architect: Attributed to Juan Arellano, who also designed the lagoon and open areas. Art deco statuary of a Filipina and a Filipino attributed to Guillermo Tolentino.

Three blocks north of the cathedral, bound by Gatuslao and Lacson Sts and North and South Capitol Sts is the Negros Occidental Provincial Capitol complex. This consists of the Capitol building, an artificial lagoon in a spacious park in front of it, and auxiliary government buildings south of the capitol.

 

The Capitol was built from 1924 to 1925, following the Beaux-Arts style favored by the city planner Daniel Burnham. The Bureau of Public Works, established to implement the modernization of infrastructure and the construction of government buildings, implemented the principles of Beaux-Arts by opting for the neoclassic style for civic buildings, thus setting a pattern for many provincial capitols. The Capitol survived World War II and continued to function as such for four decades after the war.

In 1993, a new provincial capitol was built on an adjacent lot along North Capitol St. The governor’s office was transferred to the new building and the central part of the capitol given to the judiciary. With the construction of a new hall of justice, the capitol’s central portion was transformed into the Negros Museum. The museum, which highlights the history and the life of the Negrenses, was opened on 16 Mar 1996. A campaign was launched to turn over the rest of the capitol to the museum but that did not happen. Instead, the provincial government turned over the former Agriculture Building on Gatuslao St and expanded it by building a new annex. Negros Museum transferred to this space in May 2003 and has remained there since. The capitol reverted to the Office of the Governor, who returned the office to its historical location, while auxiliary provincial services remained in the 1993 office.

The capitol is laid out as an E. A three-story colonnade crowned by Corinthian capitals, forming a loggia, accentuates the central section. On either side of this central portion, wings run parallel and come to a stop at wings built perpendicular to the central structure. Entrance to the capitol is through wide stairs equal in width to the loggia. Three entrances lead to the central lobby. Directly in front of the entrances, twin staircases in tropical hardwood lead to the main session hall on the second floor. Flanked by office spaces, long and spacious corridors to either side of the lobby lead to the perpendicular wings.

From the second floor, secluded and narrow flights of stairs lead to an upper gallery, corresponding to the attic in the neoclassical design, from which visitors can watch the proceedings of the provincial board.

Facing east and outward of the loggia, a parking lot, a grassy lawn, and an artificial quadrilateral lagoon complement the capitol, adding to its grandeur. Sculptures decorating the capitol building and the adjacent lagoon are attributed to Guillermo Tolentino, National Artist for sculpture. The Homage to Agriculture fountain was made by Francesco Riccardo Monti in collaboration with Arch Juan Arellano.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Source

Herrera, Ma. Victoria T. 2005. Francesco Riccardo Monti in the Philippines. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Museum of Arts and Sciences.

Pacific Commercial Company Building, 1968

(American Geographical Society Library, John Tewell Collection)

text:
Also known as FNCB Building. Location: Juan Luna St corner Muelle de la Industria, Binondo, Manila. Completed 1922. Architects: Murphy, McGill and Hamlin.

Completed toward the end of 1922, the Pacific Commercial Company Building (PCCB) was designed by Murphy, McGill, and Hamlin of New York and Shanghai, represented on the ground by H. H. Keys. Oscar F. Campbell was the contractor and S. D. Rowlands, the structural engineer. The building stands on the site of the Hospital de San Gabriel established by Fr Miguel de Benavides, OP, in 1596, and considered to be the best hospital in Asia until its closure in the 18th century.

 

The PCCB housed the International Banking Corporation on the ground floor and the Pacific Commercial Company on the rest of the floors from the second to the sixth, its topmost. The neo-Renaissance ground floor was fully rusticated in the banded rustication style. It had arched openings with fanlights emphasized by stones forming the arch. The main doors were adorned with lintels resting on consoles. The second, third, and fourth floors were integrated together with Ionic columns. These six columns dominating the south and west facades were in turn flanked by a pair of pilasters on both fronts. Above these columns is an entablature topped by a cornice. The fifth floor is recessed, also topped by an entablature and crowned all over by a band of classical motifs.

The building featured many firsts in Manila such as smooth, white plastering on the walls and moulded plaster of paris on the ceiling of the first floor. Many rooms were furnished with glass sides. A special type of window sash was installed throughout the building, thus eliminating earlier types of wooden construction and affording perfect ventilation and protection against the elements. All doors were made of heavy Philippine hardwood. The floors were laid with thick battleship linoleum. Durostone, a mixture recently available then, was used to finish the ground floor walls. The building’s thresholds and ornamental slabs were of marble.

The PCCB was also equipped with the latest comforts like the most modern plumbing and elevators with automatic safety doors servicing up to the fifth floor. A pumping plant working with compressed air carried water to the sixth floor. The building later housed the First National City Bank of New York. In 1936, it was bought by Jorge Araneta and Gil Montilla for 1,750,000 pesos and later sold to the Ayala and Company for two million pesos.

In 2013, the PCCB was restored and retrofitted under the direction of Arch Augusto Villalon with the assistance of Arch Melvin Patawaran. An additional floor was added to the building, making it seven levels. Planned to house business process outsourcing (BPO) companies or call centers, a continuously growing industry in the country today, it is now called Juan Luna E-Services Building.  Written by Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

 

Source

article.value: Also known as FNCB Building. Location: Juan Luna St corner Muelle de la Industria, Binondo, Manila. Completed 1922. Architects: Murphy, McGill and Hamlin.

Completed toward the end of 1922, the Pacific Commercial Company Building (PCCB) was designed by Murphy, McGill, and Hamlin of New York and Shanghai, represented on the ground by H. H. Keys. Oscar F. Campbell was the contractor and S. D. Rowlands, the structural engineer. The building stands on the site of the Hospital de San Gabriel established by Fr Miguel de Benavides, OP, in 1596, and considered to be the best hospital in Asia until its closure in the 18th century.

(American Geographical Society Library, John Tewell Collection)

article.value: The PCCB housed the International Banking Corporation on the ground floor and the Pacific Commercial Company on the rest of the floors from the second to the sixth, its topmost. The neo-Renaissance ground floor was fully rusticated in the banded rustication style. It had arched openings with fanlights emphasized by stones forming the arch. The main doors were adorned with lintels resting on consoles. The second, third, and fourth floors were integrated together with Ionic columns. These six columns dominating the south and west facades were in turn flanked by a pair of pilasters on both fronts. Above these columns is an entablature topped by a cornice. The fifth floor is recessed, also topped by an entablature and crowned all over by a band of classical motifs.

The building featured many firsts in Manila such as smooth, white plastering on the walls and moulded plaster of paris on the ceiling of the first floor. Many rooms were furnished with glass sides. A special type of window sash was installed throughout the building, thus eliminating earlier types of wooden construction and affording perfect ventilation and protection against the elements. All doors were made of heavy Philippine hardwood. The floors were laid with thick battleship linoleum. Durostone, a mixture recently available then, was used to finish the ground floor walls. The building’s thresholds and ornamental slabs were of marble.

The PCCB was also equipped with the latest comforts like the most modern plumbing and elevators with automatic safety doors servicing up to the fifth floor. A pumping plant working with compressed air carried water to the sixth floor. The building later housed the First National City Bank of New York. In 1936, it was bought by Jorge Araneta and Gil Montilla for 1,750,000 pesos and later sold to the Ayala and Company for two million pesos.

In 2013, the PCCB was restored and retrofitted under the direction of Arch Augusto Villalon with the assistance of Arch Melvin Patawaran. An additional floor was added to the building, making it seven levels. Planned to house business process outsourcing (BPO) companies or call centers, a continuously growing industry in the country today, it is now called Juan Luna E-Services Building.  Written by Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

text:
Also known as Paco Park. Location: Paco, Manila. Begun 1823, expanded 1859. Architect: Nicolas Ruiz.

During the 19th century, with the growing awareness on how diseases spread, cemeteries were constructed on the outskirts of cities and towns, away from the populated centers. A cemetery was built at Dilao (now Paco), just before the cholera epidemics of the 1820s. No sooner was it built than it became the burial grounds of many cholera victims. The cemetery was planned as one circle of stonewalls enclosing a patio. It was designed by maestro de obras (master builder) Nicolas Ruiz, and construction supervised by Jose Coll. In 1859, Gov-Gen Fernando de Norzagaray proposed the extension of the cemetery, resulting in a second wall of stone and giving the cemetery its characteristic concentric circular stonewalls enclosing a patio. A Chinese contractor won the bid to build the outer wall for 19,700 pesos. Into the walls were built niches for the dead: the inner wall for Spaniards, and the outer wall for Filipinos. The niches were put up for rent at 20 pesos for three years, renewable.

 

The cemetery had an arched entrance crowned by a triangular pediment and decorated in the neoclassical manner. Built along the same lines as the entrance was an elliptical mortuary chapel with a vaulted roof of stone. Behind the chapel and projecting from the stone walls was an enclosed area reserved for children called angelitos, and another for exhumed bones called osario. To either side of the chapel were elegant stairways of stone. These led to the top of the niches and were decorated with balustrades so that promenaders could walk above.

 

The national hero Jose Rizal was temporarily interred in the Paco Cemetery, from 30 Dec 1896 to 17 Aug 1898, when his remains were exhumed to be eventually buried in the Rizal Monument at Luneta on 29 Dec 1912. His gravesite is now marked in the cemetery. The priests Gomez, Burgos, and Zamora were also buried in the outer circle, although the precise location of their graves is unknown. Interment in the cemetery ceased in 1912.

 

During World War II, the Japanese used the cemetery as central supply and ammunition depot. To defend themselves from American troops set to liberate Manila in 1945, the Japanese dug trenches and pillboxes around and within the park. They mounted 75-millimeter guns to defend their position.

After 1945, it was derelict until declared a National Park in 1966 under the term of Pres Diosdado Macapagal. It was then cleaned and restored in stages to make it a usable space. During the presidency of Ferdinand Marcos, Paco Park as it is now called was placed under the National Park’s Development Committee (NPDC). During restoration the remains of those interred were exhumed and transferred to other cemeteries, and the decorative balustrade and the stones of the walls restored. A fountain was built in the center of the patio—the area around it was paved. The mortuary chapel’s interior, now dedicated to San Pancracio, was lined with marble and a new altar was constructed. The church was placed under the care of the parish of San Marcelino under the Vincentians.

 

The park is a favorite place for promenades, classical concerts, painting sessions, and even weddings. On 29 Feb 1980, the Press and Cultural Attaché of the German embassy in the Philippines Dr Christoph Jessen and vice-chair of NPDC Teodoro Valencia organized a classical concert in the park as part of Philippine-German Month. The success of the concert initiated the weekly Friday concerts called Paco Park Presents.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

 

Source

Diaz-Trechuelo, Lourdes. 1959. Arquitectura Española en Filipinas (1565-1800). Sevilla: Escuela de Estudios Hispano-Americanos de Sevilla.

photos.desc:
Bas relief of Santiago on a horse, Paete Church, 1993

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Facade of the Church of Santiago in Paete, Laguna, 1993

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Interior of Paete Church, 1993

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of Santiago Apostol Church Complex. Location: Paete, Laguna. Built 1717 and later.

Paete, a town presently famous for its carvers, was founded by the Franciscans in 1580 as a visita (mission chapel) Lumban under the patronage of San Lorenzo. In 1600, it was transferred to the jurisdiction of Pangil. Two years later it became independent with Pedro de San Buenaventura as first resident missionary. The construction of the present church began in 1717 and continued for some years afterward, under the direction of Fr Francisco de la Fuente, OFM, and his successors. The convento was also constructed during this period. In 1840 and the succeeding years, the convento was totally renovated by Fr Luis de Nambroca, OFM, who also repaired and improved the church. Around this same time the Paeteño artist Jose Dans was commissioned to do two large panel paintings for the church: one of San Cristobal and another, popularly known as Heaven, Hell and Purgatory, of the Seven Sacraments as a gateway to salvation. The church bell tower lost its roof in a storm but was subsequently replaced by a wrought-iron structure at the turn of the century. The church was restored under the auspices of the National Historical Institute between the 1980s and the 1990s. The wrought-iron crown of the bell tower was removed and the lost pyramidal roof rebuilt, following old photographs.

 

Paete’s facade is the most florid of the Franciscan facades built along the Laguna lakeshore. Tapestry-like in design, its pediment, merely outlined, gives way to large windows. The image of Santiago is the focal point of the whole composition which is decorated by pilasters covered with large leaves and flowers. “The facade, though it has an echo of Spanish baroque, embodies something strange and foreign, different enough to serve as an example of what happens to the style when it gets into the hand of Asian craftsmen” (Kelemen 1969).

A third painting depicting San Miguel is by an unknown artist. The church originally had painted Stations of the Cross but these are now part of the Pagrel Collection in the San Agustin Museum in Intramuros.

 

The church has five retablos. The main one contained an old image of the patron saint, Santiago. The retablo to the left side has at its apex a bas-relief of Mary’s assumption. At the transept ends are retablos of different designs. At the left end is an image of the Santo Sepulcro, the dead Christ, flanked by saints. At the apex of the retablo at the right end is an image of the crucified Christ.

 

The choir loft is supported by corbels shaped as crocodile heads with scroll-like designs emanating from their mouths. The church was finished with a heavy covering of stucco which was used to great advantage when decorating the facade with graceful floral designs. However, in the recent process of restoration, the stucco has been removed, revealing buff-colored adobe beneath. Although the adobe gives a distinctive air to the facade, the removal of stucco has destroyed the finely wrought floral designs. A more recent faux pas in restoration has been the addition of resin-based stained glass. Restoration, though, has also fortunately uncovered an earlier painting of San Cristobal on stucco, hidden by the huge canvas of Dans. A new wooden ceiling was put in place. The walls and retablos have been cleaned.

In the 1990s, the gospel side entrance was embellished with papier-mache-like cement decorations of solomonic columns, decorated niches, volutes, and foliage. In 2013, restoration of the paintings of Dans began.

Paete was declared a National Historical Landmark by the National Historical Institute, which installed a marker in 1939.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Source

Kelemen, Pal. 1969. Art of the Americas: Ancient and Hispanic, With a Comparative Chapter on the Philippines. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Company.

photos.desc:
Church of San Pedro de Alcantara and Diocesan Shrine of Nuestra Señora de los Dolores de Turumba in Pakil, Laguna, 2016

(Vonna Vista)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of San Pedro de Alcantara Church Complex. Location: Pakil, Laguna. Built 1732-67.

Pakil was a former visita (mission chapel) of Paete, a few kilometers to the north. As a parish it was administered by the Franciscans. The first church was made of bamboo. The foundations of a stone structure were dug in 1732, and work continued for more than 30 years. The church and convento were finally completed in 1767. Enshrined in the church in 1788 was the image of Nuestra Señora de los Dolores, more popularly known as Turumba and presently honored with seven feasts beginning with Biyernes Dolores, the Friday before Palm Sunday. The convento was damaged in a fire that devastated most of Pakil in 1851. An earthquake in 1881 destroyed the bell tower and ceiling of the church. Another earthquake damaged the church in 1937. Repairs were done afterwards, but the topmost story of the bell tower was not reconstructed until 1980 to 1984.

The body of the church is made with alternating bands of yellow adobe and bricks, while the bell tower is made solely of bricks. The church is cruciform and with a shortened transept, as in the Tanay and Paete churches. Its ornamented facade is similar to that of others in the Laguna Lake towns, with Corinthian columns and floriated crosses in decorative frames flanking the main entrance. Angel heads are distributed on the facade and the bell tower. Above the main entrance is a niche with crosses, foliage, and a shell-like dome, containing a stone sculpture of the patron saint. The side entrance is decorated to appear like a retablo. This side door is known as the Portiuncula after the Franciscan mother church in Assisi. It was customary to have a Saturday morning procession in honor of the Virgin Mary, passing through this door. Anyone who joined the procession and passed the door earned an indulgence similar to what would be received by a pilgrim to Assisi.

 

The church has three retablos in the florid baroque style. The central retablo, four stories high, contains 11 niches. The central one displays the image of the Turumba. Columns are used throughout. The two side retablos, three-stories high, are mirror images of each other and are lushly covered with floral decorations and foliage. On the wall near the pulpit hangs a bas-relief of San Francisco de Asis receiving the stigmata of Christ on Mt Alverna, while the miracle of the Eucharist performed by San Antonio de Padua is on the opposite wall. This depicts a donkey kneeling before the Blessed Sacrament, preferring to adore the Sacrament rather than eat. Three other retablos are found in the church. The one at the epistle side of the nave immediately after entering the church door features a Calvary scene sprouting rococo motifs. The crucified Christ, one of the most expressionistic in the country, has articulated arms and is removed from the cross during Holy Week, cleaned, perfumed, dressed, and adorned with silver for the Good Friday procession of the Santo Entierro. The images of Mary and John are small and disproportionate to the Christ figure.

The two-story convento has a brick arcade that encloses a small garden. Stone steps covered with black-and-white tiles lead up to the second story. The upper story, with floors of molave, has corridors overlooking the garden. The convento has recently been restored, reinforced and returned to its use as a residence. A door adjacent to the gospel nave opens to steps that lead to the pulpit.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Niche and stone statue of Santa Monica in Pan-ay Church, 2013

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Church of Santa Monica in Pan-ay, Capiz, 2013

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santa Monica. Location: Pan-ay, Capiz. Built ca 1692, first reconstructed 1774, second reconstruction completed 1884.

This church stands on a swampland that was once so low that it would flood when the river overflowed, hence the name of the town, Pan-ay, meaning “mouth of the river.” In 1569, Miguel Lopez de Legaspi transferred the capital of the Spanish colony from Cebu to Pan-ay. The Augustinians took charge of Pan-ay. The first permanent building must have been up by ca 1692. The Augustinian Fr Manuel Lopez reported church damages after a typhoon in 1698. In 1774, Fr Miguel Murguia, OSA, rebuilt the church, which was struck by a violent typhoon a century later. Fr Jose Beloso, OSA, completed the second reconstruction in 1884, although the adjacent convento was never rebuilt. The church facade, built of finely cut coral, is an excellent example of the baroque merged with the classic. Shallow pilasters divide the first story, while two small deep niches balance the simple arched entrance of the church. The more ornate second story has fanciful niches, a rose window at the center, and a statue of Santa Monica in a niche below it. Pineapple-like finials punctuate the undulating pediment lines and flank another relief of a saint. Finely carved floral swags and leaves decorate all the niches and windows of the facade.

 

The floral swags that decorate the exterior are carried into the nave, whose floors are of white and black marble. The crossing tower is supported by four carved posts. A pulpit is attached to one of them. The five retablos, bas-relief, and statuary were carved by the town’s best sculptor, Bergano. The retablos are unique for their Biblical verses. The church has silver frontals made by Manila artisans. Pan-ay’s other claim to fame is the 10,400-kilogram-bell in the five-story belfry, standing to the left of the facade. A parish donation of 70 sacks of coins went into casting the Dakong Lingganay or Big Bell. A foundry was dug nearby for the project. In this same tower a clock has been attached. The topmost level of the bell tower was recently rebuilt. To the right of the church, by the ruins of the old convento, a new building has been constructed. In this building is a small museum that houses the treasures of the parish.

The National Museum of the Philippines declared Pan-ay a National Cultural Treasure in 1996 and the National Historical Institute declared it a National Historical Landmark in 1997. Since the declaration, the people of Pan-ay under the leadership of the parish priest of Santa Monica church have worked on refurbishing the church. The wooden roof frame, which had deteriorated, was replaced with a steel framework and the roof replaced by long-span galvanized iron. The plaza in front of the church, formerly a grassy field, was paved. The convento, which had been repaired a number of times, was remodeled to look like a bahay na bato (stone house).

 

Flooding behind the church was addressed by filling in low areas. All the effort at repair and refurbishing was given a harsh blow when, on 7 Nov 2013, Typhoon Yolanda (Haiyan) ran the breadth of the Visayas. Part of the church roof was damaged but by and large the damage to the church complex was not catastrophic.  Written by Monica P. Consing, with notes from René B. Javellana
