A parish donation of 70 sacks of coins went into casting the Dakong Lingganay or Big Bell. A foundry was dug nearby for the project. In this same tower a clock has been attached. The topmost level of the bell tower was recently rebuilt. To the right of the church, by the ruins of the old convento, a new building has been constructed. In this building is a small museum that houses the treasures of the parish.

The National Museum of the Philippines declared Pan-ay a National Cultural Treasure in 1996 and the National Historical Institute declared it a National Historical Landmark in 1997. Since the declaration, the people of Pan-ay under the leadership of the parish priest of Santa Monica church have worked on refurbishing the church. The wooden roof frame, which had deteriorated, was replaced with a steel framework and the roof replaced by long-span galvanized iron. The plaza in front of the church, formerly a grassy field, was paved. The convento, which had been repaired a number of times, was remodeled to look like a bahay na bato (stone house).

text:
Location: Placer, Surigao del Norte.

Panhutongan Archaeological Site is an ancient burial ground located within the Barangay Panhutongan Elementary School Compound. The land area is 400 sqm of sand deposit derived from the delta at the mouth of the Panhutongan River. This ancient burial ground is in a coastal sand dune enclosed by a stone structure with wooden posts, which has protected the site from sea waves for hundreds of years. Archaeological excavation undertaken by the National Museum revealed that the burial ground is a pit-grave where human skeletons were found in layers. The first layer was found associated with ornaments and implements, as well as ceramic trade wares dating from the 16th to 17th centuries AD (Ming Dynasty). Below this layer, another layer of human skeletons was found which had ornaments, metal and stone implements, and wooden coffins that could be traced back to AD 140. The wooden coffins were of two types: dug-out coffins that are rectangular and human-shaped following the outward contour of the human body, and bier-type coffins that consist of five planks of longitudinally cut wood. Funerary offerings or grave goods were found associated with human skeletons. During this period, it was customary for the early inhabitants who used this burial ground to bury the dead with items of their personal belongings. Valuable things that best identified the deceased were buried with the individual. A red glass bead was even found inside the mouth of one individual. A few intact Ming wares were found with five skeletons, while metal implements were found buried with all male and female individuals. In this grave, 66 human skeletons representing juvenile, adult, and old-aged individuals, both males and females, are represented. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of the skeletons and teeth show that they have mongoloid, negroid, and australoid traits (Bautista 2002, 56-88). The data gathered further revealed that a wide range of variability in physical attributes existed among the skeletons studied.  Written by Angel P. Bautista

 

Source

Bautista, Angel P. 2002. “Reconstruction of Human Skeletal Population in Panhutongan Site, Placer, Surigao Del Norte.” National Museum Papers 12, No 1.

photos.desc:
Church of San Agustin in Paoay, Ilocos Norte, 2012

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Buttresses of Paoay Church, 2016

(Rafael Fernando)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Agustin. Location: Paoay, Ilocos Norte. Started 1694, reinaugurated 1896.

Mentioned as early as 1593, Paoay began as a mission station of Batac, Ilocos Norte. It gained independence as a parish in 1686. Construction of the present church began in 1694. It was led by the Augustinian parish priest Antonio Estavillo who directed the people in cutting and transporting wood, fetching water, making bricks, and quarrying and dressing stones. Considering the immensity of the church, the completion date of 1702—according to one source—must refer only to the termination of a part of the building, most probably the apse. A longer testimony in 1710, listing the main and two side altars as well as the 16 buttresses, confirms that the church was substantially erected by then. The church was repaired in 1865 and again from 1889 to 1898. The reinauguration in 1896 was celebrated with fireworks.

 

The coral-stone bell tower, standing some distance from the church, was finished in the second half of the 18th century and substantially rebuilt in 1884. It was repaired with the church from 1889 to 1898. Its facade features rusticated pilasters on the second level, standing on the plain pilaster of the first level; this is the reverse of the usual order in Europe. The Paoay Church is perhaps the most outstanding Philippine variant of “earthquake baroque,” a term first used by Pal Kelemen in reference to South American churches. Its phalanx of buttresses is the most massive of its kind in the country. Fourteen are formed along the lines of a gigantic volute supporting a smaller one, surmounted in turn by pyramidal finials. These volutes appear again as miniature scroll forms along the stone wall enclosing the expansive patio. A pair of buttresses along the length of the nave have stairways, which were probably used when parts of the roof had to be repaired. The lower half of the apse and most of the walls were constructed of coral stone. The upper level is finished in brick. The order is reversed in the facade, with the heavier coral-stone blocks occupying the upper levels and the finials. Irregularly shaped blocks with carved floral decoration flank some entrances and may be remnants of an earlier building. On the facade the decorative carving is limited only to the uppermost levels, with the lower two-thirds a massive blank.

 

In 1993, Paoay was inscribed in the World Heritage List under the title “Baroque Churches of the Philippines.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Church of Santo Tomas Villanueva in Pardo, Cebu, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of Santo Tomas de Villanueva Church Complex. Location: Pardo, Cebu. Built 1880–1893. Architect: Domingo de Escondrillas.

Located some eight kilometers south of Cebu City, Pardo was established as a town in 1863 out of the merging of the barrios of Inayawan, Bulacao, and Basak. It became an independent parish on 10 Apr 1866 after it was separated from San Nicolas.

Plans for the church were drawn up through the efforts of Fr Meliton Talegon, OSA, parish priest from 1866 to 1873. Designed by Domingo Escondrillas of the public works office in Cebu, the architectural plan was approved in 1872. Fr Manuel Ybeas, OSA, who succeeded Talegon in 1873, started the construction in 1880 and completed the church in 1893. Renovations and modifications were carried out under succeeding parish priests, but the basic structure of the church remained.

The church’s walls are of coral stone and lime. The original roofing was of red-clay tiles with rafters of molave and apitong. This was replaced with galvanized iron and, presently, with colored zinc roofing.

 

The Pardo Church departs from the standard facade of Augustinian churches in Cebu. Vertical rows of small round windows recall the Byzantine style, also seen in Ginatilan, Cebu. Its belfry is integrated into the entire fortress-like structure, which is marked by a four-level belfry. The belfry is flanked on both sides by twin cylindrical towers capped with four-sided cupolas. The balustrades at the topmost level are not part of the original plan. There used to be a pointed cupola at the fourth level. Blind windows decorate the third level of the facade and the fourth level of the bell tower, whose pinnacle is crowned by a globe of solid wood mounted with a cross. An ojo de Dios (eye of divinity), formerly a rose window, now decorates the second level. On the ground level is the main arched door of the church. Four pairs of stilted windows and a pair of side-entrance doors allow ventilation from the side of the church.

The interior embellishments of the church are also not common to Augustinian churches in the province. The main door opens out to a single spacious nave, with a transept forming a cruciform before the main altar. In the original plan of 1872, this terminated in an apse in which the altar was located. Another unusual feature is the way diagonal walls link the ends of the transept with the apse on one end and the nave on the other. A similar arrangement is seen in other Cebuano churches such as Liloan and Mandaue. Space for the sacristy at the back of the altar lengthened the structure, now with a trapezoidal end. A dome rises above the crossing and another above the retablo mayor. There are side altars at the south and north wings of the church.

A late 19th-century structure, the Pardo Church was built at a time when building construction was already more strictly regulated by Church and state. Thus the church conforms to a plan, which is seen in the consistency of the design and execution of exterior and interior sections as well as in the standardization of embellishments.

Stone facings from the cylindrical towers flanking the facade fell due to the earthquake of 15 Oct 2013. Otherwise the church was saved from major damage.  Written by Paul Labrado, with notes from René B. Javellana and Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Perez-Samanillo Building, behind bahay na bato on the right, in prewar Escolta

(Leo Cloma Collection)

text:
Also known as First United Building. Location: Escolta, Manila. Built ca 1928. Architect: Andres Luna de San Pedro and Fernando Ocampo.

Constructed by Luna de San Pedro-Cortez Associates, the Luis Perez-Samanillo Building was the first building on the northwest end of the Escolta. It won first prize in the “commercial building category” in an architecture competition in 1928. With its main entrance facing the Escolta, it occupies a squarish area almost coinciding with the entire street block. However, it appears to be sprawling horizontally, the height of the six-floor structure a mere three-fourths of the length of all its four sides. Luna achieved the illusion of height using neo-Gothic design expedients, now interpreted along the art deco sensibility as stylized recessed rectilinear arches that are more ornamental than functional. These recessed rectilinear arch motifs are established on both the northwest and southwest corners of the building as facets facing the street corners obliquely. They are repeated at the Escolta side, with a wider central one, to dramatize the main entrance. The corner motifs rise as fluted pilasters from the second floor to the fifth floor and are topped by oval forms. The tops of the arches coincide with the sixth floor and are articulated as a five-sided pediment. Two lotus-bud stupas flank the pediment, the middle of which is a rectangular frame with an octagon at the center. The eaves of the first floor project over the pavement on both the north and west sides of the building. On the west side, the eaves curve up at the center to enhance the main entrance. The stories are decorated by stylized stringcourses interrupted only by the lines of the rising-arch motifs.

 

The building was acquired by Sy Lian Teng in 1976. The building has been restored recently, its lobby and elevator rehabilitated. It stands as an example of what well-thought conservation can do to preserve a building’s life and utility.  Written by Santiago A. Pilar

 

Sources

Geringer Art, Ltd. n.d. “Galo B. Ocampo.” http://www.geringerart.com/artists/galo-b-ocampo/

Tariman, Pablo A. 2013. “End of an Era? Curtain Call for Iconic Philam Theater.” Interaksyon. Posted 18 Mar. http://www.interaksyon.com/article/57385/end-of-an-era-curtain-call-for-iconic-philam-life

photos.desc:
Philippine-American Life Insurance Company Building in Manila, built in 1961

(CCP Collection)

text:
Location: Ermita, Manila. Completed 1961. Architect: Carlos Arguelles.

The Philippine-American Life Insurance (Philamlife) Building is located along United Nations Ave. Although one of the country’s best examples of the International Style, it has a distinct tropical character. Completed in 1961, it opened a new era in Philippine architecture, marked by the marriage of architecture and technology.

It is influenced by the sleek glass box of early 20th century modernism and characterized by native warmth and openness. The cantilevered entrance shell welcomes the visitor to the spacious lobby, and near it is a lush tropical garden.

The seven-story block occupied by offices towers over a sprawling one-story building which contains various public spaces, a lobby that can accommodate large art exhibits, and an auditorium notable for its elegance and excellent acoustics.

 

The seven-story building is sheathed in anti-glare, heat-absorbing, gray-tinted glass mounted on airtight anodized aluminum frames. Around these glass walls run horizontal aluminum sun baffles supported by pipes and mullions. The gray glass, gray metal, and the repeated horizontal lines produce a visually relaxing harmony. With all its lights on, the building becomes a giant lantern as entire ceilings are evenly illuminated with the aid of corrugated plastic diffusers.

With its walls visible all around, the auditorium is like an island in the lobby as it appears like a building within a building. The exterior of its walls is finished with richly colored Venetian-mosaic tiles.

It has a handsome theater lined with wood, which seats 779. Running along both sides of the auditorium are carved wooden murals about 2.5 m high, depicting the history of Filipino culture. These were designed by Jose Alcantara and carved by artisans from the Mountain Province.

The building rests on a flat slab almost 2 m thick, poured over 4,000 hardwood piles. The total floor area of the building is 3 ha, which, at that time of its construction, made it the largest in Southeast Asia.

The excellent acoustics of the auditorium were engineered by Bolt, Beranek and Newman Inc, now Raytheon BBN Technologies. This American technology company was behind the acoustics of the Cultural Center of the Philippines , Sydney Opera House, and United Nations Assembly Hall in New York. The historic theater was host to a number of performances by both local and international artists, including opera icon Renata Tebaldi, the great contralto Marian Anderson, tenor Otoniel Gonzaga, and pianist Cecile Licad.

In 2012, when Philamlife prepared to move to its new headquarters at Bonifacio Global City, the property was sold to the SM Development Corporation. The area is intended to be converted into a residential complex, although the auditorium will allegedly be incorporated into the new structure.

Meanwhile, the seven large format paintings of National Artist Vicente Manansala, which used to hang in the lobby of the building, are now on long-term loan to the National Museum (NM). Commissioned in 1961, these masterpieces of transparent cubism were conserved before being put on display at the Philam Life Hall of the National Museum of Fine Arts in P. Burgos St, Manila. The works of Paete woodcarvers from the building are supposed to be saved by Philamlife. A sarimanok in stained glass by Galo B. Ocampo, which enlivened one corner of the lobby, is now displayed at the lobby of Philamlife’s new headquarters. Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

photos.desc:
Art noveau Mariano Uy-Chaco Building, built 1914, now Philtrust Bank Building in Escolta

(CCP Collection)

text:
Location: Binondo, Manila. Built 1914. Architect: Samuel C. Rowell.

This building was formerly owned by the Uy-Chaco family and was known by that family name until its purchase by the Philtrust Bank. It was designed and constructed by the architect Samuel C. Rowell in 1914. A picture reproduced in Nov 1914 shows it almost finished except for the roof of the projecting turret on its northeastern corner which was its most striking feature. Spared by the World War II bombings on nearby Escolta St, it underwent renovations in the mid-1970s which resulted in obscuring its jugendstil (art nouveau) features. Except for these remodeled features, the rest of the original structure is almost intact.

It is a six-story building with eight bays, located at the southeastern corner of the former Plaza Cervantes. The bays are distinctly defined; each consists of arches on the first floor that support the structure and a slightly projecting curved balcony on the third, fourth, and fifth floors. The projecting balconies were decorated with ornate iron railings, now almost covered with cement. The rustication of the arches on the first floor gives the facade a conservative appearance, as did the original treatment of the sixth floor. In old pictures of the Uy-Chaco, it is seen that the first and second bays on the southeastern corner were designed as equipment rooms; thus, like the rest of the sixth floor, they were entirely walled and furnished with glass windows. The eighth bay, the one closest to the projecting corner, repeated the same pattern as the first and second bays. However, the sixth floor of the third to the seventh bay was designed as a portico featuring more traditional balustrades. This portico and the rustication of the first floor recall Renaissance palazzos.

 

The projecting rounded corner gave the Uy-Chaco Building the appearance of a French chateau. The uppermost floor of this corner was covered by a ribbed conical dome roofed with iron tiles. This was originally crowned by a globe surmounted by an eagle, now replaced by a spire. This floor featured at least two French windows opening to a veranda that encircled the room. The semicircular shape of the corner is emphasized by the curving railings. The roof was sectioned, defined by ribs. Rising from the eaves is a gabled roof featuring round clocks instead of windows.

The Uy-Chaco Building (now Philtrust) was eclectic in design. article.value: Location: Binondo, Manila. Built 1914. Architect: Samuel C. Rowell.

This building was formerly owned by the Uy-Chaco family and was known by that family name until its purchase by the Philtrust Bank. It was designed and constructed by the architect Samuel C. Rowell in 1914. A picture reproduced in Nov 1914 shows it almost finished except for the roof of the projecting turret on its northeastern corner which was its most striking feature. Spared by the World War II bombings on nearby Escolta St, it underwent renovations in the mid-1970s which resulted in obscuring its jugendstil (art nouveau) features. Except for these remodeled features, the rest of the original structure is almost intact.

It is a six-story building with eight bays, located at the southeastern corner of the former Plaza Cervantes. The bays are distinctly defined; each consists of arches on the first floor that support the structure and a slightly projecting curved balcony on the third, fourth, and fifth floors. The projecting balconies were decorated with ornate iron railings, now almost covered with cement. The rustication of the arches on the first floor gives the facade a conservative appearance, as did the original treatment of the sixth floor. In old pictures of the Uy-Chaco, it is seen that the first and second bays on the southeastern corner were designed as equipment rooms; thus, like the rest of the sixth floor, they were entirely walled and furnished with glass windows. The eighth bay, the one closest to the projecting corner, repeated the same pattern as the first and second bays. However, the sixth floor of the third to the seventh bay was designed as a portico featuring more traditional balustrades. This portico and the rustication of the first floor recall Renaissance palazzos.

photos.desc:
Foundation of the Piñero House with two dozen molave posts

(Philippine Ancestral Houses: 1810-1930 by Fernando Zialcita and Martin Tinio, GCF Books, 1980)

text:
Oldest documented bahay na bato (stone house). Location: Possibly Legazpi St, Intramuros, Manila. Built: ca mid-17th century

A will of Doña Isabel Navarro de Piñero dated 1699, a copy of which was kept in the Dominican Archives, describes a house in Intramuros, Manila. This house is so far the oldest documented in the country. Its architectural aspects differ from those of later periods but its floor plan typifies those that would last until the 1890s.

The house of Doña Isabel, a native of Cebu who settled in Intramuros with her husband Sevillian captain Don Manuel Piñero, seems to have stood along today’s Legazpi St, “which runs towards the gate of Santo Domingo, in front of the cemetery of San Francisco.” The house was probably already very old by the time the will was made, because Doña Isabel, then already a widow and great grandmother, could not remember its age. Three heights of wall hint that the house was a veteran of the earthquakes of 1645, 1658, and 1677. It occupied almost all of the trapezoidal-shaped lot, approximately around 589 m plus a second floor area of 565 sqm. This made it not just an ordinary bahay na bato but a mansion, or maybe a house-cum-fortress since two of its four doors served to guard access to the stairway. The house had an L-shaped floor plan, which provided space for a courtyard and a well on one side.

 

The house rested on 24 stout wooden pillars each measuring 1.67 m across. The ground floor with a high ceiling was made of adobe 1.12 m thick. It had storage rooms as well as a porter’s room. The two-flight stairway led to the rooms above starting with the corredor principal or main corridor, which opened to a hall called cañon, probably a receiving room. Beside the cañon were two cuartos or bedrooms while behind the house as a separate structure was the cocina or kitchen. It was connected to the main house through a walkway. The latrine on the other hand had wooden floors and walls and a roof of tiles.

The second level of wood had balcones voladizos or balconies that projected over the street. These protected the house interior from the sun while allowing the air to flow in. The balconies were closed with latticework shutters with capiz shell panes. These shutters were swung out instead of being slid—the first of its kind on record. The walls between the cañon and corredor principal were fitted with barandillas or wooden grilles that allowed light and air to pass through. This particular detail of the house evolved into partition jalousies in some 19th century houses. Below the windows of the house were ventanillas or small windows that reached down to the floor.

There is no mention of a ceiling so it is believed that the rafters and beams were exposed, like the houses of the following century.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Zialcita, Fernando N. 1994. “Bahay na Bato.” CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, Volume III Philippine Architecture. Edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Zialcita, Fernando N., and Martin I. Tinio Jr. 1980. Philippine Ancestral Houses 1810-1930. Quezon City: GCF Books and Manila: Kyodo Printing Co., Inc.

photos.desc:
Church of Santiago Apostol in Plaridel, Bulacan, 2014

(John Leonard S. Puso)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santiago Apostol. Location: Plaridel, Bulacan. Built 18th century.

Plaridel, previously known as Quingua, already existed prior to 1599 when it was annexed to Malolos. Then, the settlement was located in Lumang Bayan, a barangay of present-day Plaridel. The first Augustinian friar to serve in Lumang Bayan was Fr Pedro Vasquez (1580-95), who built the earlier church at Lumang Bayan. In 1936, Quingua was renamed Plaridel after Marcelo H. del Pilar, the great propangandist who hailed from the province. Plaridel is del Pilar’s pen name.

In 1602, it was made a vicariate under the supervision of the Augustinian Father Provincial. For many years, it was annexed to Malolos as a visita (mission chapel). The town was officially founded as a Spanish pueblo in 1605 when it was accepted as a house of the Augustinian order during a council meeting on 30 Apr of that year. In the same year, the town site was transferred from Lumang Bayan to where it is presently found. Fr Diego Pardo had spiritual charge of the town. From the 1620s, it had its own resident priest in response to the request of its residents. The Augustinian house of Quingua was exempted from paying rent to the San Agustin Monastery from 1640 to 1704, primarily because the convent was very poor. In 1771, the parish was given to the secular clergy after the secularization decree, but was returned to the Augustinians in 1778. The present town of Baliuag, which then included Bustos, was a visita of Quingua until 1732 when Baliuag became independent. The residents of Plaridel supported themselves through farming and shoemaking.

 

During the British occupation of 1762 to 1764, the Augustinian Province transferred some of the orders’ jewels and money plus official records from San Agustin in Intramuros to Plaridel’s convent for safekeeping. By the end of the 19th century, Plaridel was under the administration of the secular clergy. The Filipino parish priest Fr Victorino Lopez joined the revolutionaries as an officer under Capt Jose Serapio of Santa Maria. In 1899, the church and convento were comandeered by the Americans and used as a hospital and barracks. It was also in Plaridel where the famous Battle of Quingua in 1899 took place. A prominent figure in the Philippine-American War, Col John Stotsenberg, was killed in that battle.

At the present townsite, Fr Tomas Quijano built in 1722 a church and convent of strong materials, following the framework of the previous structures which were previously destroyed, possibly by fire. The church was burned in 1772 and was immediately rebuilt. It was damaged during the 1863 earthquake but was repaired the same year.

The present church is baroque in style, with noticeable mudejar elements, like the trefoil arches, which embellish the facade and the retablos inside the church. Although the recent addition of a concrete porte cochere in front of the facade has obscured the original features of the church, the unique pediment of the building still stands out. It has an onion-shaped silhouette, reminiscent of the domes of mosques and churches of the Eastern Orthodox Church. This shape is achieved by a pair of volutes that define the otherwise semicircular pediment. Beginning at the apex, which is the base for a cross, the volutes descend to the sides and terminate in curls that bulge out beyond the tops of the twin columns that define the boundaries of the lower sections. The pediment has a rose window flanked on both sides by insets of vases with flowers, cherub heads, and the Augustinian coat of arms.

The two lower stories of the church are divided vertically by twin pillars. The first story’s central section is much wider than the flanking sections. In the central section is the church’s entrance, which has a trefoil arch. On the two sides are niches with statues. The second-story windows are placed directly above the niches and entrance on the ground level. Attached to the church on the gospel side is a five-tiered bell tower, crowned by a cone-shaped dome. The base of the tower is quadrilateral while the upper four stories are octagonal but of diminishing sizes, reminiscent of Chinese pagodas. The bell tower has blind and open fenestrations with balusters.

Not far from the church, in the midst of modern houses, is the Spanish-era simborio (dome), the mortuary chapel of the town’s old cemetery.

From 2011 to 2013, following extensive research, the church ceiling was painted with the images of Christ, Mary, and the 12 apostles in the trompe l’oeil style, while the two rose windows were exposed after decades of being covered by adobe. Meanwhile, palitada (primer) was applied on the upper portion of the capitals on the church facade. The church was marked by the Philippines Historical Committee in 1961.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano, with notes from René B. Javellana

 

Source

Galende, Pedro, OSA. (1987) 1996. Angels in Stone: Architecture of Augustinian Churches in the Philippines. Metro Manila: G.A. Formoso Publishing. 1996 hardcover ed. Manila: San Agustin Museum.

photos.desc:
Church of Nuestra Señora del Rosario ruins in Pudtol, Apayao, 2007

(Shubert Ciencia)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Nuestra Señora del Rosario and Capinatan Church ruins. Location: Pudtol, Apayao. Both built under the direction of Fr Pedro Gimenez, OP, 1670s-80s.

Inhabitants of the northernmost reaches of Cagayan were referred to in early 17th century documents as the Mandaya, a native name meaning “those up above.” The Dominicans ministered among these people beginning in the early 1600s, with pioneer missions in Pata (now Namuac, Sanchez-Mira), Cabicungan (Claveria), and Abulug. Further up the Abulug or Apayao River they founded Nuestra Señora del Rosario de Fotol in 1610 and its visita (mission chapel) San Lorenzo de Capinatan in 1619. The word fotol is said to derive from the local word for “behead” or “cut off,” while Capinatan is traced to pinat, “plain.” Despite interruptions in evangelization due to tribal rivalries and the lack of missionaries, the Mandaya were able to construct stone churches in these two communities. Credit for the impetus in these projects is given to Fr Pedro Gimenez, OP, vicar of Fotol in 1673-77 and 1684-90. The Apayao missions virtually disappeared from 18th century records and were only revived in 1890. It seems Fotol was re-established as a parish in 1949, with Capinatan still its visita.

 

A significant section of the church at Fotol, now Pudtol, has survived to our day. According to soldiers’ tales, the meter-thick walls of mamposteria, or rubblework, grew by four finger-lengths every night without the aid of masons. The church consists of a single nave with a narrower presbytery and an extension serving as a sacristy. Of great artistic importance is the impressive stone barrel vault in the apse, with spaces in the walls that previously held wooden bas-reliefs, and with traces of black-and-white murals depicting leaves and tendrils. The facade in Tuscan style, featuring a five-meter high arched main portal and two small towers flanking it, as well as most of the eight buttresses supporting both sides of the nave at every five meters, have sadly disappeared since they were observed by the Dominican historian Julian Malumbres in the 1890s.

The smaller river-stone church and convento at Capinatan, now Matagisi, are largely intact, though roofless. On its facade can be barely made out a bas-relief of the Dominican seal, flanked by what seem to be banners and borne by as yet unidentifiable creatures. The settlement used to be protected by a palisaded fort dedicated to San Jose.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Javellana, René B. 2010. La Casa de Dios: The Legacy of Filipino-Hispanic Churches in the Philippines. Pasig City: Ortigas Foundation, Inc.

Malumbres, Julian, O.P. 1918a. Historia de Cagayan. Manila: Tip. Linotype de Sto. Tomas.

Scott, William Henry. 1977. The Discovery of the Igorots. Revised ed. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

photos.desc:
Postcard showing Spanish-period Puente Colgante, linking Quiapo and the southern bank of the Pasig River, later replaced by Quiapo Bridge

(Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Location: Quiapo, Manila. Inaugurated 1852. Engineer: M. Gaband.

Puente Colgante or the Suspension Bridge, also known as Puente de Claveria after Gov-Gen Narciso de Claveria, was built in the area presently occupied by the Quezon Bridge. It incorporated the most advanced European technology available during the mid-19th century. The French engineer contracted for the project was M. Gaband. The steel structure was imported directly from England. The bridge was inaugurated on 4 Jan 1852, and the toll fees collected from the bridge went in part to its painstaking maintenance.

 

Besides being an example of what was then the latest in European technology, the bridge served to create a single metropolis of Intramuros and its arrabales (districts) on the northern bank of the Pasig. It also paved the way for the unification of the southern bank, which housed civil and ecclesiastical offices, and the northern bank, which in the 19th century had become the economic center of Manila with its trading houses owned by Spaniards and mestizos as well as British and Americans. The bridge survived the destructive earthquake of 1863. For sometime, it remained the only bridge spanning the Pasig because the older Puente de España suffered damages from temblors and had to be closed.

Sketches of the bridge in 1875, 1881, and 1896 in different publications show two concrete towers built on either bank of the Pasig. Strands of cables, attached to these towers, are slung across the river which in turn hold up the steel bridge. A railing of steel flankseach side of the bridge and iron streetlights are positioned at strategic places along the bridge. Its simple but sturdy design encouraged the building of other suspension bridges in the Philippines—a noteworthy one was built in Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Puente de España, ca 1920, later replaced by Jones Bridge

(John Tewell Collection)

text:
Location: Intramuros-Binondo, Manila. First bridge built 1629-39; repaired by Lucas Maria de Castro, OAR ca 1757 and Domingo Ildefonso de Aragon in 1814; rebuilt 1868-75 according to the design of Casto Irizar Olano.

Located slightly to the west of the area presently occupied by Jones Bridge, Puente de España, or Bridge of Spain, replaced an earlier bridge, Puente Grande de España, or the Grand Bridge, that spanned the Pasig River, linking the south and north banks. For the first 70 years or so of its existence, the City of Manila did not have a bridge spanning the Pasig. Citizens commuting from either bank used boats and other riverine means of transport. Gov Luis Perez Dasmariñas blocked the initiative of the cabildo (city chapter or council) of Manila to span the Pasig with a bridge when he assigned the rights for creating “a passageway over the river” to the Comunidad de Sangleyes, the council of the Manila Chinese, who built and maintained the Hospital de San Gabriel in Binondo. The City Chapter protested Dasmariñas’s action and even brought their objections to Madrid. Noche (2011) surmises that the council objections had to do with loss of income from the toll the city collected from the ferries that crossed the Pasig.

But Dasmariñas prevailed. Thus a bridge was built and completed sometime between the last three months of 1629 and early 1630. A 17th-century document describes the bridge as made of 10 spans, supported by nine strong piers, which blocked the swift currents of the Pasig. Its walkway was wood. As planned the bridge was to have eight spans: six stone, both its piers and arches, and the central two spans (Nos 4 and 5) of cast iron to be manufactured in France by Imbert and Company. photos.desc:
Ramon Magsaysay Center on Roxas Boulevard, Manila, 2016

(Kiko del Rosario)

text:
Location: Roxas Blvd corner Dr Joaquin Y Quintos Sr St, Malate, Manila. Built 1967-68. Architect: Alfredo J. Luz and Associates.

The Ramon Magsaysay Awards Foundation was established to perpetuate the legacy of a former president of the Philippines, who died in an airplane crash in 1957. A piece of land in Ermita, Manila formerly known as Plaza Militar, was donated by the Philippine Congress in 1959 to be the site of the commemorative building. The Ramon Magsaysay Center (RMC), an 18-story office cum commercial building, rose on this dramatic location that fronted the busy Roxas Blvd and Manila Bay. Housed here are the Asian Library and the offices of the foundation that adminsters the Ramon Magsaysay Award, Asia’s equivalent of the Nobel Prize.

 

The iconic RMC building was designed by Alfredo J. Luz in modernist style, melding innovative structural solutions such as precast and pre-stressed construction with earthquake-resistant design. Luz consulted the American engineer and architect Pietro Belluschi from Boston and a structural firm headed by Dr Alfred Yee from Honolulu, USA. Yee introduced Hawaii’s first precast, prestressed concrete mass production facility in 1955.

The RMC may be characterized as a rectangular block raised above the ground by 12 tree trunk-like massive square reinforced concrete columns. The block is a cast-in-place concrete sheer wall core (moment frame) on concrete piles. The facade of repeated rows of deeply recessed square windows is finished with travertine slabs on precast wall panels. The travertine slab cladding was chosen not only for its aesthetic appearance but also for a functional purpose: it lessened the maintenance of a building that was constantly exposed to the salty environment of Manila Bay.

Other structural features are the prestressed concrete beams and multiple in-place floor slabs. The building’s interior introduced a column-free concept, fire resistant gypsum boards, metal runners in the dividing walls, and movable partitions to maximize space according to different users’ needs.  Written by Clarissa L. Avendaño

photos.desc:
Cathedral of San Jose in Romblon, 2009

(Raymond Low)

text:
Roman Catholic Cathedral of St Joseph, formerly San Jose. Location: Romblon, Romblon. Church and tower built early 18th century; nave raised and transept added 2nd half of 19th century.

Since time immemorial, Romblon and its cluster of islands have provided food and shelter to sea-voyagers negotiating the turbulent waters between Luzon and the Visayas. Though the area was known to Spanish explorers from 1572, a Christian settlement was only formally organized in Romblon, on the island of the same name, in 1631. Together with Banton, established earlier in 1622, it was under the spiritual care of the diocesan parish priest of Ajuy, Iloilo. In 1635 Romblong—as it appeared in early documents—with its adjacent islands was turned over by the Bishop of Cebu to the care of the Augustinian Recollects. Though a quasi-parish, it remained a district of the province of Capiz throughout the rest of the Spanish regime.

 

It turned out that slave-raiders had also set up their lairs in these very islands. In 1644 the Recollect Superior ordered the transfer of Agustin de San Pedro, OAR, from Cagayan de Misamis in Mindanao to Romblon. Born in Portugal in 1599, Fray Agustin had already earned some fame for building palisades and forts in Linao and Cagayan. From 1644 to 1650, he inculcated in the Romblomanon the arts of defense, including fighting on land and sea, surprise attacks, and pursuit of the enemy. He instructed them in constructing forts on Romblon and Banton islands. He died in 1653, and his remains are enshrined at the foot of the Romblon bell tower which used to serve as his own bulwark. These achievements earned him the name el Padre Capitan. The title was soon recorded in chronicles of the era such as the Historia de Mindanao by the Jesuit historian Francisco Combés.

Fray Agustin fortified the semicircular enclave of Romblon facing the sea, with its back shielded by the thickly forested vertical slopes of an extinct volcano. A 9,144-meter masonry wall connected the stone bulwarks at both ends of the enclosure, and closed off any enemy entry into the town. Inside the enclosure a church was built. Its apse or rear was firmly set into the mountain wall for stability and security, a unique undertaking in Philippine architecture. The convento extended from the right side of the facade so that the compound formed an “L”. The houses of the residents radiated from the church. We get an idea of how the fortified town looked like through a plan prepared in 1734 by Gov-Gen Fernando Valdes y Tamon. The forts in Romblon and Banton were built with local labor and under the direction and maintenance of the Augustinian Recollects.

For a hundred years after the coming of el Padre Capitán to Romblon, the district enjoyed a period of relative calm. The bulk of the present church and convent of cut coral-stone must have been erected by the first decades of the 18th century. This is presupposed by the dating of certain furnishings and structures in the complex. Roman numerals for the year “1726” mark the construction of the retablo mayor. The two retablos fronting each other in the transept are of the same baroque style and must have come at around the same time. Roman numerals for the year “1727” provide a date for the lower level of the bell tower. An image of the Santo Niño based on the famous one in Cebu was gifted to the church in 1728. The church and convento of Banton were also built in 1726.

A wave of bloody raids that commenced in 1740 retarded development in the Romblon area for most of the century. The two hills flanking the town of Romblon were crowned with forts in 1760. Natural calamities and famine worsened living conditions as its residents lost their fields and cattle in the adjoining islands of Tablas and Sibuyan. Typhoons in 1780 and 1829 greatly damaged the church and convento.

The decrease of pirate raids in the early 19th century brought in more maritime commerce and local prosperity. To accommodate the growing population, a transept was added to the church in the 1860s and 1870s. At the same time the walls of the nave were raised by a few meters, a cupola was built over the crossing, and the building was roofed with tile. A section of the convento adjoining the church was taken down to give access to the right transept. In the 1890s, the windows were enlarged and enhanced with colored glass panes, a pipe organ was installed, the church was painted, and the tile roof replaced with a lighter one of zinc. The famous marble industry of Romblon seems to have been initiated only in the last years of the 19th century, as there is no mention of it in earlier chronicles. The Recollects assisted the residents in carving holy water fonts and baptismal basins that were distributed all over the country.

Despite all the changes the church has gone through, the early 18th century shell has survived almost intact. It seems unusually tall in relation to its width, due to the additions of the 19th century. The octagonal cupola over the crossing has recently been replaced by an ill-advised dome. Over the central doorway is an image of St Joseph cradling the Christ Child, who affectionately curls his right hand on his earthly father’s nape. Three intricately carved doors give entrance to the church. The year M./DCC./XX/VI (1726) is inscribed on the base of the second level of the central retablo, making it a benchmark for Philippine colonial art history. This altarpiece, along with two others in the transept ends, is exuberantly decorated with twisted columns, graceful scrolls, and flowery finials and flanges. Two other retablos flanking the central one are in the neoclassic style, installed in the 2nd half of the 19th century.

The parish church of St Joseph became a cathedral when it became the seat of the Diocese of Romblon which was erected on 17 Apr 1975. The National Museum declared the Cathedral of St Joseph a National Cultural Treasure on 31 Jul 2001.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Saint Catherine’s Academy in Carcar, Cebu, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
P. del Corro Building. Location: Carcar, Cebu. Built 15 Sep 1921.

St Catherine’s Academy in Carcar was the first Catholic school in southern Cebu outside Cebu City. It was founded by Fr Anastacio del Corro, parish priest of the town from 1901 to 1947. First opened in Jun 1923 to serve as an all-girls boarding school, it was administered by the Belgian Missionary Canonesses of St Augustine (now the Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, ICM). It is now run by the sisters of the Order of Preachers. The first school building, now one in a row of five, is a large two-story structure across the edge of the plaza. The concrete facade, built to impress, is a veritable cornucopia of turn-of-the-century motifs like medallion-shaped clerestory windows on both levels adorned with fancy iron grills for balustrades (Cañete 2013). The roofline shaped like a swan’s neck is ornamented with floral carvings and bears the name of the building and its date of construction, 15 Sep 1921. The second story of the portico has a veranda which overlooks the school’s quadrangle. At the foreground is an open space with stairways leading to the separated twin main doors.

 

Flat windows encircle both stories of the building. These are varied in style: ground floor windows with pregnant grilles, second floor persianas, and low-grilled second floor ventanillas (small windows). Galvanized-iron awnings protect the windows from the elements. The transoms have two sets of ornamentation. Right above every window is a half-moon espehong (mirrorlike). Capiz pieces decorate the entire lower and upper stories of the building, producing dramatic effects of sunlight entering from the outside when the windows are closed.

Inside the building are compartments occupied by the different offices of the school. On the second story is the chapel, sala, and the nuns’ quarters. These interior divisions are later additions, which disrupt the play of space in the original plan.

Hardwood is used for the ground floor’s dividing walls and the floors and ceiling of the second floor. The rest of the walls, the posts, and the entire portico are of concrete. Iron grilles and cast lead decorate the windows and doors. Galvanized iron covers the roof.  Written by Paul Labrado, with notes from René B. Javellana

 

Source

Cañete, Reuben Ramas. 2013. “A Preliminary Study of Ceiling Murals from Five Southeastern Cebu Churches.” Asian Studies: Journal of Critical Perspectives on Asia. Vol 49, Issue 1, 69-104. Quezon City: Asian Center, University of the Philippines.

article.value: P. del Corro Building. Location: Carcar, Cebu. Built 15 Sep 1921.

St Catherine’s Academy in Carcar was the first Catholic school in southern Cebu outside Cebu City. It was founded by Fr Anastacio del Corro, parish priest of the town from 1901 to 1947. First opened in Jun 1923 to serve as an all-girls boarding school, it was administered by the Belgian Missionary Canonesses of St Augustine (now the Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, ICM). It is now run by the sisters of the Order of Preachers. The first school building, now one in a row of five, is a large two-story structure across the edge of the plaza. The concrete facade, built to impress, is a veritable cornucopia of turn-of-the-century motifs like medallion-shaped clerestory windows on both levels adorned with fancy iron grills for balustrades (Cañete 2013). The roofline shaped like a swan’s neck is ornamented with floral carvings and bears the name of the building and its date of construction, 15 Sep 1921. The second story of the portico has a veranda which overlooks the school’s quadrangle. At the foreground is an open space with stairways leading to the separated twin main doors.

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of San Miguel Arcangel Church Complex. Location: Samboan, Cebu. Built before 1878.

The town of Samboan was established on a promontory in the southern extremity of Cebu Island. Its high location overlooking the Tañon Strait which separates Cebu from Negros may have been for defensive and strategic reasons. It was a visita (mission chapel) of Tanjay, Negros Oriental until it became an independent parish on 3 Nov 1784, under the ministration of the secular clergy.

 

The church facade is a simple echo of the Basilica of the Santo Niño. Shallow pilasters divide its two levels into three segments. It is decorated by twin semicircular windows at the first level and paired flat windows at the second level. Right above the arched main door is a miniature recessed niche bearing a wooden image of the town’s patron saint San Miguel Arcangel. The triangular pediment has a circular opening screened with iron grills. A four-story octagonal stone belfry is attached to the left side of the church. Some stones from the belfry were dislodged by plant roots. Beside the old church is a modern butincongruous shrine dedicated to St Jude Thaddeus. To the right is the old convento. Its first level of coral stone is utilized as parish office while the second level of wood is used as the priest’s quarters. Recently, the roof level was improperly raised almost as high as the church facade.

The massive walls are of cut stone and lime. The church has a single nave with a choir loft right above the main door positioned between twin rectangular columns. The interioris a dramatic play of space leading up to the old two-level retablo. The retablo and the choir loft, of apitong and molave wood, feature rococo elements. The altarpiece, which bears statues of the people’s saintly advocates, is painted in folksy colors. The tiled roof was replaced with galvanized iron when the beams began to weaken their hold of the roof at the turn of the 20th century.

At the top of the promontory is a three-story watchtower. From here an archway marks the upper terminus of 157 stone steps that link the top of the hill with the seashore. This stairway was built in 1878 by the Fr Toribio Gerzon, parish priest of the town from 1847 to 1897. It is popularly called Jacob’s Ladder, alluding to the ladder seen in a dream by the patriarch Jacob in the Book of Genesis. The mid-point of the stairway is crossed by the camino real (royal road) that leads to the church plaza. This plaza has since been spruced up by the local government. It is also dotted with life-size images portraying Christ’s passion and death. Jacob’s Ladder is well maintained unlike its counterpart in Santander, the only other town in Cebu with such a structure.  Written by Paul Labrado, with notes from Trizer Dale D. Mansueto and Regalado Trota Jose

text:
Roman Catholic Church and Monastery of San Pablo el Ermitaño, popularly known as San Agustin. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Completed ca 1607. Architect: Juan Macias. Renovated 1854 by Luciano Oliver.

The first church built in Luzon, San Agustin church dates back to 1571 when Manila was conquered by the Spaniards. A site in this city, named Intramuros when it was later rebuilt in stone, was apportioned to the Augustinians, the first religious order to evangelize in the Philippines. Early structures of bamboo, nipa, and wood burned down in 1574, 1583, and 1586. Thus, the friars decided in 1586 or 1587 to build a church and monastery of stone. About 20 years later both structures were substantially complete. Various dates are given for the completion of the church: 1605, 1608, and 1609. Juan Macias, a Spaniard, was the architect and director of construction. He died in 1611 and was buried in the church.

 

Much of the San Agustin church has survived intact to the present, making it one of the earliest examples of late 16th-century and early 17th-century architecture. The atrial plan of the monastery and its architectural articulation owes much to Mexican models, according to Galende.

Practical and direct to the point, the church’s exterior form is boxlike and rather plain. From 1854 onwards, architect Luciano Oliver worked on renovating the church. He modified the squat facade by raising the two bell towers flanking the main section in 1861. The tower to the left or the gospel side cracked in the earthquakes of 1863 and 1880 and had to be torn down. The facade represents a sedate style more akin to Renaissance. The only concession to baroque is the carved doors decorated with rocaille of the late baroque or rococo style.

 

The church’s more significant characteristics are found inside. Of prime interest are the series of chapels lining both sides of the nave. The walls separating the chapels also act as buttresses, in the same manner as the wandpfeiler (wall pillars) of German baroque churches. Perhaps due to limited space within Intramuros these buttresses were placed inside the church, the voids between them providing spaces for chapels. Both these chapels and the wall-buttresses are features found nowhere else in the country. The Manila cathedral a few blocks away possessed these features in the 18th century. San Agustin also boasts of a barrel vault, dome, and arched vestibule, all of stone supporting the choir loft. These are also the only extant examples in the country.

The monastery, being the motherhouse of the Augustinians in the Philippines and their springboard to other parts of Asia, came to comprise three distinct buildings. The first was built together with the church and adjoins its left or south side. It is quadrangular, enclosing a cloister and inner garden. The second monastery was built from 1623 to 1668 to accommodate the growing religious community. It was linked to the first monastery by a passageway. A third floor was added by Oliver in 1861. The third monastery was actually an extension of the first building and was built intermittently from 1713 to 1828. These last two were destroyed by American bombs in the Battle of Manila in 1945. The church, however, was the only church in Intramuros that survived World War II.

 

The church and monastery are priceless repositories of the country’s religious art including: the earliest dated retablo by Juan de los Santos, ca 1620; 26 huge oil paintings by Fuster and Enriquez; a sumptuous baroque pulpit; a 17th-century Macao-made choir lectern; exquisitely carved 17th century choir stalls of molave, in the church choir, and the ivory image of the Nuestra Señora de la Correa or La Consolacion; an ivory crucifix by Juan de los Santos; an ivory San Miguel; and gold embroidered vestments for images and for Mass.

The church interior was painted in 1875 by the two Italian painters Cesare Alberoni and Giovanni Dibella in trompe l’oeil style, which influenced the decoration of some churches of that era. The heavily carved baroque doors at the front and side entrance are outstanding. The 19th century grille door leading from the epistle transept to the cloister is an example of the art of wrought iron.

San Agustin is also a veritable historical relic. The remains of the founder of Spanish Manila Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, the artist and patriot Juan Luna, and other prominent personalities are buried within its walls. The first church council and the first national synod were held here, in 1578 and 1581 respectively. In 1898 plans for the surrender of Manila to the Americans were discussed here.

In the process of restoring the cloister walls, remnants of frescos were discovered. The strapwork design on the vault of the former refectory, now a museum gallery, has been preserved. Part of a painted retablo was uncovered underneath a painting that hung in the corridor of the first floor. In 1997 and 1998, the pipe organ at San Agustin was restored by the Diego Cera Organ Builders in Las Piñas. When the pipes were removed for restoration, an older scheme for painting the church walls was uncovered. This was not in the style of the grisaille or grey painting of the 19th century but employed a rich polychrome palette of red, blue, green, orange and a touch of gold leaf, similar to the color schemes of early Mexican baroque churches.

Because San Agustin is a popular venue for weddings and because the church’s outer patio gets flooded, the patio has been raised and paved for better parking. The inner cloister of the first monastery, which used to be planted was paved to allow its use for wedding receptions. Within the monastery compound a new residence in the colonial style has been built as a house of formation for Augustinian seminarians.

San Agustin has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1994 under the title “Baroque Churches of the Philippines.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
First San Ignacio: College church of the Colegio de San Ignacio. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Built 1626-32. Architect: Gianantonio Campioni. Second San Ignacio: College church of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Architects: Felix Roxas Sr (principal); Isabelo Tampinco, Crispulo Jocson, Agustin Saez (interior). Built 1879-89.

The first San Ignacio was the third church the Jesuits built in their compound at Intramuros, located at the southern part of Manila, bounded by Calle Real (now General Luna), Victoria, Santa Lucia, and Muralla, and presently occupied by the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. The first church, a wooden one with a tile roof, was built in 1587 with donations from Don Gabriel de Ribera, the oidor (judge) of Manila. It was replaced between 1590 to 1596 by the first Jesuit stone church in the Philippines, dedicated to Santa Ana, the Blessed Virgin’s mother. It was planned by the Jesuit Antonio Sedeño after the pattern of the Jesuit church in Rome—Giacommo da Vignola and Giacommo della Porta’s Il Gesu. Santa Ana church was seriously damaged by the earthquake of 1600. The church was subsequently repaired.

 

It was replaced between 1626 and 1632 by a new church constructed following the plans of the Italian priest-architect Gianantonio Campioni. The church as it came from Campioni’s hand was plain, perhaps more Italian than Spanish baroque. The church was dedicated to San Ignacio de Loyola who was canonized in 1622. In 1700 the church ceiling was painted by Bro Manuel Rodriguez, assisted by Filipino artisans. Around this time the church facade was decorated with carved foliage that gave it a plateresque appearance. In 1727 the church was solemnly consecrated after extensive renovations.

After the Jesuits’ expulsion from the Philippines, the archbishop of Manila in 1771 requested the government to allow the diocesan seminary, San Carlos, use of the abandoned Jesuit College of Manila, adjacent to the church. In 1784 the College of Manila and the church were turned over to the archdiocese following the visitation of 1778. The seminary was renamed Real Seminario Conciliar de San Carlos. On 6 Sep 1852 at 1:30 pm an earthquake destroyed the church. Stones of the church were later used in the foundations of the second San Ignacio the Jesuits were going to build at Arzobispo St, next to the episcopal palace of Manila, beginning 1879.

 

The first San Ignacio, of grayish adobe quarried from Antipolo, was located on a southeast-by-northwest axis, its front door opening to a quadrilateral plaza flagged with stone and surrounded by a breast-high wall ornamented by stone lions. The plaza opened to Calle Victoria. The church was 62 m long and 30 m wide. Its height from the base to the top of the dome was 33.83 m. The central nave was 12 m wide. This was flanked by aisles of about 7.62 m wide, enough to appear as naves.

The facade was divided into two stories crowned by a triangular pediment. Twin towers of three stories, terminating in a triangular roof, flanked the facade. The church bells were hung in one of the facade towers and a clock installed in the other tower. Ionic capitals on pilasters were used throughout. At the first floor of the bell tower, decorative niches were gouged into wide pilasters, while at the facade thin pilasters flanked niches. Pairs of pilasters were on the second and third floors of the bell towers. Large windows pierced the second floor both at the facade and on the towers. All in all the facade gave a pleasing appearance. Hence, according to the Jesuit Murillo Velarde, the Campioni-designed facade is the shell that declares its content. However, Velarde writing in 1734 and referring to the plateresque designs imposed on the facade, lamented the excessive ornamentation that ruined the majesty of the original concept behind the facade.

 

The choir loft rested on elliptical arches. The church roof was supported by 12 well-wrought pillars, rectangular in shape, fluted with tiny canals terminating in Ionic capitals. From pillar to pillar were semicircular arches decorated at the center with cartouches. Then from pillar to the 2.74 meter-thick wall were equally well-wrought arches, together forming domes of stone. Above these arches, galleries were made to accommodate large crowds for such times as Lent, missions, and solemn feasts. The idea of the gallery was not novel. Santa Ana on the same spot had already used it. Il Gesu in Rome also had galleries, called correte. The upper gallery, covered with domes, rested on the pillars that echoed those below. The axis of these domes coincided with those below. The interior gave an overall impression of solemnity. The crossing of the principal nave and transept was covered by an octagonal crossing tower, which had a window on every side to allow light to filter into the church. The crossing tower’s exterior had a gallery that ran around it, making the dome accessible from outside. San Ignacio, the titular of the church, was depicted in a life-size statue and located in a niche on the second level of the retablo that was all of four stories. The retablo was richly gilded, and before it stood an altar with a frontal of finely chased silver. Flanking the altar and distributed throughout the nave were lampstands, also of silver. At the side of the transepts were the collateral naves. Beneath the choir loft stood altars dedicated to different saints. At the right side was the altar of the crucifix. There was also the altar of the Blessed Virgin under the invocation of Dolores and Loreto. The collateral aisles, which terminated in chapels, had one dedicated to San Jose and the other to San Francisco Xavier. Beneath the choir loft were smaller altars for San Francisco Regis and San Luis Gonzaga; and San Juan Nepomuceno and San Joaquin, the Blessed Virgin’s father. An auxiliary entrance on the gospel flank of the nave was also loaded with ornamentation.

The second San Ignacio was built to serve two purposes: as the oratory or college chapel of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila and as the central Jesuit church in the Philippines. The Ateneo used the church for special occasions or when large crowds were expected, otherwise, the Ateneo used the students’ chapel dedicated to the Immaculate Conception.

It was considered the masterpiece of the Filipino artists Isabelo Tampinco et al, and the architect Felix Roxas Sr. The plan was drawn by Roxas, who had trained in England and had traveled extensively in Europe and India. The cornerstone was laid on 9 Feb 1878, with the archbishop of Manila the Dominican Pedro Payo presiding over the rites. He was also one of the principal patrons of the church, who donated part of his garden as the site for the San Ignacio. Roxas died while the church was being built, and the Jesuit brother Francisco Riera took over the supervision of the work. Riera would later help build churches in Mindanao, among them the Dapitan Church and the Jasaan Church, the latter patterned after Roxas’s San Ignacio. In 1882 Tampingco and 50 to 60 artisans, including his father-in-law Crispulo Jocson, began finishing the church interior following designs drawn by Agustin Saez and sometimes improving on them. Saez was director of the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura and a teacher of art at Ateneo. Tampinco and his artisans carved the retablo, colonnade, and coffered ceiling of the church using hardwood from Surigao. A Spaniard, Francisco Rodoreda, carved the three marble altars, and a Filipino, Felix Martinez, painted canvases of Jesuit saints. The bell tower, made of iron sheets, was built by Jose Fuentes, a government engineer. On the whole, Roxas’s plan was executed except for a cupola, which the Jesuits decided not to build for lack of funds, and the bell tower, which was built taller and slimmer. In 1895 a crypt was dug under the main altar to hold the remains of Jesuits who had worked in the Philippines since the 16th century. In 1932 a fire swept Intramuros, destroying Ateneo but leaving San Ignacio intact. The church was finally destroyed by fire in 1945 during the Battle of Manila.

San Ignacio was designed in the neoclassical style with touches of the Renaissance in the interior, especially in the colonnade with its contrasting colors of white and natural wood. The chaste facade of piedra de visayas (cut coral), bricks, and marble led into an arcaded church with Corinthian columns of carved wood. The arcade was ornamented with medallions depicting Jesuit saints. The arcade supported galleries that were joined to the choir loft and that opened into the nave. The ceiling was ornamented with acanthus leaves enclosed in boxes with ropelike designs. Where the cupola should have been the ceiling was raised to form a truncated octahedron decorated with reliefs of Jesuit saints. The main retablo had a single niche with a statue of San Ignacio carved by Jocson in the classical style favored by the Gremio de Escultores. The corners of the retablo were ornamented with angels. The altar table itself of Carrara marble was decorated with a high relief version of Leonardo da Vinci’s Last Supper. The pulpit of hardwood was designed by Saez and meticulously embellished with images from the bible and the symbols of faith, hope, and charity. It was considered the masterpiece of the interior.

Plans to restore the San Ignacio had long been in the works since the time when Imelda Marcos, appointed governor of Manila in 1975 and then minister of the Ministry of Human Settlements, commissioned studies on how to restore the San Ignacio and the adjoining buildings of Casa Mision and Ateneo de Manila. No restoration was done but the lots of Ateneo and Casa Mision were cleared.

During the administration of Maria Ana L. Harper, appointed head of the Intramuros Administration (IA) in 2008, a more assiduous move to restore the San Ignacio was launched. Planning was begun and an inventory of the IA’s holding of ecclesiastical art was done. The plan was to restore the San Ignacio not as a church but as a museum of ecclesiastical art. Some of the objects IA wanted to exhibit had been earlier shown in the Puerta Isabel museum inside the casamata or chambers of the Intramuros walls near Puerta Isabel II. But more were in storage.

article.value: First San Ignacio: College church of the Colegio de San Ignacio. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Built 1626-32. Architect: Gianantonio Campioni. Second San Ignacio: College church of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Architects: Felix Roxas Sr (principal); Isabelo Tampinco, Crispulo Jocson, Agustin Saez (interior). Built 1879-89.

The first San Ignacio was the third church the Jesuits built in their compound at Intramuros, located at the southern part of Manila, bounded by Calle Real (now General Luna), Victoria, Santa Lucia, and Muralla, and presently occupied by the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. The first church, a wooden one with a tile roof, was built in 1587 with donations from Don Gabriel de Ribera, the oidor (judge) of Manila. It was replaced between 1590 to 1596 by the first Jesuit stone church in the Philippines, dedicated to Santa Ana, the Blessed Virgin’s mother. It was planned by the Jesuit Antonio Sedeño after the pattern of the Jesuit church in Rome—Giacommo da Vignola and Giacommo della Porta’s Il Gesu. Santa Ana church was seriously damaged by the earthquake of 1600. The church was subsequently repaired.

(Leo Cloma Collection)

article.value: It was replaced between 1626 and 1632 by a new church constructed following the plans of the Italian priest-architect Gianantonio Campioni. The church as it came from Campioni’s hand was plain, perhaps more Italian than Spanish baroque. The church was dedicated to San Ignacio de Loyola who was canonized in 1622. In 1700 the church ceiling was painted by Bro Manuel Rodriguez, assisted by Filipino artisans. Around this time the church facade was decorated with carved foliage that gave it a plateresque appearance. In 1727 the church was solemnly consecrated after extensive renovations.

After the Jesuits’ expulsion from the Philippines, the archbishop of Manila in 1771 requested the government to allow the diocesan seminary, San Carlos, use of the abandoned Jesuit College of Manila, adjacent to the church. In 1784 the College of Manila and the church were turned over to the archdiocese following the visitation of 1778. The seminary was renamed Real Seminario Conciliar de San Carlos. On 6 Sep 1852 at 1:30 pm an earthquake destroyed the church. Stones of the church were later used in the foundations of the second San Ignacio the Jesuits were going to build at Arzobispo St, next to the episcopal palace of Manila, beginning 1879.

Facade of the 1889 San Ignacio Church

(René Javellana Collection)

article.value: The first San Ignacio, of grayish adobe quarried from Antipolo, was located on a southeast-by-northwest axis, its front door opening to a quadrilateral plaza flagged with stone and surrounded by a breast-high wall ornamented by stone lions. The plaza opened to Calle Victoria. The church was 62 m long and 30 m wide. Its height from the base to the top of the dome was 33.83 m. The central nave was 12 m wide. This was flanked by aisles of about 7.62 m wide, enough to appear as naves.

The facade was divided into two stories crowned by a triangular pediment. Twin towers of three stories, terminating in a triangular roof, flanked the facade. The church bells were hung in one of the facade towers and a clock installed in the other tower. Ionic capitals on pilasters were used throughout. At the first floor of the bell tower, decorative niches were gouged into wide pilasters, while at the facade thin pilasters flanked niches. Pairs of pilasters were on the second and third floors of the bell towers. Large windows pierced the second floor both at the facade and on the towers. All in all the facade gave a pleasing appearance. Hence, according to the Jesuit Murillo Velarde, the Campioni-designed facade is the shell that declares its content. However, Velarde writing in 1734 and referring to the plateresque designs imposed on the facade, lamented the excessive ornamentation that ruined the majesty of the original concept behind the facade.

Ruins of the first San Ignacio Church, ca 1880

(Photo by Francisco Van Camp, John Tewell Collection)

article.value: The choir loft rested on elliptical arches. The church roof was supported by 12 well-wrought pillars, rectangular in shape, fluted with tiny canals terminating in Ionic capitals. From pillar to pillar were semicircular arches decorated at the center with cartouches. Then from pillar to the 2.74 meter-thick wall were equally well-wrought arches, together forming domes of stone. Above these arches, galleries were made to accommodate large crowds for such times as Lent, missions, and solemn feasts. The idea of the gallery was not novel. Santa Ana on the same spot had already used it. Il Gesu in Rome also had galleries, called correte. The upper gallery, covered with domes, rested on the pillars that echoed those below. The axis of these domes coincided with those below. The interior gave an overall impression of solemnity. The crossing of the principal nave and transept was covered by an octagonal crossing tower, which had a window on every side to allow light to filter into the church. The crossing tower’s exterior had a gallery that ran around it, making the dome accessible from outside. San Ignacio, the titular of the church, was depicted in a life-size statue and located in a niche on the second level of the retablo that was all of four stories. The retablo was richly gilded, and before it stood an altar with a frontal of finely chased silver. Flanking the altar and distributed throughout the nave were lampstands, also of silver. At the side of the transepts were the collateral naves. Beneath the choir loft stood altars dedicated to different saints. At the right side was the altar of the crucifix. There was also the altar of the Blessed Virgin under the invocation of Dolores and Loreto. The collateral aisles, which terminated in chapels, had one dedicated to San Jose and the other to San Francisco Xavier. Beneath the choir loft were smaller altars for San Francisco Regis and San Luis Gonzaga; and San Juan Nepomuceno and San Joaquin, the Blessed Virgin’s father. An auxiliary entrance on the gospel flank of the nave was also loaded with ornamentation.

The second San Ignacio was built to serve two purposes: as the oratory or college chapel of the Ateneo Municipal de Manila and as the central Jesuit church in the Philippines. The Ateneo used the church for special occasions or when large crowds were expected, otherwise, the Ateneo used the students’ chapel dedicated to the Immaculate Conception.

It was considered the masterpiece of the Filipino artists Isabelo Tampinco et al, and the architect Felix Roxas Sr. The plan was drawn by Roxas, who had trained in England and had traveled extensively in Europe and India. The cornerstone was laid on 9 Feb 1878, with the archbishop of Manila the Dominican Pedro Payo presiding over the rites. He was also one of the principal patrons of the church, who donated part of his garden as the site for the San Ignacio. Roxas died while the church was being built, and the Jesuit brother Francisco Riera took over the supervision of the work. Riera would later help build churches in Mindanao, among them the Dapitan Church and the Jasaan Church, the latter patterned after Roxas’s San Ignacio. In 1882 Tampingco and 50 to 60 artisans, including his father-in-law Crispulo Jocson, began finishing the church interior following designs drawn by Agustin Saez and sometimes improving on them. Saez was director of the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura and a teacher of art at Ateneo. Tampinco and his artisans carved the retablo, colonnade, and coffered ceiling of the church using hardwood from Surigao. A Spaniard, Francisco Rodoreda, carved the three marble altars, and a Filipino, Felix Martinez, painted canvases of Jesuit saints. The bell tower, made of iron sheets, was built by Jose Fuentes, a government engineer. On the whole, Roxas’s plan was executed except for a cupola, which the Jesuits decided not to build for lack of funds, and the bell tower, which was built taller and slimmer. In 1895 a crypt was dug under the main altar to hold the remains of Jesuits who had worked in the Philippines since the 16th century. In 1932 a fire swept Intramuros, destroying Ateneo but leaving San Ignacio intact. The church was finally destroyed by fire in 1945 during the Battle of Manila.

San Ignacio was designed in the neoclassical style with touches of the Renaissance in the interior, especially in the colonnade with its contrasting colors of white and natural wood. The chaste facade of piedra de visayas (cut coral), bricks, and marble led into an arcaded church with Corinthian columns of carved wood. The arcade was ornamented with medallions depicting Jesuit saints. The arcade supported galleries that were joined to the choir loft and that opened into the nave. The ceiling was ornamented with acanthus leaves enclosed in boxes with ropelike designs. Where the cupola should have been the ceiling was raised to form a truncated octahedron decorated with reliefs of Jesuit saints. The main retablo had a single niche with a statue of San Ignacio carved by Jocson in the classical style favored by the Gremio de Escultores. The corners of the retablo were ornamented with angels. The altar table itself of Carrara marble was decorated with a high relief version of Leonardo da Vinci’s Last Supper. The pulpit of hardwood was designed by Saez and meticulously embellished with images from the bible and the symbols of faith, hope, and charity. It was considered the masterpiece of the interior.

Plans to restore the San Ignacio had long been in the works since the time when Imelda Marcos, appointed governor of Manila in 1975 and then minister of the Ministry of Human Settlements, commissioned studies on how to restore the San Ignacio and the adjoining buildings of Casa Mision and Ateneo de Manila. No restoration was done but the lots of Ateneo and Casa Mision were cleared.
