Carving on the facade of San Joaquin Church depicting the Battle of Tetuan, 2015 

(Bernardo Arellano III)

Church of San Joaquin in Iloilo, 2015

(Bernardo Arellano III)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Joaquin. Location: San Joaquin, Iloilo. Built 1869. Builder: Fr Thomas Santaren, OSA.

San Joaquin town was earlier known as Suaraga, Siuaraga, or Suaragan, a name derived from the Siuaga (now Siwaragan) River, which in turn was named after a venomous snake. It was an encomienda in the southeast part of Panay Island under the guidance of Esteban de Figueroa. Christianization was initiated in 1581 by the Jesuits, to whom Figueroa donated the encomienda in 1585. In 1594 Panay Island was placed under Augustinian supervision by virtue of a royal decree. A legal battle between the Jesuits and Augustinians over the area lasted for more than 20 years. It was amicably settled in 1696 when the Jesuits agreed to give up missions in Iloilo in exchange for other parishes.

Canonically, Suaragan was a visita (mission chapel) of Hamtic (Antique) from 1581 until its independence in 1592. In 1688 it remained a visita until 1692 when it was made into a parish with Miag-ao as its annex. Nine years later it was annexed to the town of Guimbal and then to Miag-ao in 1731. In 1793 it was separated civilly from Miag-ao and became an independent town known as San Joaquin. It was erected as a parish under the advocation of the Most Holy Name of Jesus in 1801. Its residents supported themselves through abaca and cotton weaving, farming, fishing, and cattle raising.

 

The town’s church was built on a plain overlooking the sea by Fr Thomas Santaren, OSA and inaugurated in 1869. Its fabric is of white coral rock quarried from nearby shores and from the town of Igbaras. Halfway through the construction, an elaborate bas-relief was carved on its triangular pediment.

Inscribed Rendicion de Tetuan (Surrender of Tetuan), the work depicted the Battle of Tetuan in Morocco in 1859, where Spanish troops under Gen Leopoldo O’Donnell defeated the Moors led by Moroccan Crown Prince Muley Abbas. The depiction of Rendicion was a manifestation of Santaren’s patriotism. Rendicion was done with the help of Spanish engineer Felipe Diaz and Filipino or perhaps Chinese carvers. Local imagination was used in delineating soldiers and horses, as if they were characters from a moro-moro drama, interspersed with local flora and fauna.

 

Inside the church is a stone retablo with sculptures of San Pedro and San Pablo. Traces of polychrome found on these images as well as on the Rendicion imply that a number of churches may also have had similar finishes. To the church’s left is the sprawling ruin of its old convent, notable for its wide oval well and a kiln for baking bread. Bells for the tower were cast in a still unlocated foundry in the vicinity of the church. Both tower and convento were damaged in the 1948 “Lady Caycay” earthquake.

Fr Santaren is remembered for his translation of the pseudo-history of the 10 datus from Borneo who were said to have landed in San Joaquin in the 13th century. He and his brother Hilario, also a priest, opened the road which cuts through the mountains to connect San Joaquin with Hamtic in Antique.

As notable as the church is the town’s cemetery or camposanto located about a kilometer to the east. Built by Fr Mariano Vamba, OSA in 1892, it is dominated by an octagonal capilla (chapel) of locally cut coral stone and red bricks, approached through a grand but steep stone staircase. Both cemetery entrance and capilla are decorated with bas-reliefs of flowers, leaves, and dentils.

In the 1980s and 1990s, the right and left side walls of the church were incorrectly reinforced with concrete. Both the apse and stone retablo were also reinforced, sealing the exposed mamposteria or rubblework. Restoration of various parts of the church was undertaken throughout the first decades of the 21st century.

San Joaquin Church was declared a historical site in 1972 by the National Historical Institute and a National Cultural Treasure on 31 Jul 2001 by the National Museum.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

(Franz Allan Rodriguez)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Luis Gonzaga. Location: San Luis, Pampanga. Built before 1883.

According to oral lore, the town of Cabagsa was renamed San Luis after Doña Luisa, the wife of a lawyer who worked in the town’s behalf against a land claim filed by the neighboring town of Santa Ana; Doña Luisa’s patron saint was San Luis Gonzaga, a Jesuit. The parish, administered by the Augustinians, is said to have been founded in the 1740s. Little is actually known about the history of the church building, except that it was greatly renovated in 1883.

The facade of the church presents a number of unique characteristics. First, it is concave, with the main entrance set deeper than the sides. Second, there are belfries instead of a pediment above the facade’s ground level; a pediment of sorts stands behind these belfries. Third, set in niches are images of saints belonging to the different orders not exactly known for their mutual friendship: the Jesuit, Luis Gonzaga, is the town’s patron while San Agustin represents the order who had jurisdiction over the parish. The joints of the cornice flanking the middle concave part are crowned with undulating dientzenhofer motifs, named after the family of architects who popularized these ornaments in the mid-18th century during the rococo period in Europe. With the exception of the dientzenhofer motifs, which are found surmounting churches and retablos elsewhere in the Philippines, all the other elements are found only in San Luis. Nineteenth-century neoclassical retablos have been preserved in its interior.

 

While the facade is purely of adobe blocks, the sides of the church consist of adobe blocks interspersed with square bricks laid horizontally. This technique, resulting in a checkerboard pattern, may have been one more attempt at strengthening the structure against earthquakes. Walls exhibiting this pattern can also be seen in Maragondon, Cavite, and Atimonan, Quezon.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

article_title: San Miguel Corporation Head Office Complex

photos.desc:
San Miguel Corporation Building in Mandaluyong City, 2008

(San Miguel Corporation)

text:
Location: Mandaluyong, Metro Manila. Built 1984. Architects: Manuel, Jose, and Francisco Mañosa.

The San Miguel Corporation (SMC) Head Office Building in the Ortigas Development has an unusual trapezoidal form that evokes an ancient stepped pyramid, a Babylonian ziggurat, or even the Ifugao rice terraces. Its very precisely aligned glass windows, perfectly reflecting everything beneath them, evoke American high-tech architecture of the late 20th century. The building employs sophisticated technology.

The SMC Building was designed by the Mañosa Brothers, Jose and Francisco, and was completed in 1984 with Jose Mañosa as supervising architect. The building consists of the 10-level Executive Tower and the Podium Mall, a glass-covered structure. The glass windows of the Tower are slanted 30 degrees to minimize heating by sunlight. Plant boxes serve as a cooling device outside the windows.

 

The tower, which has a total floor area of 42,000 sqm, houses the executive offices, as well as the cafeteria, sports facilities, social areas, a minimart, clinic, travel agency, and bank.

The air-conditioning system cools the eastern half of the building in the morning and the western half in the afternoon, and maintains a balanced temperature throughout the building. During noon breaks, stale air is pumped out and fresh air pumped in.

Although the interior spaces are extensive, work areas were planned so that no workstation is more than 15 m away from a window. Conference rooms, storage rooms, and utility rooms occupy the center of the building. Every floor has two employee lounges. On each floor are entrances, exits, and special facilities for the handicapped.

A computer-based building-automation system monitors and provides information to control and manage equipment operation and maintenance including air-conditioning, security, fire protection, electrical, and sanitary systems. The security system, which ensures the safety of employees and guests, has alarms, detectors, closed-circuit television, and card access to critical areas. At the basement of the building is the fireproof and flood-resistant records center, where document classification, storage, and retrieval are systematized. A vertical paper lift running through all floors transports documents, files, mail, and interoffice communications.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Facade and side view of the all-steel neo-Gothic San Sebastian Church

(Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)

Central nave, lateral aisles, vaulted ceiling, and stained glass windows of the Church of San Sebastian in Quiapo, Manila, 2013

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Sebastian. Location: Quiapo, Manila. Inaugurated 1891. Architect: Genaro Palacios.

The earthquakes of 1863 and 1880 severely damaged the Recollect church of San Sebastian. Wishing to build a church that would endure, the Recollects contracted the services of government engineer Genaro Palacios to design a church in the Gothic style, without flying buttresses, in the spirit of Revivalist architecture then in vogue. Plans for the church and all the necessary authorization were drawn while Fr Gregorio Sesma, OAR was vice-prior of San Sebastian from 1887 to 1888. The responsibility of overseeing the construction fell on Fr Bernardo Muro de la Virgen del Carmen, OAR, the prior, and Fr Remigio San Miguel de Santo Cristo, OAR. The former took charge of the legal work, the workers and consultants, and the procurement of materials; the latter supervised the daily work on the church. The church was blessed in the afternoon of 15 Aug 1891 by Fr Bernardino Nozaleda, OP, Archbishop of Manila. The inaugural Mass was celebrated the following morning, and festivities continued until 19 Aug with a triduum of thanksgiving. The festivities concluded with a procession at 9:30 pm, with the customary fireworks lit by the archbishop. The estimated cost of the church was more than 200,000 pesos.

 

The plans specified a building covering a 704-square-meter area, with a central nave 12 m high from floor to the springing of the dome, and towering 32 m to the tip of the spires. The church was to be all of steel plates.

The use of steel and cast-iron parts for construction was considered an innovation from the late 19th to the early 20th century. Steel was used extensively in Europe and the United States for commercial building, e.g., the cast-iron buildings in lower Manhattan, New York, the Crystal Palace exhibition halls, and the Victoria Train Station in London. However, it was rarely used for a church. The plans were sent to Belgium, where the parts were manufactured in sections and then sent to Manila onboard 10 steamships. The parts were then assembled and erected on the site of the old church and anchored to an elevated concrete pavement. A trench 4.70 m deep and 3.60 m wide was dug along the perimeter of the church. The trench was filled with masonry of lime, sand, and cement, which formed a wall. Trenches filled with mortar were also built to link the pilasters on the longitudinal side of the church and the main door with the sanctuary. This network of masonry was built to support the heavy steel structure. The load bearing columns, attached to cast-iron plates were sunk two meters into the ground, and a heavy load of steel was placed over these plates, forcing them to descend one more meter. Iron chains, 5 m in length and one ton in weight, tied the columns together. Likewise, chains were run along the perimeter to link the outer pillars together. The whole area defined by the perimeter was filled with clay, sand, and mortar, and leveled to form the support of the floor. Then the heavy gauged steel plates were riveted together to form walls. Cast-iron buttresses, windows, doors, cornices, and ornaments contributed to the aesthetics of the church.

As a neo-Gothic church, San Sebastian bears the mark of this style: spires, ogee arches, rose windows, stained glass, and tracery. As in all Gothic churches, the central aisle is flanked by a colonnade that divides it from the side aisles. The columns have a quadrilateral core surrounded by semicircular tubes. The transept crossing is crowned by a polygonal crossing tower. The ambulatory is shallow, and the side chapels that open into the ambulatory found in Gothic churches is missing in the floor plan of the church.

 

The columns in the church rise to form groin vaults, made of a slightly thinner gauge. As steel could not be worked as finely as stone, the church lacks the fine ornamentation characteristic of Gothic churches. The play of texture found in stone is also lacking. The exterior was originally painted with lead white. The church interior was painted with oils to resemble jasper and marble to make up for the lack of fine detail and texture. Grisaille, strategically added to openings, gave texture to the interior and disguised the material used for the church.

The five neo-Gothic altars finely wrought of wood and finished with gesso, paint, and gold leaf contributed to the sumptuous interior of the church. Originally, the main altar had an image of Nuestra Señora del Carmen flanked by images of San Simon Stock and Santa Teresita del Niño Jesus. It was flanked by an altar of the Sacred Heart and another of the Blessed Virgin. In the transept were the altars of the Santo Nino flanked by Santa Monica and Santa Rosa and the altar of San Jose flanked by the martyrs of Japan. The pulpit was decorated with scenes from the bible, the life of the Blessed Virgin, and the four great doctors of the Church.

The Filipino sculptor Eusebio Garcia worked on the sculptures of the church while Lorenzo Rocha did some of the paintings. Light entered through 12 stained-glass windows manufactured in Linnich, Germany depicting the mysteries of the Rosary. These added color to the interior.

The church has survived earthquakes but not the alternating seasons of rain and sun, which contribute to the corrosion of the structure. To preserve the church from further damage, the exterior has been cleaned and painted in shades of gray. The interior was recently restored, particularly the altars, which were painted and gilded.

With the corrosive and polluted atmosphere of downtown Manila, maintaining San Sebastian has been a challenge. So the church is repainted every so often, especially its exterior, which is now aqua in color rather than gray.  Written by René B. Javellana

Church of San Vicente in Ilocos Sur, 2012

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of San Vicente Ferrer. Location: San Vicente, Ilocos Sur. Built 19th century.

The churchyard is one of the few in the country surrounded by a swayback wall. The church is rectangular in plan. Aside from the front portal, there are two side portals, one of each side of the nave, facing each other. The convento is not located along the line of the facade, as is usually the case. It is at the rear, forming a right angle with the church. The buttresses supporting the sidewalls of the nave are unusual since they consist of plain sloping buttresses alternating with vertical buttresses that bulge at the bottom, suggesting the profile of a long-necked jug. Both types of buttresses have sloping tops.

Although not grand in scale, the facade is one of the gems of colonial church architecture in the Philippines. It is not a single plane like most church facades, but is slightly broken, with the central section appearing to protrude, while the side sections recede. The two-story front wall of the nave is crowned by a pediment. Engaged columns with ionic capitals and square bases divide the wall vertically into five sections. The end sections, which are narrower than the three in between, terminate in pilasters. On the pediment of the facade is an oval medallion with a trumpet, the symbol of San Vicente Ferrer, a Dominican and titular of the church.

 

The facade is flanked by two three-story bell towers which are as high as the pediment. The bell towers are square in plan on the first story and octagonal on the second and third stories. The sides of the octagonal stories are defined by engaged columns, and are alternately pierced by arched windows. The walls between windows are adorned with blind arches. The domed roof of each tower is surrounded by a low parapet, octagonal in plan, with a finial at each corner. Each dome is topped by a lantern.

The first story of the facade appears like a massive base for the upper stories. In its middle section is an arched portal, the main entrance of the church. In the central portion of the second story is an arched window. In each section flanking the middle is a round window, decorated with leaf-like forms on the upper half of the frame. On the second level of each bell tower, resting on the corners of the square-shaped first story, are tower-like finials.

From each end of the pediment, the raking cornice slopes upward then dips downward to form a shallow curve that rises and forms a volute that appears to lift the gable-shaped upper section of the pediment. On the horizontal cornice of the pediment are urn-like finials. Rising from the raking cornice of the pediment are seven finials—one on the apex, and three on each side.

The entire facade, including the bell tower, is characterized by the dynamic movement of lines and planes and the richness of forms. Although the facade has been described as baroque, its grace, lightness, and accented vertical thrust reveal a playful rococo spirit.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Side view of Santa Ana Church, 2016, showing side aisles added in the 1960s

(Kiko del Rosario)

Church of Santa Ana in Manila, one of the earliest missions of the Franciscans, 1993

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santa Ana. Location: Santa Ana, Manila. Started 1720.

Santa Ana was the first settlement outside Manila to be evangelized by the Franciscans. Called Sapa by the Tagalog, the settlement, which for centuries had traded with the Chinese and Arabs, stood at the confluence of the Pasig River and an estero (canal), called sapa, a Tagalog word for stream. In 1966, archaeological diggings in the courtyard of the Santa Ana Church and its surroundings uncovered burial sites rich with artifacts and tradeware dated to the Sung Dynasty, 1127-1279. These indicate that the settlement had achieved a high level of sophistication prior to the coming of the Spaniards. The first Franciscan provincial in the Philippines, Pedro de Alfaro, sent Juan de Plasencia, OFM, Diego de Oropesa, OFM, Juan de Garrovillas, OFM, and Francisco de Santa Maria, OFM, to convert the Tagalog of Sapa. In 1580 the Franciscan chapter appointed Pablo de Jesus, OFM, as first resident minister of Sapa.

 

The first church of bamboo and nipa was dedicated to Santa Ana, the Blessed Virgin’s mother. In 1599 the government allowed the construction of a stone church, which was begun not much later than this year. In 1720 construction of a larger stone church was begun under the direction of Vicente Ingles at a site different from that of the earlier church. The Archbishop of Manila Francisco Cuesta, concurrently acting as governor general, blessed the cornerstone on 12 Sep of the same year. Toward the construction of the church, the archbishop donated 4,000 pesos, while Ingles added to the sum from his own savings and from donations given by devotees to the Nuestra Señora de los Desamparados, an image of the Virgin enshrined in Santa Ana which Ingles brought from Spain. The total cost of the project was 33,000 pesos. During the Philippine Revolution of 1896, the church and convento were looted of its statuary, furniture, and church records. In the 1960s, the church was renovated with the addition of side aisles to accommodate the growing number of parishioners. Further intervention of the church fabric involved adding stained glass windows made of resin and covering the adobe stones with a cement and adobe mix, which would prove inimical to the structure in the long run. The altar was replastered, painted in enamel, and gilded with faux gold leaf.

 

The facade of the church is baroque. Tall and narrow, it is divided into three narrow vertical sections by engaged pilasters. The triangular pediment is pierced by two octagonal windows and a niche at the center, while volutes on the raking cornice crown it. The original church was cruciform in plan with an octagonal crossing tower. The four-story octagonal tower stands at the right of the facade. The church has a main retablo in the baroque style. Divided into horizontals and verticals, the retablo has a number of niches; the principal one houses the Virgin. Floral motifs decorate the columns of the retablo. Behind the main altar is a chapel called Camarin de la Virgen, the entrance of which is decorated with trompe l’oeil paintings depicting angels. The chapel’s focal point is a small shrine surmounted by a crown. This shrine directly leads to the Virgin’s image in the retablo. The octagonal ceiling is decorated with paintings.

Between 2008 and 2010, the Cofradia de la Inmaculada Concepcion and other devotees and heritage advocates restored the Camarin. Badly planned interventions using modern material incompatible with 18th century construction, painting materials, and techniques were removed. The painting in the Camarin was restored and its whole interior refurbished. Work also began on the main retablo, where layers of paint were removed beginning with the niche of the Virgin. The earliest layer of paint and true gold gilt was discovered and this guided the work of restoration.

The exterior walls of the nave were replastered with lime plaster and work continues at restoring the church properly.  Written by René B. Javellana

Church and convento of Santa Barbara in Iloilo, 2016

(Government of Santa Barbara, Iloilo)

text:
Roman Catholic Church of Santa Barbara Virgin and Martyr. Location: Santa Barbara, Iloilo. Built 1849–1878. Builders: Fr Francisco Agueria, Fr Mateo Rodriguez, Fr Calixto Fernandez.

Formerly a visita (mission chapel) of Jaro, the town of Santa Barbara became an independent parish in 1760, named after its patroness Santa Barbara Virgin and Martyr. It was earlier known as Catmon, after the plant Dilenia bracteata or Dilenia speciosa, with San Pedro Apostol as its titular patron. The town’s fertile land is irrigated by the Salog river to its north and east, and by the Aganan river on the west.

In 1617, the Augustinians considered transferring the seat of the Jaro parish to Catmon due to its wider and better location. This plan never materialized. After its independence from Jaro and subsequent renaming to Santa Barbara, its progress declined because its political system was ruled only by a privileged few individuals. Up to 1820, its residents were involved in hunting, agriculture, and wood cutting. They also supported themselves through cultivation of tobacco, wheat production, and weaving. Santa Barbara was known for its musical bands, touted as some of the best in the whole of Iloilo. Today, its musical bands continue to perform during religious activities, though not in as grand a scale as before.

 

The construction of the town’s present church was started by Fr Francisco Agueria in 1849. It is made of limestone blocks quarried from the towns of Alimodian, Leon, and Tubungan. It replaced an older church destroyed in 1787 by an earthquake. The stone edifice started by Fr Agueria was continued by Fr Mateo Rodriguez from 1855 to 1873 and eventually finished by Fr Calixto Fernandez in 1878. The adjacent convent, with floors made of piedra silleria (cut stone) was constructed simultaneously with the church. Both church and convent served as the headquarters of the revolutionary government in Western Visayas led by Gen Martin Delgado. During the Philippine Revolution, both were spared from destruction. They also survived World War II and the “Lady Caycay” earthquake of 1948. On the occasion of the 220th founding anniversary of Santa Barbara, both structures were restored by Msgr Enrique Perez.

The church’s Renaissance-baroque facade has well-unified designs of arches, pillasters, and vas finials. It is divided into three vertical registers and three horizontal sections. The vertical divisions are defined by four twin Ionic pilasters mounted on rectangular bases. The horizontal sections are defined by friezes. In the center of the first story is an arched entrance. Flanking it are niches with statues. This design of arches is echoed at the second story.

The church pediment consists of another shorter story with a niche with statue, crowned by a pediment and finials at the center register. The center is flanked on either side by broken arches that link the pediment to the second story. The facade is embellished with the seal of the Augustinian Order and the Holy See.

The convento follows an L-plan, with its main wing running parallel to the facade and attached to it, and the adjoining wing running perpendicular and attached to the main wing. It lacks a fourth wing to make it a complete atrium. The convento is built in the manner of the bahay na bato (stone house), with a lower story in coral stone and brick, and an upper story of wood. The upper story has a volada (cantelivered overhang), sliding ventanillas (small windows), and capiz windows. But the gem of the convento is found inside. Passing through the main entrance, one is led to an inner garden through archways and a brick colonnade that supports the corridor on the second floor. This corridor of wood is decorated with wooden cutout arches reminiscent of the Victorian gingerbread style. An English connection may not be too far fetched, because with the opening of the Iloilo port to world trade in 1856, the British were actually operating in the Visayas, engaged in the developing sugar industry. The church and convent are examples of better preserved structures in Iloilo that still maintain their Spanish colonial architectural features.

Another notable Spanish-era structure in the town is its stone cemetery, built in 1878-88 by Fr Mateo Rodriguez, using materials coming from possibly the same places as those used in the construction of the church and convent. The cemetery facade bears similarity to the facade of the church. The striking unique feature of this cemetery is the stone tablet located above the arched entrance. It bears an inscription written in Hiligaynon, “Ig-ampo niño cami. Car-on sa amun, buas sa iño.” It translates to “Pray for us. Today is ours, tomorrow is yours.”

Santa Barbara Church and Convent were declared National Historical Landmarks in 1990 by the National Historical Institute, and National Cultural Treasures on 17 Nov 2013 by the National Museum.

In 2013, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP) conducted a detailed engineering study (DES) and architectural investigation on the Santa Barbara church complex and found minor cracks. Actual conservation activities started in Jan 2014. Cleaning of stone surfaces was conducted by the NHCP.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano, with notes from René B. Javellana

Galende, Pedro, OSA. (1987) 1996. Angels in Stone: Architecture of Augustinian Churches in the Philippines. Metro Manila: G.A. Formoso Publishing. 1996 hardcover ed. Manila: San Agustin Museum.

article.value: Roman Catholic Church of Santa Barbara Virgin and Martyr. Location: Santa Barbara, Iloilo. Built 1849–1878. Builders: Fr Francisco Agueria, Fr Mateo Rodriguez, Fr Calixto Fernandez.

Formerly a visita (mission chapel) of Jaro, the town of Santa Barbara became an independent parish in 1760, named after its patroness Santa Barbara Virgin and Martyr. It was earlier known as Catmon, after the plant Dilenia bracteata or Dilenia speciosa, with San Pedro Apostol as its titular patron. The town’s fertile land is irrigated by the Salog river to its north and east, and by the Aganan river on the west.

In 1617, the Augustinians considered transferring the seat of the Jaro parish to Catmon due to its wider and better location. This plan never materialized. After its independence from Jaro and subsequent renaming to Santa Barbara, its progress declined because its political system was ruled only by a privileged few individuals. Up to 1820, its residents were involved in hunting, agriculture, and wood cutting. They also supported themselves through cultivation of tobacco, wheat production, and weaving. Santa Barbara was known for its musical bands, touted as some of the best in the whole of Iloilo. Today, its musical bands continue to perform during religious activities, though not in as grand a scale as before.

value.desc:
Church and convento of Santa Barbara in Iloilo, 2016

(Government of Santa Barbara, Iloilo)

article.value: The construction of the town’s present church was started by Fr Francisco Agueria in 1849. It is made of limestone blocks quarried from the towns of Alimodian, Leon, and Tubungan. It replaced an older church destroyed in 1787 by an earthquake. The stone edifice started by Fr Agueria was continued by Fr Mateo Rodriguez from 1855 to 1873 and eventually finished by Fr Calixto Fernandez in 1878. The adjacent convent, with floors made of piedra silleria (cut stone) was constructed simultaneously with the church. Both church and convent served as the headquarters of the revolutionary government in Western Visayas led by Gen Martin Delgado. During the Philippine Revolution, both were spared from destruction. They also survived World War II and the “Lady Caycay” earthquake of 1948. On the occasion of the 220th founding anniversary of Santa Barbara, both structures were restored by Msgr Enrique Perez.

The church’s Renaissance-baroque facade has well-unified designs of arches, pillasters, and vas finials. It is divided into three vertical registers and three horizontal sections. The vertical divisions are defined by four twin Ionic pilasters mounted on rectangular bases. The horizontal sections are defined by friezes. In the center of the first story is an arched entrance. Flanking it are niches with statues. This design of arches is echoed at the second story.

The church pediment consists of another shorter story with a niche with statue, crowned by a pediment and finials at the center register. The center is flanked on either side by broken arches that link the pediment to the second story. The facade is embellished with the seal of the Augustinian Order and the Holy See.

The convento follows an L-plan, with its main wing running parallel to the facade and attached to it, and the adjoining wing running perpendicular and attached to the main wing. It lacks a fourth wing to make it a complete atrium. The convento is built in the manner of the bahay na bato (stone house), with a lower story in coral stone and brick, and an upper story of wood. The upper story has a volada (cantelivered overhang), sliding ventanillas (small windows), and capiz windows. But the gem of the convento is found inside. Passing through the main entrance, one is led to an inner garden through archways and a brick colonnade that supports the corridor on the second floor. This corridor of wood is decorated with wooden cutout arches reminiscent of the Victorian gingerbread style. An English connection may not be too far fetched, because with the opening of the Iloilo port to world trade in 1856, the British were actually operating in the Visayas, engaged in the developing sugar industry. The church and convent are examples of better preserved structures in Iloilo that still maintain their Spanish colonial architectural features.

Another notable Spanish-era structure in the town is its stone cemetery, built in 1878-88 by Fr Mateo Rodriguez, using materials coming from possibly the same places as those used in the construction of the church and convent. The cemetery facade bears similarity to the facade of the church. The striking unique feature of this cemetery is the stone tablet located above the arched entrance. It bears an inscription written in Hiligaynon, “Ig-ampo niño cami. Car-on sa amun, buas sa iño.” It translates to “Pray for us. Today is ours, tomorrow is yours.”
Santa Barbara Church and Convent were declared National Historical Landmarks in 1990 by the National Historical Institute, and National Cultural Treasures on 17 Nov 2013 by the National Museum.

In 2013, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP) conducted a detailed engineering study (DES) and architectural investigation on the Santa Barbara church complex and found minor cracks. Actual conservation activities started in Jan 2014. Cleaning of stone surfaces was conducted by the NHCP.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano, with notes from René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Church of the Asuncion de la Virgen in Santa Maria, Ilocos Sur, 2015

(Jernel Pateña)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion. Location: Santa Maria, Ilocos Sur. Built ca 1824.

An early account mentions that the church and convento of Santa Maria were burned during a revolt in 1660, implying the existence of these buildings as early as that time. Santa Maria is said to have been erected as a parish in 1769. According to legend, the original chapel used to stand at the foot of a large hill. An image of Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion venerated here would often disappear, only to be found on a guava tree on top of the hill. The periodic disappearances led to the transfer of the church to the hill, its present site. The relocation on the hill, however, was most probably because of the frequent piratical attacks on lowland coastal communities at that time. The church on a hill provided not only a convenient watchtower which commands a panoramic view of the sea, but also a refuge in case of attacks.

Aside from its unusual location, Santa Maria is also unusual because its convento is located opposite and across from the main church facade, while its bell tower is found beside the middle of the length of the nave. Most conventos adjoin the facade to one side, with the bell tower usually on the other side. This arrangement may have been dictated by the longitudinal contour of the hilltop.

What most probably were wooden structures were burned down in 1822. Reconstruction began in1824. The present church may have been built at this time, for it coincides with the start of Santa Maria as a center for the Augustinian missionaries assigned to evangelize among the Tinguian of the nearby mountains of Abra. The extraordinary long apse, lined on both sides with stone altars for the various devotions of the priests, may be evidence of this, as it suggests a large community of priests typical of a center for missionaries.

 

The convento suffered some damage from the earthquake of 1880 and was repaired. It must have been during this time that neo-Gothic pointed windows were applied on one of its sides.

From any angle, the approach to the Santa Maria Church is magnificent. A colossal stairway of 85 stone steps leads from the old school to the church buildings. Another stairway on the opposite side of the hill leads down to the cemetery. The rest of the hillside is covered with huge blocks of stone, giving the site the look of a citadel. All the buildings, including the school and the cemetery, are of brick. The walls of the church are very thick, bolstered by huge quadrangular buttresses. The facade is plain and undecorated. It is framed by two exaggerated cylindrical columns. The pediment is curved, a feature shared by the twin school buildings and the cemetery chapel, located below the hill. Their architectural similarities strongly imply that all were built at the same time. The National Historical Institute installed a historical marker on Santa Maria in 1974 and declared it a National Historical Landmark in 1978. It 1993, it was inscribed in the UNESCO World Heritage List under the title “Baroque Churches of the Philippines.”  Written by Regalado Trota Jose, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
Fifth Santo Domingo. Location: Intramuros, Manila. Built 1864-67. Architect: Felix Roxas Sr, sixth Santo Domingo. Location: Quezon Ave, Quezon City. Inaugurated 1954. Architect: Jose Maria Zaragoza.

The Dominicans arrived in Manila in 1587. Welcomed by the bishop of Manila Domingo de Salazar and the city council, they sought lodging with the Franciscans in Manila, while some friars were sent to Bataan and Pangasinan to start mission work. With the bishop contributing 300 pesos for land and 3,000 pesos for the construction of a church, ground was broken on 6 Aug 1587 for a small church of light materials. The church, completed on 1 Jan 1588, housed the image of the Nuestra Señora del Rosario which the Dominicans brought from Mexico. In 1589 the roof of this first church collapsed, and the friars decided to build a much bigger church using more durable material.

 

This second church of stone was completed and inaugurated on 9 Apr 1592. A fire on 30 Apr 1603, which destroyed a third of the city, consumed both the church and the convento.

A third church, bigger and costlier, which had a stone vault as a precaution against fire, was built almost immediately. On 30 Nov 1610, the feast of San Andres, the church collapsed during an earthquake.

A fourth church of stone and hardwood was built. This time, wooden posts supported the roof and divided the church into a central nave with side aisles. The church took two years to build. The structural soundness of the church made it last for 250 years. A new facade, flanked by two towers and patterned after London’s St Paul’s Cathedral designed by Christopher Wren, was built for the church. The facade lasted almost a year. It was inaugurated on 15 Jun 1862. But on 3 Jun 1863, the eve of the feast of Corpus Christi, the church was ruined by an earthquake of the same intensity as that which hit Manila in 1610.

 

From 1864 to 1867 the fifth church was built in the gotico fingido (neo-Gothic) style. This measured 70 m long, 31 m wide, and 22 m high at the central aisles, and 16.6 m high at the lateral aisles. Its towers rose to 23.3 m. Although Fr Sixto, OP, and Fr Ristoro, OP, would supervise construction of the church, the Dominicans contracted the services of the European-trained architect Felix Roxas Sr. Roxas, adapting to seismic realities, designed a church with a lower story of stone and an upper story of wood. He worked closely with Isabelo Tampinco who decorated the interior with carving imitating the fan vault reminiscent of the English Gothic. The walls and the ceiling of the sacristy were similarly treated. Even the furniture in the sacristy was treated in the Gothic manner. Noteworthy was a vesting table with niches containing relics. The chapel of the Nuestra Señora del Rosario had an altar with lancet arches and Gothic-inspired ornamented pinnacles. Colored glass chandeliers imported from Europe hung inside the church. Fr Joaquin Sabater, OP, professor of drawing at the Universidad de Santo Tomas (UST), designed and supervised the construction of four retablos. That of the Virgin was embellished with reliefs of the Mysteries of the Rosary and titles of the Virgin from the Litany of Loreto, and figures of the apostles and prophets in high relief. The images of Santo Domingo, Santa Catalina, and the four evangelists were in the round retablos. The gilded main retablo had two parts, the lower occupied by an image of Santo Domingo and the upper by an image of Maria Magdalena. The columns surrounding the sanctuary were decorated with images of Dominican saints. Behind the altar was the choir, where the friars gathered for their devotions separate from the congregation.

 

The church incurred damage over time and was repaired. In 1887 the vault and the rose windows of batikuling were restored. The main altar was almost totally renovated, and the columns repaired. The roofs of the bell towers were renovated to assume a crown-like form. The second to the fifth Santo Domingos were bound by a common symbol, the image of the Nuestra Señora del Santisimo Rosario or La Naval de Manila which was solemnly crowned on 5 Oct 1907.

On 21 Dec 1941, the church and the Dominican convento beside it were hit by Japanese bombs. This was the first church to be ruined during the Pacific War. The friars, their archives, the image of the Nuestra Señora del Rosario, and some movable property like ivory statues, the gala vestments of the Virgin, jewelry, and sacred vessels were the only survivors of the war. The friars had kept valuable items inside a cement vault.

After World War II, the Dominicans decided to move out of Intramuros and the lot occupied by the Santo Domingo was acquired by the Bank of the Philippine Islands. The Dominicans built the postwar Santo Domingo in a lot they had purchased in Quezon City. Built in the Spanish Moderne style, so called by its architect Jose Maria Zaragoza, the church employed the latest technique in reinforced-concrete building. The church and its adjoining quadrangle and living quarters were inaugurated on 12 Oct 1954. The church facade has receding planes with eaves designed in corbel arches. Over the triple portals of the church is a high-relief frieze depicting the story of the La Naval designed by the Italian sculptor Francesco Monti, then a professor at the UST. The gigantic sculpture of Santo Domingo that graces the otherwise plain quadrilateral bell tower is also by Monti. The interior gives a sense of expansiveness, as the nave gives full view of the apse whose focal point is a mosaic of Santo Domingo with a dog carrying a fiery brand designed by Zaragoza. The pendentives supporting the quadrilateral-crossing tower are designed as reliefs of the four evangelists depicted as winged creatures or the tetramorph. Monti designed the reliefs. Above these are murals of the evangelists by Antonio Llamas. Other areas beneath the crossing tower are decorated with eight murals by Carlos “Botong” Francisco depicting scenes from the life of Santo Domingo. Galo B. Ocampo designed the stained glass of the church, whose bases show different ecclesiastical seals. The image of La Naval is kept on the side altar all year round, except during the October fiesta when a special canopy and platforms are built for it behind the main altar. The canopy is designed like a retablo in the neo-Gothic style reminiscent of the prewar Santo Domingo. Curtains in gold, white, and blue adorn the sanctuary for the festivities.

Work to maintain the church continues. The exterior has been repainted several times. The frieze, at one time, was painted silver, but it has been restored to white, which has long been its color.  Written by René B. Javellana

Santo Niño Basilica and Monastery in Cebu City

 (A Philippine Album: American Era Photographs 1900-1930 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1998)

text:
Location: Cebu City. Built 1735 onwards. Basilica completed 1739; monastery completed 1760.

The Basilica Minore del Santo Niño is the shrine of the Santo Niño de Cebu, oldest known Catholic image in the Philippines. During the conquest of Cebu by the Spaniards in 1565, one of the soldiers of Legazpi found the image in a wooden box in an abandoned house. It is said to be the same image which Magellan gave the queen of Cebu in 1521 after she was baptized. On seeing the image, Legazpi declared that the statue should be enshrined in the first church to be built in the place and that it should be called the Church of the Santisimo Nombre de Jesus. Since then the image of the Santo Niño has been in the custody of the Augustinians.

Fr Diego de Herrera, OSA, is said to have built the first church, made of wood and nipa, which was completed 21 years later. This building was destroyed by fire in 1628. A church of brick and stone was built that same year by Fr Juan Medina, OSA. This church appears in a 1699 map of Cebu. By 1729 the church needed major structural repairs. The Augustinian chapter of 31 Oct 1729 decided that the church be rebuilt. In 1731, Fr Jose Bosqued, OSA, informed the governor-general that the building should be demolished and a new one built on its site. Construction began but the project was suspended when the walls were found to be defective, being made of bricks that easily crumbled.

 

The foundations for a church made of stone were laid in 1735. The project was directed by Fr Juan de Albarran, OSA, who left his experiences in an unpublished work, “Arte de construir Iglesias en Filipinas” (Art of Constructing Churches in the Philippines). The stones came from quarries on Mactan and Panay islands which were brought to Cebu by banca. Molave for trusses came from the mountains of southern Cebu. Coral stones, transported to the site by banca, were used to make lime for mortar. Records show that wage laborers from San Nicolas, Carcar, and Boljoon worked on the church for five years. The building was completed in 1739. On 16 Jan 1740, the image of the Santo Niño was installed in the new church. According to an inscription over its entrance, the convento was completed in 1760.

Repairs were undertaken in 1782. Two side altars were constructed between 1861 and 1865. In 1889, glass windows and iron grills were installed, two side altars were added, the floor was finished with marble, and the interior and main altar were painted. In preparation for the Fourth Centenary of the Christianization of the Philippines in 1965, both church and convento were restored and renovated. Of the four arcos torales (semicircular arches) at the transept, the two transverse arches were removed. The two side altars were also removed. On 1 Apr 1965, under a special privilege granted by Pope Paul VI to the Augustinian Order, the church was recognized as the mater et caput (mother and head) of all churches in the country and at the same time declared a basilica minore. In 1973, Pres Ferdinand Marcos declared it a national historical shrine.

 

The church is cruciform in plan with a transept half the length of the nave. The walls are of coral stone and range from 1 to 1.5 m in thickness. The facade, including the bell tower and the convento portal, is a masterpiece of balance and harmony. The two-story sections are divided by thin pilasters into three vertical sections. The three-story belfry is hexagonal in plan. This disposition of elements influenced the later Cebuano churches of San Nicolas, Boljoon, Dalaguete, Argao, Opon, and Samboan.

The trefoil arch of the church portal is echoed in the small relief above it and in the convento’s portal, as well as in the shallow niche on the second story of the bell tower. The relief over the portal is flanked by small pilasters topped with small finials and adorned with florid flanges in the baroque manner. A triangular pediment rests over the relief. The central panel of the facade has its own pediment echoing the main pediment on which it is imposed. The resulting three layers of pediments on the central panel are unique in Philippine colonial church architecture.

Each side section of the facade has an arched window on the second-story resting directly on the cornice. Under these windows on the first story are large reliefs, each portraying an Augustinian saint in a florid rectangular frame resting on a fan-shaped console adorned with volutes.

The wall on the bell tower along the line of the church facade has an image in a trefoil niche on the second story and another relieve of a saint on the first story.

 

The interior of the basilica has two important features: the ornate retablo and the coro-cum-tribuna (choir loft with balcony). The first is a three-story structure with seven niches each on the first and second stories and two niches and a relief on the last. Salomonica columns and carved flanges and statues of Augustinian saints make the retablo impressive, perhaps the widest of its kind in the Philippines. The coro-cum-tribuna is distinguished for its mudejar-style carvings of flat screen-like balustrades. Notable too are the carved benches and the oil portraits.

The Santo Niño is now enshrined in a bulletproof altar. The convento has been renovated and the atrium between the church and the adjoining convento has been landscaped and decorated. To accommodate the large crowd that attends the Sinulog fiesta, celebrated on the third weekend of January to honor the Santo Niño, an altar and a grandstand have been built along the perimeter of the church plaza.

During a strong earthquake on 15 Oct 2013, a part of the belfry, including its bulbous coral stone roof, tumbled down and broke into pieces. Inventory and restoration efforts with the help of several cultural agencies are now done bringing the belfry back to its original form.  Written by Resil B. Mojares, with notes from Trizer Dale D. Mansueto, René B. Javellana, and Regalado Trota Jose

It is said to be the same image which Magellan gave the queen of Cebu in 1521 after she was baptized. On seeing the image, Legazpi declared that the statue should be enshrined in the first church to be built in the place and that it should be called the Church of the Santisimo Nombre de Jesus. Since then the image of the Santo Niño has been in the custody of the Augustinians.

Fr Diego de Herrera, OSA, is said to have built the first church, made of wood and nipa, which was completed 21 years later. This building was destroyed by fire in 1628. A church of brick and stone was built that same year by Fr Juan Medina, OSA. This church appears in a 1699 map of Cebu. By 1729 the church needed major structural repairs. The Augustinian chapter of 31 Oct 1729 decided that the church be rebuilt. In 1731, Fr Jose Bosqued, OSA, informed the governor-general that the building should be demolished and a new one built on its site. Construction began but the project was suspended when the walls were found to be defective, being made of bricks that easily crumbled.

Carved staircase and newel post in the convento of the Santo Niño Basilica Minore, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

article.value: The foundations for a church made of stone were laid in 1735. The project was directed by Fr Juan de Albarran, OSA, who left his experiences in an unpublished work, “Arte de construir Iglesias en Filipinas” (Art of Constructing Churches in the Philippines). The stones came from quarries on Mactan and Panay islands which were brought to Cebu by banca. Molave for trusses came from the mountains of southern Cebu. Coral stones, transported to the site by banca, were used to make lime for mortar. Records show that wage laborers from San Nicolas, Carcar, and Boljoon worked on the church for five years. The building was completed in 1739. On 16 Jan 1740, the image of the Santo Niño was installed in the new church. According to an inscription over its entrance, the convento was completed in 1760.

Repairs were undertaken in 1782. Two side altars were constructed between 1861 and 1865. In 1889, glass windows and iron grills were installed, two side altars were added, the floor was finished with marble, and the interior and main altar were painted. In preparation for the Fourth Centenary of the Christianization of the Philippines in 1965, both church and convento were restored and renovated. Of the four arcos torales (semicircular arches) at the transept, the two transverse arches were removed. The two side altars were also removed. On 1 Apr 1965, under a special privilege granted by Pope Paul VI to the Augustinian Order, the church was recognized as the mater et caput (mother and head) of all churches in the country and at the same time declared a basilica minore. In 1973, Pres Ferdinand Marcos declared it a national historical shrine.

(CCP Collection)

article.value: The church is cruciform in plan with a transept half the length of the nave. The walls are of coral stone and range from 1 to 1.5 m in thickness. The facade, including the bell tower and the convento portal, is a masterpiece of balance and harmony. The two-story sections are divided by thin pilasters into three vertical sections. The three-story belfry is hexagonal in plan. This disposition of elements influenced the later Cebuano churches of San Nicolas, Boljoon, Dalaguete, Argao, Opon, and Samboan.

The trefoil arch of the church portal is echoed in the small relief above it and in the convento’s portal, as well as in the shallow niche on the second story of the bell tower. The relief over the portal is flanked by small pilasters topped with small finials and adorned with florid flanges in the baroque manner. A triangular pediment rests over the relief. The central panel of the facade has its own pediment echoing the main pediment on which it is imposed. The resulting three layers of pediments on the central panel are unique in Philippine colonial church architecture.

Each side section of the facade has an arched window on the second-story resting directly on the cornice. Under these windows on the first story are large reliefs, each portraying an Augustinian saint in a florid rectangular frame resting on a fan-shaped console adorned with volutes.
The wall on the bell tower along the line of the church facade has an image in a trefoil niche on the second story and another relieve of a saint on the first story.

value.desc:
Santo Niño Basilica and Monastery in Cebu City

 (A Philippine Album: American Era Photographs 1900-1930 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1998)

article.value: The interior of the basilica has two important features: the ornate retablo and the coro-cum-tribuna (choir loft with balcony). The first is a three-story structure with seven niches each on the first and second stories and two niches and a relief on the last. Salomonica columns and carved flanges and statues of Augustinian saints make the retablo impressive, perhaps the widest of its kind in the Philippines. The coro-cum-tribuna is distinguished for its mudejar-style carvings of flat screen-like balustrades. Notable too are the carved benches and the oil portraits.

The Santo Niño is now enshrined in a bulletproof altar. The convento has been renovated and the atrium between the church and the adjoining convento has been landscaped and decorated. To accommodate the large crowd that attends the Sinulog fiesta, celebrated on the third weekend of January to honor the Santo Niño, an altar and a grandstand have been built along the perimeter of the church plaza.

During a strong earthquake on 15 Oct 2013, a part of the belfry, including its bulbous coral stone roof, tumbled down and broke into pieces. Inventory and restoration efforts with the help of several cultural agencies are now done bringing the belfry back to its original form.  Written by Resil B. Mojares, with notes from Trizer Dale D. Mansueto, René B. Javellana, and Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Church of San Francisco de Asis in Sariaya, Quezon, 2010

(National Historical Commission of the Philippines Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish of San Francisco de Asis Church Complex. Location: Sariaya, Quezon. Built by Fr Joaquin Alapon, OFM, 1748. Present church completed 1748, renovated 1850.

Sariaya, founded in 1582, was one of the first towns of the present province of Quezon. Its Christianization was undertaken by the Franciscans, who dedicated the town to Santa Clara. In 1605, the town was placed under the jurisdiction of Tayabas. It was reestablished in 1631 along the banks of the Cayanuang River. A stone church was constructed on this new site from 1632 to 1641—this time, it was dedicated to San Francisco de Asis. In 1703 Sariaya was transferred a third time to a place called Tumbaga or Lumang Bayan. An eruption of Mt Banahaw in 1730 forced the town a year after to move a fourth time. The eruption also formed a lake in the caldera of Banahaw. A lip of the caldera collapsed in 1743, releasing boulders and torrents of water that destroyed the townsite and the stone church in Tumbaga as well. Thus, Sariaya relocated for the fifth and last time to the place it presently occupies. On this site Fr Joaquin Alapon, OFM, built a stone church and convento, which were completed in 1748. The church was repaired in 1850. It was painted and renovated by Fr Andres Alvarez, OFM, who also had the old convento demolished and a new one built. As with other towns established by the Franciscans along the slopes of Banahaw, fresh water ran through the community in canals, and stone and brick bridges were built to cross the many rivers that fertilized the town.

 

The silhouette of the Sariaya Church is similar to many Franciscan churches in the Tagalog region. A triangular pediment crowns the ornamented facade whose vertical sweep is defined by paired Corinthian columns. As with other Franciscan churches, its facade is crammed with bas-reliefs. Flanking the main door are two escutcheons, the left one depicting the Jerusalem cross and the right, the Franciscan emblem. Cherub heads fill the arch of the main portal and of the second-story windows. A niche with an image of the Inmaculada Concepcion surmounts the main portal, while the pediment is decorated with a niche in which the statue of the church’s titular is depicted. Movement is suggested by the wide horizontal band that crests over the openings. To the facade’s right is the four-story bell tower. Its first two levels are quadrilateral, while its higher level is octagonal. Balusters decorate the base of the dome that crowns the tower. In this cruciform church, the nave is divided from the transept by double arches forming an unusual arcade. The octagonal crossing tower is also unusual for two of its sides are longer than the rest, thus forming a shape nearly ovoid. The pendentives supporting the crossing tower are decorated with paintings of the evangelists in gilt frames surmounted by bunches of flowers and a crown. Three neoclassical altars with floral flanges on either side are found in the church. The main one has many images of Franciscan saints. The church’s unique pulpit has pierced panels and an onion-shaped base that melds into the wall. Its torna voz (ceiling) is shaped as a crown. The whole ensemble is painted in gold and white, a pleasing contrast to the black and white Machuca tiles that decorate the wall and the floor.

Sariaya’s exterior has been restored by replastering and painting. The interior has likewise been repainted, the pulpit and the retablo refurbished. Sariaya Church was marked by the Philippines Historical Committee in 1938.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
Brick facade of the Church of Santa Monica in Sarrat, Ilocos Norte, 1995

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

Wood trusses of Sarrat Church, a rarity among Philippine churches, 1995

(Regalado Trota Jose)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of Santa Monica. Location: Sarrat, Ilocos Norte. Present church dates from about 1848 and after; convento inaugurated 1896, although unfinished.

Sarrat was known by various names throughout its dramatic history. It was once called Cabayugan, after a kind of bamboo in the area. It was listed as Santa Monica de Sarrat in 1586 when the Augustinians established it as a mission station of Laoag further down the Padsan River. Separated and erected as a parish in 1724, it was then called San Miguel de Sarrat, but occasionally San Miguel de Cuming after an abundant saffron-like plant. Finally, it was officially changed to Sarrat in 1917.

Sarrat was one of the richest towns in the Ilocos, essentially due to its cotton textile industry. However, its people joined the Basi Revolt in 1807. In 1815, the cailianes (common people) rose up against the principales (land-owning local elite) and the friars, ending with the church and town in ashes. This incident led to the formal partition of Ilocos into two provinces. Sarrat would have been the capital of Ilocos Norte, except that Laoag had a larger population.

 

After 1815, Sarrat relocated on a promontory on the other side of the river, apparently standing guard over what could have been its old seat in Nagrebcan (destroyed). On 3 Mar 1816 both church and convento caught fire, and it is after this date that the extant parish books commence. The convento was reconstructed in 1817, while the church was rebuilt in 1848. The preponderance of classical elements on a monumental scale implies that much of the form of the church dates from the first half of the middle of the 19th century. Both structures burned down again in 1882. The grandly reconstructed but not quite completed convento was inaugurated in Jun 1896. To one side is a well finished on 21 May 1895. Expense records in the parish archives indicate that work was still in full swing when the Philippine Revolution spread to Sarrat in 1898. The church was occupied by the Iglesia Filipina Independiente from the early 1900s to 1910, when it was returned to the Catholics on 1 Feb 1910.

The earthquake of 19 Mar 1931 toppled the bell tower and damaged the church and convento. The Philippines Historical Committee placed a historical marker on the facade in 1959. In 1977 the protective stucco was peeled off from the walls of both buildings. Another earthquake in 1983 caused the church’s pediment and part of the apse to fall. Unfortunately, the rebuilding did not follow the lines of the 19th century original.

Despite extensive earthquake damage, many original aspects and details can still be observed in the interior. Most striking is its size—the nave, said to be about 105 m, is the longest in the province. All three brick retablos are intact and still maintain their palitada (stucco). Like the 19th century facade, they were built in the neoclassical idiom, with smooth massive columns flanking niches for saints’ images. But surely the most important treasure of the church is its roof trusswork. In this excellent example of the par y nudillo (collar-beam roof) system learned from the Hispanic world, hundreds of logs seem miraculously locked in place without benefit of any supporting columns from below. This is one of the most amazing architectural feats of its kind in the Philippines, and cannot be replicated even with today’s technology.

 

A picturesque brick bridge on three arches leads from the church choir loft to the second story of the all-brick convento. Each arch delineates a dome with special acoustic properties.

 

Both levels of the convento are of brick, but the application of the protective lime plaster was interrupted in 1898 and never resumed. Zialcita describes the convento’s method of cooling as the “thermos effect”—i.e., a corridor runs between the external walls and the inner wall—thus sheltering the rooms from the solar heat. Large brick shrines distributed along the main street of the town mark the route of the penitential Stations of the Cross procession.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

De los Reyes, Isabelo. 1890. Historia de Ilocos. Vol 2. Manila: Establecimiento tipografico La Opinion.

Galende, Pedro, OSA. (1987) 1996. Angels in Stone: Architecture of Augustinian Churches in the Philippines. Metro Manila: G.A. Formoso Publishing. 1996 hardcover ed. Manila: San Agustin Museum.

Ilocos Norte: A Travel Guidebook. 2004. Laoag: Gameng Foundation, Inc.

Jose, Regalado Trota. 2001a. A Chronology of Ilocos Norte History 1572-1999. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

photos.desc:
Church of the Nuestra Señora de Candelaria in Silang, Cavite, 1994

(Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)

text:
Roman Catholic Parish Church of the Nuestra Señora de Candelaria. Location: Silang, Cavite. Built 1637-39. Architect: Juan Salazar.

In 1585, the Franciscans evangelized Silang and, 10 years later, established it as a parish. For lack of personnel, the Franciscans turned over the parish to the Jesuits. In 1601, the Jesuits assigned Frs Lopez and Seguera to Silang. In 1603, a church, probably of wood, was consumed by fire. The present church was probably built between 1637 and 1639; certainly it was standing before 1645. The church is attributed to the Jesuit Juan Salazar, who was both provincial superior from 1637 to 1639 and responsible for the churches of Taytay and Antipolo. The Silang Church, although lacking in architectural beauty, is a sturdy structure with thick walls and stout buttresses supporting the rear wall and the gospel-side nave. The plain church facade, flanked by a squat bell tower, gives no indication of the stunning and well-preserved retablos within.

 

There are three retablos, probably from the last decades of the 17th century and the early decades of the 18th century. The central retablo depicting the life of the Blessed Virgin is divided into three stories. The first two have alternating statuaries and reliefs. Five reliefs depict incidents in Mary’s life—the Annunciation, the Nativity, the Visit of the Magi, the Presentation, and the Coronation of Mary. Statuaries enclosed by niches and flanked by either salomonica or Corinthian columns depict the patriarch, the apostles, and Franciscan and Jesuit saints. The third-story relief depicts the Santo Niño de Ternate being adored by the Jesuits San Ignacio and San Francisco. Pendant tropical fruits link the third with the lower stories, while flowers and vases flank them. Angel heads and large fernlike volutes decorate the arbotantes (flanges) of the retablo.

The three-story side retablos follow the decorative scheme of the main retablo: alternating reliefs and statuaries; salomonica and Corinthian columns; fruits, flowers, and angels. The right-side retablo contains images of Jesuit saints. The top story depicts the martyrs of Japan, Paul Miki and his companions, perhaps the earliest depiction of these saints in Philippine altars. The left-side retablo depicts female saints—that of Santa Teresa de Avila is the most striking and innovative. Depicting Teresa’s vision of her heart being transfixed by the arrow of divine love, the relief takes on a folksy turn. Instead of the angel delivering the arrow, the Holy Family is depicted as responsible for this transaction. San Jose’s steady hands guides Jesus with bow and arrow. The retablos may have been built between 1668 and the early 1700s, although the presence of flanges indicates that the altar belonged to a later era.

Remnants of wooden frontal depicting San Ignacio, holding a banner, has been made into a table. A portion of another frontal with the image of the Virgin Mary has been incorporated in a lectern. Sillas episcopales (chairs for the priest) are of the same style as the retablo, suggesting their antiquity.

Although the church fabric survived World War II, its ceiling, originally flat, was in a bad state and was replaced by one of varnished timber, slightly curved at the sides. The altar of the female saints was separated from the main nave by a grille fence, which was formerly part of the perimeter fence of the outer atrium. The intention was to make this a Blessed Sacrament chapel, open to visitors 24 hours daily, but the plan seems not to have materialized.  Written by René B. Javellana

The altar of the female saints was separated from the main nave by a grille fence, which was formerly part of the perimeter fence of the outer atrium. The intention was to make this a Blessed Sacrament chapel, open to visitors 24 hours daily, but the plan seems not to have materialized.  Written by René B. Javellana

photos.desc:
American-period Silliman Hall of Silliman University in Dumaguete City

(Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
Location: Dumaguete, Negros Oriental. Begun 1901.

Silliman University, founded on 28 Aug 1901 in Dumaguete City by Presbyterian missionaries, is the first Protestant school in the Philippines. Also considered the oldest North American University in Asia, it began as an academic institute named after Dr Horace B. Silliman, a retired businessman from the town of Cohoes, New York. In 1899, Dr Silliman convinced the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions to introduce a new educational system in the Philippines. He personally donated $10,000 to start an industrial school inspired by the Hamptin Institute of Virginia. Dr. David Sutherland Hibbard and his wife Laura were tasked to initiate the project. While checking possible locations in Cebu, Zamboanga, and Iloilo, a recommendation was made to check Dumaguete.

The Institute started as an all-male elementary school with only 15 students and basic facilities. In 1912, it admitted its first female student, Pura Blanco. Silliman Institute was elevated to a university status in 1938. The oldest building, Silliman Hall, is set in a campus, which is abundant with acacia trees and a breathtaking view of the Visayan sea. This three-story building was completed by Filipino students in Victorian style. Cast-iron steel columns with decorated capitals, recycled from the debris of a theater in the United States by former secretary of the Army and Navy Charles Glung, support the wooden upper floors. Corrugated G.I. sheets are used for the roof while capiz-paned windows greatly contribute to the ventilation, as does the generous veranda. During World War II, the Japanese used Silliman Hall as barracks and jail for Filipino and American prisoners captured from the mountains of Negros Oriental. Today it serves as the Silliman Anthropology Museum which features artifacts excavated in Negros Island.

 

Silliman University sits on a 62-hectare campus that now holds a total of 6,000 students and 500 faculty members. With a huge library, museum, auditorium, football field, archery range, tennis and pelota courts, gym, chapels, dormitories, faculty houses, and an Olympic size swimming pool, Silliman University remains true to its motto “Via, Veritas, Vita” (the Way, Truth, and Life) in ensuring a holistic Christian formation program. In 19 Jun 2002, Silliman University was declared as National Landmark by the National Historical Institute.  Written by Billy Ray C. Malacura

photos.desc:
Basilica Minore of San Martin de Tours in Taal, Batangas, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
Basilica Minore of San Martin de Tours. Location: Taal, Batangas. Begun 1858, completed 1878. Architect: Luciano Oliver.

The town and church of Taal were organized by the Augustinians originally in a place called Balagon. It was abandoned when the community transferred to what is the present-day town of San Nicolas. When Taal volcano erupted in 1754, the townspeople, together with the parish priest sought refuge in Caysasay. Here in 1756 Fray Martin Aguirre, OSA, began construction of a church of reef stones. Completed in 1782, the church and its adjoining convento were again ruined by Taal’s eruption in 1852. In 1858 Fr Marcos Anton, OSA, with the help of the government architect Luciano Oliver, started the construction of the present church of Taal on a plateau above Caysasay. Although inaugurated in 1856, the church was completed only in 1878. Fr Agapito Aparicio, OSA added a main altar and paved the baptistry with tiles said to come from Europe. It was elevated to a basilica minore on 22 Oct 1948. After years of neglect, the church was restored in 1972 to commemorate the quadricentennial of the town’s foundation. In 1974, it was declared a “national shrine.”

 

The church stands majestically on top of a hill and is unobstructed by any edifice. Its facade has been described as baroque as it is a single mass of stone shaped according to complex, rich, and dynamic designs. Paired Ionic and Corinthian columns contrast sharply with the massiveness of the facade and create “a dramatic vertical movement broken by the roundness of fenestration aligned horizontally” (Galende 1987). Ever since Taal town was marked as a potential heritage zone with its unusually wide and stately neoclassical church, community effort has been expended to preserve the town’s heritage. The focus was the church complex, with various levels of success. The exterior continues to go through refurbishments. The small bell tower that had been destroyed was rebuilt, and the Escuela Pia outside the church was restored to be reused as a venue for events.

The basilica’s cruciform interior is divided into three naves by massive piers supporting rounded arches of stone. The transepts, like the apse, are rounded. The interior has recently been refurbished in a more pleasing and aesthetically sound way. Around 2008, the trompe l’oeil painting in the manner of San Agustin in Intramuros was reconstructed. The nave floor was resurfaced. The side altar, formerly an unsightly neon-lit cement structure which occasionally housed the Virgin of Caysasay, has been replaced by a replica of the original wooden retablo. However, by 2013, the neoclassical main retablo had been restyled with the addition of flanking niches in the baroque idiom, detracting from its authenticity.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

photos.desc:
Tabon Cave Complex, 2016

(Edgar Allan M. Sembrano)

text:
Natural habitation used by humans. Location Lipuun Point, Quezon, Palawan. 50,000-600 BP.

The Tabon Cave Complex is located in Lipuun Point, a 138-ha land formed by limestone and connected to the mainland of Palawan by an isthmus of mangrove forest. Composed primarily of karst formation which dates back to about 25 million years, it is rocky with large domes, deep cliffs, and steep hills with a highest elevation of 215 meters above sea level. Rich in plant and animal life, Lipuun Point has attracted humans from prehistoric times to the present.

The area is famous for its caves, rock shelters, ledges, and overhangs as living areas and later, as burial sites of prehistoric humans. Archaeological explorations and excavations undertaken by the National Museum since the 1960s have revealed numerous archaeological materials. The archaeological finds belong to cultural periods that have been traced back from 50,000 to 600 years ago. The most important find is of human remains dating to 47,000 years ago, recovered from a cave known as Tabon.

 

There is only one Tabon Cave but the caves, rock shelters, and other crevices are collectively known as the Tabon Caves and the entire Lipuun Point as the Tabon Cave Complex. Of the 218 caves identified within the complex, 38 caves were used as habitation and burial sites in the past. These caves have revealed a wide-range of cultural materials. These are: a flake tool tradition associated with animal and human fossils dating back to the Paleolithic Age (50,000 years ago); a jar burial complex from the Late Neolithic Period (3,500 years ago); to the Developed Metal Age (1,500 years ago); and local trade with China exchanging goods with tradeware ceramics during the Sung and Yuan Dynasties (1,000 to 600 years ago).

The archaeological activities provide insights into more than 50,000 years of Philippine prehistory. Because of its cultural and scientific significance, the Tabon Cave Complex was declared as a Site Museum Reservation on 11 Apr 1972 pursuant to Proclamation No 996 and as a National Cultural Treasure on 27 Feb 2011 by virtue of National Museum Declaration No 1-2011.  Written by Angel P. Bautista

 

Sources

Bautista, Angel P. 2004. Tabon Cave Complex, Lipuun Point, Quezon, Palawan. Manila: National Museum.

Fox, Robert B. 1970. The Tabon Caves. Manila: National Museum.
